div.p: CERTAINE CHOISE GROVNDS, and principles of our Christian Religion, with their seuerall Expositions, set forth in way of Questions, and Answers.

Wherein the people of the Parish of NORTHIHAM, in the County of SVSSEX, haue beene Catechized, and instructed, for the settling of their hearts and mindes, in the mysteries of saluation, and for their better preparation to the Lords Supper.

p.hi: Now published for their sakes, and for the further vse of the Church of God.

div.p: By IOHN FREWEN, Minister of the Word of God, in that particular Congregation.
div.q: ROM. 10.14. How shall they call on him, in whom they haue not beleeued? and how shall they beleeue in him, of whom they haue not heard? and how shall they heare without a Preacher?
div.p: Printed at London by G. P. for ROGER POTT, dwelling at the signe of the Flower-de luce in Pauls Churchyard. 1621.

div.head: TO THE RIGHT WORSHIPFVLL SIR THOMAS COVENTREY Knight, his Maiesties Attourney Generall: And to the vertuous and true Christian Lady, the Lady ELIZABETH his wife; Grace, mercy, and peace be multiplyed from God the Father, through our Lord and Sauiour Iesus Christ.
div.p:
RIght Worshipfull, and right deare in the Lord, I being desirous to leaue behind me (for after my dayes) some small portion of my former labours in the Ministerie of the Gospell, as an assured and infallible
testimony of my vnfayned loue towards the good & saluation of that people, whose resident Pastor I haue beene almost the full space of forty yeeres, and resoluing that it should be the ensuing principles, with their seuerall Expositions: I now make bold to present them to your Worships, and vpon these two motiues to dedicate them to your worthy names.

The one, that by this meanes they might remaine, as a perpetuall pledge, and euerliuing witnesse of my thankfulnes for your many great and vndeserued fauours, most willingly and cheerefully vouchsafed vnto myselfe, and vnto mine, from time to time.

These could I expresse in their particulars, but I forbeare to doe it. And yet not so much to escape the reproach of flattery (wherewith vniustly by some I might be branded) as because you take no such delight, (as some others doe) in hearing praises, and commendations, though iustly deserued.

The second reason is, that they might be a like euidence, and seale of my hearty, and vnfayned longing after your growth, and going on in grace and goodnes, according to the glorious Gospell of Iesus Christ: whereof though I haue no cause to doubt, yet can I not but desire it: & desiring it (as I do) no other way better thē this, am I able to expresse it.

Famous, & of great esteeme, and that right worthily, Sir, are you growne to be (the Lord be praised for it:) And that not only in regard of such eminent places, wherein it hath pleased God (by degrees, and in his appointed times) to set you: but for your learning, wisedome, and sufficiency, to the well discharge of all, and euery of them. But yet, if I may be bold, to speake what I conceiue, and rest perswaded of (with the ioynt opinion of many others) this is nothing so precious for your good name, as your religious, vpright, and conscionable proceedings, appearing and shining to the view of all men, in the middest of thick and foggie mists of corruption,
and when conscience among many is so little regarded. Heereby haue you gayned the loue, and commendation of all estates and degrees: yea many there are, that know not your person, who will not make mention of your name, without great respect.

The like may I say of you also, Madame, that although you bee aboundantly qualified, (as God bee praised you are) with all good gifts of body and minde, that be fit ornaments, and which adde a grace to your sex, and degree of calling, (as it is respected, and had in account among the men of this world) yet the honour and crowne of your good name, is the good report your Ladiship hath gotten in the Church of
God, among such as truly feare God, for your good and vertuous disposition in matters of religion and godlinesse, for your modesty, meekenes, humility, and such like graces, as they appeare to be graces of sanctification.

And indeed, what reckoning is to be made of humane wisedome, learning and knowledge, of riches, beautie, of worldly honour and preferment, (yea euen in the highest degree of them) if they be not found in the way of righteousnes? if they be not sanctified by the Spirit of God? Without this special blessing they do but puffe vp, and make onely a slender shew, and a bare profession, without all care and conscience of
an agreeable practice.

Oh, let your Worships labour then (in a zealous vse of the ordinary meanes which God hath appointed) for this so great and excellent a grace (as is the grace of sanctification) that your high places and callings, your wisedome, learning, riches, and all other good gifts which God hath bestowed vpon you, being seasoned and sweetned therewith, they may all ioyne together in a sweet harmony and sound consent, for the aduancement of Gods glory in your mortall bodies, and for the sure sealing and assurance of your owne saluation. And the Lord giue you not onely spirituall vnderstanding, for a generall conceiuing
out of his Word, what is to be done, and what not, but spirituall wisedome also for a right vnderstanding, and a right applying of it in particular.

And thus not doubting of your fauourable acceptance of these my weake endeuours, for the reasons before remembred, commended vnto you, and according to that of the Apostle Peter, 1. Epist. 1.12. and of S. Iohn, 1. Epist. 2.21. I now take my leaue, as the Apostle Paul doth, Acts 20.32. resting at Northiham, August 24. 1621.

closer.signed: Your Worships at commandement in the Lord, IOHN FREWEN.

div.head: TO MY MVCH RESPECTED IN THE Lord, William White, Esquire; and to all other my louing friends and neighbours, men, and women, children, and seruants, of what estate and degree soeuer, inhabitants of the Parish of Northiham: a gracious supply of all spirituall blessings in heauenly things, for the ioy and comfort of their seuerall consciences, and for the sure sealing of Gods loue and fauour in Iesus Christ, to the euerlasting peace, and saluation of their soules.
div.p:
BEloued Brothren & Sisters in the LORD: If there should bee a question amongst vs, who excels, and hath the preeminence, for birth,
for riches, for credit, and countenance in the world; or for humane wisedome, learning, and knowledge: This would bee found no ouer-hard or vnpossible matter. But if it should bee questioned, what degrees there are of sinceritie and good affections to true Religion and godlinesse: this would not so easily be decided: The greatest part conceiting of themselues, that they are as neere to the Kingdome of Heauen, and walke as directly in the way that leadeth therunto, as the best.

(A second sort also, who although they bee not so well grounded and settled in Religion as the former; and therefore cannot possibly either haue such peace in themselues, or make such conscience of all their wayes: yet are tractable, willing to be instructed, admonished, and reformed: And thus giuing good hope of a comfortable proceeding in the way of godlinesse and saluation:)

So, are there many (on th'other side) whose mindes and affections are so wholly set vpon the profits & pleasures of this world, as that they seem almost vtterly vncapable of the heauenly things. If they come to the Church (as sometimes they doe) when the holy exercises of Religion are in hand, either they are asleepe, or so giue place
to idle, and carnall cogitations, that they nothing profit by any thing spoken: but returne to their houses as carelesse and secure, as ignorant and sencelesse in the mysteries of saluation, as they came from thence. Nay, some of them as vaine and common swearers; as wilful prophaners of the Lords day; as malicious, as proud and couetous, as filthy talkers, as very lyers, slanderers, tale-carryers, Alehouse-haunters, and the like, as euer before. The Word of God sounds in their eares, but can take no rooting in their hearts.

Now of this third sort there be many; (as I said before) yea, some such there are manifestly faulty in some of these, who in regard of their yeeres, education, and wealth, should be better instructed, and giue better examples.

They that are thus affected, as they cannot loue the Minister whom God
hath set ouer them, because hee is Christs Minister, nor yet any other that truely feare God, because they doe so; but are very ready vpon all occasions to oppose against such, to disgrace, despight, and discourage them to the vttermost of their power. So very small delight can either the Minister or any of the rest take in them againe: And so much the lesse, because seldome, or neuer, shall you heare any of these either penitently acknowledge any thing in them to be amisse; or in humility desire to bee taught and instructed, but (puffed vp with high conceits) are ready rather to wrest and peruert wholesome doctrine; yea, peremptorily to censure and controll, whatsoeuer either discouereth their corruptions, or crosseth their peeuish and peruerse affections, how well grounded so euer it bee vpon the Word of God.

This (my Brethren) is the generall
state and condition wherein (so farre as I am able to discerne) you presently stand. And let no man bee offended for this manner of discouerie, seeing it is done in the presence of GOD, and of his Church, vpon grounded experience, and without the touch of any mans person in particular: For conscience also of my duty, and that euery one of you might be the better mooued, and stirred vp to try and examine your seuerall soules, and finde how the case stands betwixt God and them.

As I obserue this difference among the men of this Congregation; so hath late experience (much against my hope and expectation) discouered the like betwixt you that are the women. But not iudging it fit in this manner to stand longer vpon it; I will onely admonish and put you in mind of these two things, which haue been formerly taught and applyed vnto
you. The one, that the nature and sexe of women is no sufficient warrant, or excuse; wherefore you may lawfully, or safely continue in ignorance of heauenly things: or why the Word of God should not dwel in you plenteously, Col. 3.16 in all wisedome and spirituall vnderstanding.

The other is, that seeing it is a principall end of your Creation, that you should bee helpers; Gen. 2.18. that therefore in the feare of God, according to the notable examples of Priscilla,
Rom. 16.3, 12. and other godly women (whose praise is in the Scripture) you endeuour to answere the same end of your creation, in being helpers not onely at all times, Phil. 4 3. and in all good things to your Husbands; but also to the Minister (as shee was to the Apostle Paul) and vnto one another, in spending some part of the time, when you are together at one anothers house, and at womens labours, and when you feast and gossip
together, for the edifying of one another in the holy Faith; by asking questions, and by calling that to mind which hath beene publikely taught, by exhorting, admonishing, and incouraging one another in the way of godlinesse, and by all other good meanes, as occasion is offered.

And that it may appeare to the glory of God, to the ioy and comfort of all such as feare God, and to the silencing of the contrary-minded, that the saluation of you all, hath beene carefully endeuoured, and sought after; I haue published this little Treatise, containing those speciall, and choise Principles of our Christian Religion, vvith their seuerall Expositions (as neere as I could both for matter and forme) which you haue in writing, and wherein not long since, you haue beene instructed.

These doe I desire to leaue behinde mee, for a perpetuall Testimonie and
pledge of my true and vnfained loue towards you all, and as my last Will and Testament; wherein I bequeath vnto you the very best gifts and Legacies, which I haue to bestow. Onely, whereas in other Testaments vvhich concerne goods, and Lands, the death of the Testator giues life and power to the Will that is made, and vvhich before is of none effect: It is my will and hearty desire (if it may so also please God) that the Legacies thus giuen and bequeathed, may be possessed, and enioyed of you (to whom they are meant) euen whiles I liue. And that howsoeuer the time of my dissolution cannot now be farre of; and my desire is to benefit many (yea euen after my death) yet, that I may liue to see some fruit of them, before I goe hence, and be no more.

Herein (my beloued) shall you more comfort the feeble spirits, and bring greater ioy, and gladnesse of
heart to the ancient yeeres, and last breath of your deceasing Pastor (when God cals for it) then hath been all sorrow, and griefe conceiued, for, and in regard of any former iniuries, and vnkindnesses: what, and how great soeuer.

And now, my last request is, that you, who haue religiously harkened vnto these Principles, and doctrines of Religion when they were preached, would be as diligent in reading, and meditating vpon them, beeing thus brought into the light; for the better establishing, and confirmation of your hearts & minds in the truth: Phil. 3.1. for it grieueth me not to write the same things vnto you; and for you it is a sure thing. And that you (on the other side) who haue carelesly regarded them in times past, would take the opportunity which the Lord doth offer, in thus putting them into your hands, and in laying them againe before your eyes, to redeeme the
time past with a more religious care and conscience of the glory of God, and of your owne saluation. For the opening of your eyes, & sanctifying of your hearts & affections whereunto: I heartily pray and beseech the Lord.

And whereas (good Mr White) I am thus bold to make choise of your name (amongst all rest of the neighbours) in this Dedication: I haue done it for two especiall Reasons, and respects. First, that by this publike testimony of speciall respect, I might the better expresse the great desire which I haue of such true and vnfained loue in your selfe, and in yours, as whereof many yeeres together in the good neighbourhood, and godly conuersation of your deceased parents, I had good experience, and content: And that as a Successor in grace, as well as in nature, you shew and approue your selfe constant & resolute for the nourishing and preseruation of it; and not suffer the same by
the suggestions and subtilties of the contrary-minded, of such as are ill-affected in this kind, to be remoued frō you, or stolne out of your heart. The which to your worthy praise and commendation in the Churh of God, will be so much the more, because such a succession and descent of true ancient loue towards their Minister in the generation of almost all the rest, is much decayd, if it be not already euen vtterly extinguished, and come to nought.

The second reason is, that by this meanes, you might in a more speciall manner, be prouoked and stirred vp to true zeale, and seruency of Spirit, as well for the right vnderstanding, as for the profession and practise of these seuerall Doctrines, and Principles of our Faith: wherin (together with the rest) you haue formerly beene instructed: And that not onely in regard of your own peculiar good, and saluation, and of those that are committed to your
charge in your owne particular Family: but for the good example also, alluring, incouraging, and drawing on of o • hers. For being the chiefe (through the Lords bounty and goodnes) in this place of your aboad, and hauing therefore the eyes of all sorts vpon you: it is well worthy your serious consideration, and godly regard; how much more, then many others, you may glorifie God; and what great good you may doe among your neighbours, in be ng a godly president, and patterne of Religion and vertue, in your life and conuersation, in shewing a good and cheerefull countenance, and in expressing a true and sincere loue to the glorious Gospell of Iesus Christ, both in the Ministery, and in the profession of it; hauing no fellowship (in the meane season) with vnfruitfull works of darknesse, but eschewing and auoiding them from the bottome of your heart. And (good Sir) bee you well assured,
that God doth require, and will looke for all this at your hands.

And now,
Heb.
• 3.20, 21, 22. the God of peace that brought againe from the dead, our Lord Iesus Christ, the great Shepheard of the Sheepe, through the bloud of the euerlasting Couenant, make you perfect in all good workes, to doe his will, working in you that which is pleasant in his sight, through Iesus Christ. To whom bee praise for euer and euer, Amen. And so I rest,

closer.signed: Yours alwayes in Christ Iesus, to doe you good, IOHN FREVVEN.

div.head: TO THE YOVNG AND WORTHY KNIGHT, SIR IOHN HARE, SONNE AND heyre apparant to the Right Worshipfull Sir RALPH HARE of Stowe Hall in the County of Norfolke: And to the vertuous yong Lady, the Lady ELIZABETH his Wife; and to her brother, the hopefull yong Gentleman, Mr THOMAS COVENTRY, eldest Sonne to the Right Worshipfull his MAIESTIES Attorney Generall before mentioned. Long life, and good dayes, with increase of all spirituall blessings, in heauenly things.
div.p:
WHen I had finished the precedent Epistles (welbeloued in the Lord) I considerd with my selfe, that, seeing they were Principles, and grounds of Christianity, which I had expounded, and was ready to publish: I might doe some further seruice pleasing God, acceptable and profitable vnto you, (being as yet but nouices and younglings in Religion:) if in some speciall
manner, I should commend them to your meditations.

And • owsoeuer to you, Sir Iohn, I am but a stranger, and in that respect, might haue been discouraged: yet such is, & alwaies hath been mine vnfained loue & good affection t • wards her, who now (by Gods prouidence) is become yours: that this could n • t hinder. For I cannot otherwise rest perswaded, but that all good offices of true loue now done to her, or vnto you for her sake, will as kindely in • uery degree be entertained, as if they directly aimed at your selfe alone.

And, good Madame, doe you for your part, cherish by all good meanes, all good motions and affections in your kinde and louing Husband. And as it is a principall end of your Creation, to be an Helper: So in the feare of God, apply, and endeuour your selfe, to bee cheerefull, comfortable, and h • lpfull indeed. And as in all duties and respects which concerne this life: So especially in those things that concerne
Gods glory, and your owne saluation, together with the good and saluation of such, as may any way belong vnto you, or depend vpon you.

And for you (welbeloued Mr Thomas) as you haue hitherto by your godly Parents, been carefully traded and trained vp in the feare and nurture of the Lord: and haue shewed your selfe docible, tractable, and towardly, (which I am able to report vpon some good experience,) by yo • r behauiour, by your gestures, by your speech, and by the course of your practices, making your selfe knowne, to haue vprightnes and good meaning in you without dissimulation: According to that of Salomon,
Pro. 20.11. Pro. 20. Euen a child will make knowne by his conuersation, whether he be pure, and whether his worke bee right: So settl • your s • lfe to grow forward in grace and goodnes, as in yeeres and dayes. And then, shall you be sure, as well as the an ient, to be rewarded with saluation in the life to come, and honoured among all good
men with praise and estimation, whiles you are heere.

To you all I say with Salomon, Ecclesiastes 12.
Eccles. 12.1. Remember your Creator in the dayes of your youth, whiles the euill dayes come not, that is, before old age commeth. For you must know, that God requires the seruice of youth, as well as the seruice of old age. Nay, this, before the other. And if you looke into the Scripture, or into experience, you shall hardly finde any who haue accustomed themselues to vanity, and prophanenesse in the time of their youth, that doe become truely and vnfainedly repentant when they are old. As Ier. 13.
Ier. 13.23. Can the Blackamore change his skinne, or the Leopard his spots? then may yee also doe good, that are accustomed to doe euill. And therefore Prou. 22.
Prou. 22.6. Teach a childe in the trade of his way, and when hee is old, hee shall not depart from it. And Psalme 119.
Psal. 119 9. Wherewith shall a young man
redresse his way? In taking heed thereto, according to thy Word. Thus you see, that the Word of God ought to bee the rule and direction of yong mens liues, as well as of those that are old. Let the Word of God therefore dwell in you plenteously in al wisdome,
Col. 3.16. & spirituall vnderstanding. Search the Scriptures,
Ioh. 5.39. Psal. 1.2. and take delight to meditate in them day and night: yea, make them the Lanterne for your feet,
Psal. 119.105. and a light for your pathes.

And not onely for my sake, and at my request; but for your owne good, and for the better settling and establishing of your hearts and minds in the truth, take a serious view of this little Treatise. Lay these Principles in your hearts, as a foundation for other higher points of Doctrine to bee builded vpon. Imprint them in your memories, bee zealous in the profession of them, without being ashamed. Consider, 2. Tim. 2 7. 2. Thes. 2.17 what I say, and the Lord blesse you, and giue
you vnderstanding in all things, comfort your hearts, and establish you in euery word and good worke. And so I take my leaue at Northiham in Sussex. September the 20. 1621. Resting

closer.signed: Yours in all Christian duties, IOHN FREVVEN.

div.head: The generall heads and points of Doctrine, handled in this Treatise.
div.p: 1 ALL such are to be Catechized, and instructed in the grounds a • d principles of Christian Religion, who are ignorant of th • m, and vnderstand them not, of what estate and condi ion soeuer they be, high or low, rich or poore, old or young, male or female: for there is no respect of persons with God, but God will that all men shall be saued▪ and come to the knowledge of the truth.
2 Christian Religion consisteth in a true and sincere acknowledging of that truth, which is according to godlines.

3 That truth doth teach vs what we are to know and beleeue, concerning God, and
what wee are to know and beleeue concerning our selues.

4 God is a Spirit, which is most simple, most holy, eternall, infinite, of inestimable glory, maiesty, and power, all-sufficient, onely wise, onely good, most iust, most mercifull, and therefore one. There are three eternall, and equall persons of the Godhead, distinguished by their proper difference, but yet not separated one from another. The Father, the Sonne, and the holy Ghost.
5 Wee are to know concerning our selues, what we are by nature, and what by grace.
6 Wee are by nature the children of wrath, full of sinne and corruption, and heires of hell and condemnation.
7 By grace we are freed from the power and dominion of sinne: Of the children of wrath wee are made children, and heires of God, yea coheires with Christ.
8 Christ is the eternall Sonne of GOD, perfect GOD, and perfect man in one person.

9 Christ, as touching his Godhead, was without beginning, of one, and the same essence, and being with the Father equall,
and all one with him, in glory, maiesty, and power: and he became man, when he took to his diuine nature, our flesh in the wombe of the virgin Mary, like vnto vs in all things, except sinne.

10 It was a matter of so great necessity, in regard of our saluation, that Christ should haue two natures, and be in one person both God and man, that he could not otherwise haue ouercome death and the deuill, vnder whose captiuity wee were holden, neither haue satisfied Gods iustice for our sinnes, nor reconciled vs vnto him.
11 Christ performed this (according to his flesh and humane nature) by his humiliation and sufferings, wherein hee became obedient vnto the death, euen to the death of the Crosse.
12 Christ his obedience, and the fruit and effect of his humiliation and sufferings, are applyed vnto vs, and made ours, by a true and liuely faith.

13 A true and liuely faith, is a supernaturall worke, wrought in the heart of man, by the Spirit of God, whereby wee apprehend, receiue, and apply vnto our selues, Iesus Christ, with all his benefits, righteousnes, and redemption.
14 The ordinary meanes whereby the holy Ghost doth worke this faith in the hearts of Gods children, is the ministery and preaching of the Word of God.
15 This faith is nourished, strengthened, and confirmed, by hearing the same Word of God preached and read, as also by prayer, conference, and partaking the Sacraments.

16 A Sacrament is a publike worke of the Church, instituted by our Lord Iesus Christ, and consisting of a visible signe, or signes, whereby the promises of God, concerning the free forgiuenesse of our sinnes, and euerlasting life, are firmely confirmed, and sealed vp in our hearts.
17 There are onely two Sacraments instituted by our Lord Iesus Christ: The Sacrament of Baptisme, and the Sacrament of the Lords Supper.

18 Baptisme is a Sacrament of the new Testament, wherein is signified and sealed vnto vs, that we are as assuredly washed frō our sinnes, by the bloud of Christ, as our flesh is washed with water, In the name of the Father, the Sonne, and the holy Ghost.

19 The Supper of the Lord is a Sacrament instituted by our Lord Iesus Christ,
whereby is signified and sealed vnto vs, that we are as assuredly sustained to eternall life, by the body of Christ crucified, and by his bloud shed, as wee certainly eate the broken bread at the Lords Table, and drinke the wine out of the cup.
20 Wee cannot be sustayned to eternall life, vnlesse we eate the flesh of Christ, and drinke his bloud.
21 All that receiue the Sacrament, doe not feed vpon Christ to eternall life, but only such as are Gods elect.
22 Gods elect doe eate Christs flesh, and drinke his bloud, by a true and liuely faith in his death and redemption.

23 A man may be assured of his election, by the witnesse of Gods Spirit, working in him true repentance, and framing his heart to beleeue, and to yeeld obedience according to the Word, and will of God.

24 When wee receiue bread and wine at the Lords Table, we ought to set our hearts and mindes vpon the death and passion of our Lord Iesus Christ, to glorifie & praise God, for the most excellent worke of our redemption by him: confessing, that therein consisteth all our happines, and saluation, and that it is no more possible for vs to
come to the Kingdome of heauen without it, then it is possible to liue in the world without meate and drinke.

24 Such as presume to receiue this Sacrament, without thus remembring the death and passion of our Lord Iesus Christ, (to glorifie and praise God, for the worke of redemption by him) are vnworthy eaters and drinkers of it, guilty of the body and bloud of the Lord, and eate and drinke their owne damnation.

26 Wee must prepare our selues beforehand, for the worthy receiuing of the Lords Supper, by examining our knowledge, our faith, our repentance, our purposes and affections, how sound and vpright they are before God.
Whether Iudas receiued the Sacrament.

div.head: CERTAINE GROVNDS AND PRINCIPLES OF Christian Religion.
Quest. 1. Who are to be catechized and instructed in the Grounds, and Principles of Christian Religion?
div.p: Ans. All such are to be catechized, and instructed in the Grounds and Principles of Christian Religion, who are ignorant of them, and vnderstand them not, of what estate, and condition soeuer they be; high, or low; rich, or poore; old, or yong; male, or female: for there is no respect of persons with God, but he will that all men shall bee saued, and come vnto the Knowledge of the Truth, Rom. 2.11. 1. Tim. 2.4.

div.head: EXPOSITION.
div.p:
THis order of teaching, and instructing the youth, and ignorant, in the Grounds, & Principles
of Religion, hath alwayes beene in the Church of God, as plainely appeares (first for the Old Testament) in these words of the Lord to Abraham, Gen. 18.
Gen. 18.17, 19. Shall I hide from Abraham, that thing which I doe? &c. For I know him (saith God) that hee will command his sonnes, and his houshold after him, that they keepe the way of the Lord, to doe righteousnesse, and iudgement, &c. And Deut. 6.
Deut 6.6.7, 8. & • . 20, 21. These words which I command thee this day, shall be in thine heart, and thou shalt rehearse them continually vnto thy children, &c. And afterwards, When thy sonne shall aske thee in time to come, saying, What meane these Testimonies, these Ordinances, and Lawes which the Lord our God hath commanded you? Then shalt thou say to thy sonne, We were Pharaohs bondmen, &c. Also Deut. 31.
Deut 31.12, 13. Gather the people together (saith the Lord by Moses) men, women, and children, and the stranger that is within thy gate, that they may heare, and that they may learne, and feare the Lord your God, and keepe and obserue all the words of this Law, &c. What can be spoken more plainely? It being the Lords expresse goodwill and pleasure, that not
onely men; but that men, women and children should be taught, and instructed, in his Statutes and Ordinances. The Prophet Dauid thought it in like manner necessary, that the people generally should come to the knowledge of Gods Word; and therefore Psal. 1.
Psal. 1.1, 2. pronounceth him blessed, that takes delight to meditate therein day and night. And Psalm. 119.
Psal. 119.9. &c.
Wherewithall shall a young man redresse his way? In taking heed thereunto according to thy Word &c. This might yet further be amplified, by sundry other authorities, as Exod. 12. and 13. chap.
Exod 12.26, 27, & cha. 13.24, 15. Psal. 78.
Psal. 78.1, 2, 3. &c.
&c. All notably shewing, how highly God required that euery Father, and Master of a Family, should bee so perfect and skilfull in the Doctrines and principles of the Law, and Word of God as that they might not only walke directly themselues in the wayes of holinesse, and righteousnesse: but bee able to teach, and instruct their Children, and Families, from generation to generation. To put the which in practice, how religiously carefull, the godly Fathers (at that time) were: the commendation, which the Lord giueth of Abraham in the place before alledged, doth
plainely shew. Of this order of teaching, speaketh the Apostle (for the New Testament) Heb. 5. & 6.
Heb. 5.12, 13, 14, &. ch. 6.1, 2, 3. where hee termeth these grounds and principles of Religion, the doctrine of the beginning of Christ: and compareth such as haue need to be instructed therein, vnto little children, that are to be fed with milke, because they are not able to digest strōg meat. And therfore exhorteth, that leauing these things, they should be led forward to perfection. Hereunto tendeth also the doctrine of the Apostle Paul, Ephes. 4. 1. Thes. 4. 2. Tim. 2.
Ephes. 4.11, 12, 13, 14, 15. 1. Thes. 5.14. 2. Tim. 2.24, 25. and in sundry other places.
In the Primitiue Church (after the dayes of the Apostles) there were two sorts of such, as were catechized, and instructed in the Grounds and Principles of Religion.

A first sort consisted of such as were of ripe age, and who comming vnto Christianity, from among the Iewes, and Gentiles, were first taught these doctrines of the beginning of Christ, of repentance, and faith, (as the Apostle calleth them,) then baptized, and afterward admitted to the Lords Supper.

The second sort, were such as were
borne in the Church, as the children of Christians, who with all conuenient speed, after their birth, were baptized, as members of the Church. Afterward, being instructed, they were likewise receiued to the Sacrament of the Supper. Which order (in a comely and commendable maner,) hath continued in the Church of Christ, euen vnto this day.

Now, Reasons. wherefore all such as are ignorant, and vnderstand them not, are thus to be taught, and instructed in the Principles of Faith, and Religion: Besides the expresse commandement of God, whereof I haue spoken before. Another maine and especiall reason is, because the knowledge and faith of these things, is as necessarie to the well-being, and sound estate of a Christian man, as a good and sure foundation is to an house, or other building. For euen, as if the foundation be not sure, and good, whatsoeuer is builded therevpon cannot possibly stand: so, in whomsoeuer these doctrines and beginnings of Christianitie are not settled, and established: let such a one make what faire shew hee will, and attaine to as much other knowledge as hee can, yet is all
in vaine, and to no purpose.

Whosoeuer (I say) perswadeth himselfe, that he is a sound and good Christian▪ and yet hath not laid these things for a foundation: hee doth but most miserably deceiue himselfe. There is vndoubtedly no more stablenesse in the Christianity of such a one, nor any more reckoning to be made of it, then of a building without a good foundation, ready with euery blast of winde to be ouerturned.

Vse 1 In the Church of Christ, the children of God are not all of one age, and strength. And although no man in this life can possibly attaine vnto an absolute measure of wisedome, and knowledge, in spirituall, and heauenly things, (the perfection hereof, as of all other like graces, being reserued for the life to come:) yet very rare and surpassing excellent gifts hath the Lord bestowed vpon some. So as the Word of God dwelleth in them plenteously in all wisedome; and they are able to comprehend with all Saints, which is the breadth, and length, and depth, and height, &c. Col. 3. & Ephes. 3.
Col. 3.16. Ephes. 3.18, &c. Whereas many, yea the greatest part, on the other side, are so simple in knowledge, and so weake in
faith, as that in comparison of an exquisite knowledge, and faith, they are to be estéemed but as little children that are to bee fed with milke, and cannot digest strong meate.

Now as it is in vaine, to offer strong meat to new borne babes; euen so, to as little purpose is it, to preach the higher, and harder Doctrine of the Gospell vnto such, who in the degrees of Christianitie, are not growne past the Principles, and first grounds of Religion. Which, as it worthily tendeth to the reproofe of all such in the Ministerie, as neglect a constant, and conscionable discharge of this duty, and either teach not at all, or account it sufficient onely to preach: so for the loue of your saluation, and to the end you might either bee builded vp towards Gods Kingdome, by such degrees as he hath sanctified, or vtterly made without excuse, and not be able to plead (when yee appeare before God, and are called to an account,) that you would haue learned, if you might haue been taught. As I haue beene accustomed many yeeres together, and for some part of the euening exercise to handle one, or some of them: So, for
your instruction in the mysteries of saluation, and better preparation to the Lords Supper, (which is shortly to bee celebrated, and whereof yee make reckoning, for the most part, to be partakers:) My purpose is, (through Gods assistance) to begin now, a briefe and plaine exposition of these few points, which (from among the rest) I haue chosen heretofore, and for the most part of them, giuen you in writing, for that end and purpose. Only crauing at your hands, a religious attention and regard, that when you come to giue an account of your faith, and how well you haue profited: You speake not as Parrots, but with soundnesse of iudgement, and vnderstanding.

Vse 2 As the Minister, as a wise and faithfull Steward, Luke 12.42 1. Cor. 3.1, 2 2. Tim. 4.2. ought to giue to euery one his portion, and that in due season; milke to the younglings, and strong meat to them that are of age, to instruct the ignorant, to comfort the feeble-minded, to admonish the vnruly, to exhort with the sweet promises of Gods grace, and mercy in Christ Iesus, and to terrifie with the threatnings of his iudgements, according to the diuers occasions that are offered,
and that measure of gifts which hee hath receiued: euen so is this a duty required also, and that after a speciall manner; of Parents, and Masters of Families. For it is not inough for them to prouide for the bodies of their children, and seruants; but they ought to bee chiefely carefull for the good of their soules. Many thinke that if they finde their Seruants sufficient meat and drinke, and pay them their wag • s, they haue sufficiently discharged themselues, but they are greatly deceiued. For what doe they more herein, then the very Turkes and Infidels, that know not God? Againe, if men thinke themselues discharged by prouiding for their children, & by leauing them a temporal patrimonie, and in the meane season neuer regard by the ordinary meanes which God hath appointed, to make them heires and inheritors of the Kingdome of Heauen: What doe they more, then the very Iewes and Gentiles? To leaue them rich in the world, and poore in God; to lay vp for them treasures on earth, and to neglect the treasures of Heauen, which are the true and euerlasting substance? What will this auaile them in the end? The
dwelling houses of vs Christians in this time of the Gospell, should be as so many little Churches, vsing prayer to God in them, sometimes together with our Families, and sometimes more priuately by our selues; catechizing our youth, teaching the ignorant, reading the Scriptures, singing of Psalmes, examining our Children, and Seruants, how they profit by the publike Ministery, what Doctrines haue beene taught, and exhortations deliuered, encouraging the towardly, and rebuking the other.

Euery Master of a Family (in this flourishing time of the Gospell) should be able to say with Ioshua, chapter 24.
Iosh. 24.15. I and my House will serue the LORD. And euery Mistris and Dame should bee as Queene Hester,
Ester 4.16. who answered Mordecai; I and my Maids will doe likewise. Herein haue we also the notable example of Dauid, as Psalme 101.
Psal. 101.2, 3. Rom. 16.3, 5.14, 15. Phil. 2. And such little Churches were the houses of Philemon, of Priscilla, and Aquila, & of many others that might be remembred.

And thus shall we giue our selues, and those that depend vpon vs, a passage, and entrance into Gods Kingdome. But
alack, if we examine the matter, how far are the greatest part of our houses, from being (as it were) such little Churches? Men and women in most of our Families, so vnable to teach, and instruct their Children, and Seruants, in the doctrine of saluation: that they haue continuall néed to be taught, and instructed themselues. So farre from praying with, and for their Families, that very seldome they pray for themselues. And then too, how coldly and carelessely? how without sound knowledge, sence, or consideration, either of their owne wants, and necessities, or of Gods mercy, and fauour in Christ Iesus? It is too apparant. But I passe to a third vse.

As to the being of an house, there Vse 3 must not onely a foundation be laid, but the rest of the building in order insue: so to the being of a sound and absolute Christian, there must not onely be a true knowledge and vnderstanding of the first grounds, and principles of Religion, but a zealous, and religious profiting also, in the rest of the Doctrines, which the Lord hath reuealed in his Word. It being in very deed, an vnseemely thing, for such
as haue the preaching of the Gospell among them, to be alwayes sticking in the first grounds of Religion; yea, euen as monstrous, as it is to remaine alwayes a child, and not to grow from the degrées of infancy, hauing fit meanes, and nourishment orderly applyed. We haue heard the Principles of Religion, with other Doctrines of the Gospell, plainely, and familiarly taught: we haue had liberty, and opportunity, many dayes and yeeres together, to meditate vpon them, and to exercise our selues in them. Is it not then a very great shame, and an intolerable vnthankefulnesse, that wee should continue to bee herein but as little children, that know not the right hand from the left? If we should be asked any question touching our worldly affaires, we can (for the most part) giue a ready answere, and render a sound reason of that we say: but if we be asked any question, touching our estate before God, and how the case standeth with vs concerning Faith, repentance, peace of Conscience, and other like graces of Sanctification: wee will many of vs be found mute, and know not what to say; yea, and which is most of all lamentable
to consider, nothing at all are we ashamed for the most part, to consider our ignorance, in this behalfe: This old Popish poison hath so infected mens hearts, that ignorance is the mother of deuotion; And that if they can say the Lords Prayer, &c. If they come to the Church, and goe vnder the names of Christians, and Protestants, it is sufficient. And more precisenesse then necessary, to labour for further perfection: wherein they wretchedly deceiue themselues.

But to help and remedy this (as much as is possible) remember alwayes (I beseech you, Brethren) and keepe this in minde, that the best Christians, and such as be indued with greatest graces, are very farre from being thus conceited of themselues. They, euen they (I say) seeing iust cause to complaine, and finde fault with their owne ignorance, and slacknesse in holy duties; and to bee more grieued with that which they want, for the inriching and furnishing of their soules; then ioyous in that which they haue attained. And that he on the other side, which thinketh of himselfe, either that he is already forward enough; or that a little more
knowledge, zeale, or holinesse will serue the turne: Such a man hath vndoubtedly no true zeale, no true holinesse, no sound knowledge or Religion at all. For it is but a seeming, & shew of Religion, where there is no care of increasing it. Many there are at this day (the Lord knoweth) of whom it may truely be said, that they are growne to be old and ancient men and women in yeeres; but yet remaine very children in knowledge and vnderstanding of heauenly matters: Neere vnto death, and so to the saluation of their soules, (as a man would thinke▪) when their age is considered, but very farre from the same, doe they plainely shew themselues to be, when their Religion, and godlinesse, and the fruits of their loue to the Preachers, and professors of the Gospell, bee duely examined, and regarded. And which is most lamentable to consider, as none commonly are more ignorant, then the elder sort of men and women: so, none more carelesse of instruction, nor any more vnapt, or vnwilling to be taught.

I haue knowne many in this Congregation, euen from their childhood; and among the rest, some of them twenty
yeeres, some ten, some more, and some lesse: In all which space, as they cannot deny but that they haue had sufficient time: So may I boldly, and with good conscience (I praise God) affirme, that they haue had meanes in some good measure to be nourished in the way of saluation, and to be builded vp towards Gods Kingdome, in the sanctifying graces of his blessed Spirit. But can it bee said withall, that they haue receiued this nourishment, and are so builded vp? It were surely a blessed and comfortable thing, if this might truely be so verified, and affirmed: And that the contrary were not rather too apparant, to our worthy shame, and reproofe. Many of vs are growne in wealth, but not in Religion; growne in yeeres, but not in grace. Nothing at all nearer, but rather much further from saluation, then so long agoe; yea, I say, then ten, or twenty yeeres since. Stepping a foot forward (as it were) some Sabbath dayes when they list to come to ye Church, and to lend an eare to the hearing of Gods Word: but running much faster from it, euen the greatest part of those very daies, besides all the other dayes of the weekes
following: It being out of doubt, that one little sleepe, or sluggish fit, in the time of preaching, and Prayer; one vaine Oath, the cherishing of one corrupt affection, be it either to anger, malice, incontinency, oppression, &c. the exercise of the tongue in one vaine word, bee it in swearing, lying, mocking, slandering, and the like: Any one of these (I say) or any such like, set a man much further backe in the way of saluation, then all the labour and paines that a Minister of Christ can take in preaching, exhortation, and doctrine will be able to helpe him forward againe in many dayes. The way to Heauen is an ascent, and a going vpwards; but this is a declining and a going downewards. And easily (as wee know) may a man goe much further downe a steepe Hill in the space of one houre, then hee shall be able to recouer againe in many houres, though he sweat, and take neuer so much paines to doe it.

But now to make an end of this point. As the Papists are euidently discouered to haue hard hearts, and to bee deadly enemies to the saluation of Gods people, in denying them the Bread of Life, without
which, there can be nothing but fearfull death. And as this which hath been spoken, bewrayeth the wretched, and miserable condition of all the rest: So, it teacheth vs, not onely to glorifie God, and to praise his Name, for vouchsafing vs the pure preaching, and free passage of his Word, with freedome to heare it, to learne it, and to make profession of it: but also to pray, and beseech him, for the gracious assistance of his blessed Spirit, together with the Ministerie and preaching of it, that so wee may not enioy so great a grace in vaine, but take the opportunitie (whiles hee in mercy doth vouchsafe it) to bee builded vp from one degree of holinesse to another, euen vntill we become perfect members of Iesus Christ, and enioy eternall life.

div.head: Quest. 2. What is Christian Religion?
div.p: Answ. Christian Religion consisteth in a true, & sincere acknowledging of that truth, which is according to godlinesse, Tit. 1.1.2. Pet. 1.3. 1. Tim. 6.3.

div.head: EXPOSITION.
div.p:
THis terme, or phrase of speech, Religion, is deriued from a word which signifieth to forsake, or leaue off, because thereby wee leaue and forsake false gods, all errours, and earthly desires, and seeke after the True God, after truth, and heauenly things. It signifieth a friendship, a knitting, a vnity or league, with the true, and euerlasting God. And sometimes it is set forth also by the name of Marriage, or Wedlocke. For as they that are confederate, are vnited together, and made one by a League, or Couenant: so God and Man are knit together by Religion. And as by marriage, the Husband, and the Wife, are made one body: so by Religion we are knit into a spirituall body with God, and with the Sonne of God, as with our Bridegroome, and Head. Whereupon it followeth,
that whosoeuer are not truely religious, they haue no fellowship at all with God; they are no members of Iesus Christ; they are not sealed to eternall life, but Truce-breakers, disloyall, and infamous before the face of God. Secondly, when wee speake of Christian Religion, wee meane the Religion of Iesus Christ. For the word Christian, is deriued from Christ, of whom wee haue the name of Christians, being vnseparably knit vnto him, by true Faith, and being members of that body, whereof he is the Head.

But to passe from the meaning of the words, vnto the matter. Christian Religion consisteth in a true, and sincere acknowledging of that truth, &c. In these words where it is said not simply, that Christian Religion consisteth in the knowledge, but in the acknowledging, or confession of the Truth: And not in a bare, or verball, but in such a confession, or acknowledging as is sincere, and true: these two points are especially offered to our consideration. First, what euery true Christian must acknowledge, and make profession of: and secondly, how and after what manner the fame must be done.

As touching the first; Euery tongue ought to confesse to the glory of God, as the whole truth which he hath reuealed in his Word: so especially the faith, and hope, which we haue in Christ Iesus to eternall life: yea, euen the whole doctrine of that our faith and Religion, boldly, and publikely, as occasion is offered. In this sence doth the Apostle writing to the Hebrewes, chapter 3. call Christ Iesus the High Priest of our profession.
Heb. 3.1. Heb. 10.23 & cha. 13, 15. And after, chapter 10. Let vs hold fast the profession of our Faith without wauering. And chap. 13. Let vs by him offer the sacrifice of praise alwayes to God, that is, the fruit of the lips which confesse his Name. Herein we haue the examples of the Apostles, Act. 4.8, 9. &c. chap. 5.30. Act. 24.14, 15. 1. Tim. 6.12, 13. Acts 4. and of Paul before Felix, chapter 24. Of Timothy, as is testified to his commendation, 1. Tim. 6. Yea, euen of our Lord Iesus Christ himselfe, who vnder Pontius Pilate witnessed a good confession. Now although all these, as a cloud of Witnesses may seeme suffcient to confirme vs in the truth of this point; yet being (as it is) a matter of great importance. and most necessary for our times, to be thorowly considered, & vrged to mens consciences: • will
labour to make it yet more apparant, by some speciall reasons.

First, the confession of our Faith, and Reason 1 hope in Christ Iesus, hath a great promise of a rich reward, ioyned with it, and added vnto it; whereas the starting backe from it, hath on the contrary a grieuous curse. As both parts hereof are plaine, in the words of our Sauiour, Math. 10.
Math. 10.32, 33. Whosoeuer shall confesse mee before men, him will I also confesse before my Father which is in Heauen; and whosoeuer shall deny me before men, him will I also deny before my Father which is in Heauen. And to be denied of Christ, before his Father: what is it else, but to bee vtterly cast out of his presence, and from all partaking of his grace, and fauour.

Secondly, this confession is a necessarie Reason 2 fruit, and consequence of Faith. For where true Faith is in the heart, there will follow confession with the mouth, as 2. Cor. 4. 2. Cor. 4.13. Because (saith the Apostle) wee haue the same Spirit of Faith, according as it is written; I beleeued, and therefore haue I spoken: We also beleeue, and therefore speake. Hee that is either afraid, or ashamed to confesse Christ and his Gospell
with the mouth: such a one vndoubtedly, hath not the true Faith of Christ in his heart. If thou shalt confesse the Lord Iesus with thy mouth, (saith the Apostle, Rom. 10
Rom. 10.9, 10.) and beleeue in thy heart, that God raised him from the dead, thou shalt be saued. For with the heart, man beleeueth vnto righteousnesse; and with the mouth, man confesseth to saluation.

Againe, how acceptable a thing it is in the sight of God; what an excellent branch Reason 3 of true Christianity; how necessary for the sealing and assurance of our saluation, to adioyne a sincere confession of the mouth, with a faithfull beleeuing of the heart. It is further confirmed, Psal. 116.
Psal. 116.10. I beleeued (saith the Prophet) and therefore did I speake; meaning in way of confession, to the glory and praise of GOD. Hereunto belong also the notable confessions of Nathaniel, Ioh. 1.
Ioh. 1.49. Rabbi, thou art the Sonne of GOD, thou art that King of Israel. Of Peter, Mathew 16.
Mat. 16.16 in the name of all the Disciples, Thou art the Christ, that Son of the liuing God. And Ioh. 6.
Joh. 6 68, 69. Lord, to whom shall we go? Thou hast the words of eternall life. 1. Ioh. 4.15. And we beleeue, & know, that thou art that Christ, that Sonne of the liuing
God, 1. Ioh. 4. And whosoeuer confesseth, that Iesus is the Son of God, in him dwelleth God, & he in God. Thus you sée some reasons, wherfore euery true Christian must confesse, & acknowledge that truth, which is according to godlinesse: Yea, and how plentiful the Scripture is, in describing & setting forth the notable confessions of the Saints and seruants of God, after their Calling, and conuersation to the Faith of Christ. Whereby the truth of this point is cleerely confirmed, that herein we haue a notable argument, that wee are true Christians indeed, and doe vndoubtedly belong to eternall life: if we haue so profited by the preaching of the Gospell, as that together with the planting, and establishing of a true, & liuely faith in Christ Iesus, to the free, and particular forgiuenesse of our sinnes, to our iustification, and saluation: We finde our selues able in some acceptable measure, and zealous, and willing according to our measure, to make profession hereof, without wauering, and without being ashamed of the same. Whereas on the contrary, how great a fault, and how vntolerable an vnthankefulnesse it is, either not to know
how to make this confession, or to deny it, or to be ashamed of it: besides the expresse words of our Sauiour himselfe, Math. 10. which I alledged before: This is further manifest, 2. Tim. 2. 2. Tim. 2.12. If we deny him, he will also deny vs.
Now let vs consider what profitable vses may be made of this.

Vse 1 First, wee may see by that which hath been spoken, that wee are not left at our owne liberty, whether wee will make a solemne, and sound profession of the Gospell, and Religion of Christ, or no, no more then it is at our owne choice, whether wee will beleeue, or no; or whether wee will bee saued, or not. They that thinke the confession of the truth of the Gospell, and Religion of Iesus Christ, to be of no absolute necessitie, but a thing indifferent, whether it be done or no; such are no better then very Libertines, that would liue as they lust, and who indeede make no conscience of any Religion at all.
Vse 2 Secondly, we see that it is not inough for vs not to deny Christ, & the Gospell, but it is required of vs, that wee confesse him and his truth, euen before men.

Let vs know, that confession, and saluation,
must goe together: If we wait for the one, we must expresse the other. If confession goe before, we may build surely, and ground our selues strongly vpon the promise of Christ, that the saluation of our soules shall follow after, and that no man shall bee able to take it from vs. This made the Apostle say, 2. Tim. 1. 2. Tim. 1.12 For this cause I suffer those things, but I am not ashamed, for I know whom I haue beleeued: and I am perswaded he is able to keep that which I haue committed vnto him against that day.

Thirdly, it is required of vs, that we Vse 3 shew our selues ready, and absolute, to giue a reckoning of our Faith, and hope; of our profession, and Religion, whensoeuer we shall be thereunto required. For it is greatly to the honour of God, when his seruants prepare themselues to set forth his truth, and are not afraid of the threatnings of such as are the enemies thereof. And this is that which the Apostle Peter teacheth, 1. Epist. 3. 1. Pet. 3.15. Sanctifie the Lord in your hearts, and bee ready alwayes to giue an answere to euery man that asketh you a reason of the hope that is in you, with meeknesse, and reuerence.

Vse 4 Fourthly: if it be a duty that lyeth vpon vs, to make profession of our Faith & Religion: It is then of necessitie that we labour to know the doctrine of Faith, and the truth of Religion. For profession of the Faith, presupposeth a knowledge of the faith. For how can we confesse that which wee know not? or manifest that to others, whereof wee are ignorant our selues?

Vse 5 And lastly: seeing it is a duty to open our mouthes for the confession of his Name, who hath called vs to the knowledge of his truth: it standeth vs vpon to pray for the Spirit of strength & courage, that wee may be able to stand in the time of danger. For it is not in all that know, and acknowledge the truth in their hearts, to auouch it, & to maintaine it, to confesse it, and to stand to it: but this is onely in such as haue receiued, the strengthening power, and grace of Christ. And therefore notably saith the Apostle of himselfe, Phil. 4.
Phil. 4.13. I am able to doe all things through the helpe of Christ who strengtheneth me. And so prayeth he for the Colossians, chapter 1.
Col. 1.11. that they might bee strengthened through the glorious power of Christ.

This may suffice to bee spoken in this place concerning confession, or acknowledging of the truth. In the handling whereof I haue been the more large; not onely because it is an excellent branch of true Christianity, a notable argument of election, and a principall part of that obedience which the Lord requireth at our hands: but also in that, whereas at this day, it should of euery one bee taken vp, and that with earnestnesse, and delight: It is of the greatest part, either neglected, & euen reiected, as a matter of no weight, or as a thing too base for mens estate, and countenance in the world: or else contemned, scorned, and derided, as a matter most odious, foolish, and vaine. Such ignorant Atheists, and godlesse persons, there are too many at this day, (notwithstanding the cleere light of the glorious Gospell of Iesus Christ shining amongst vs,) that will not sticke to condemne that with the reproachfull termes of new-fanglenesse, precisenesse, &c. and to make a by-word, & a scoffing terme of that, which the Lord so highly commendeth; yea, and earnestly requireth (vnder the paine of condemnation) of euery one that belongeth
vnto him. Deadly also to hate, disgrace, and despight those (to the vttermost they may) that professe Christ, and his Gospell; yea, euen in regard of their profession. For which (if they had any grace in their hearts) they would thinke the better of them, glorifie, and praise God for them, and settle themselues to ioyne together with them, in a sweet harmony, and sound consent. But as all such do hereby plainely discouer of what spirit they are: and that being (by their owne confession) no professors themselues of Christs Gospell; it is not the Spirit of Christ, but the spirit of Satan, that ruleth and raigneth in their hearts, and causeth them to vtter such blasphemy with their mouthes: So, must we learne hereby, not to bee discouraged, but to hold fast the profession of the glorious Gospel of Iesus Christ, without wauering: Patiently in regard thereof passing through honour, and dishonour, through euill report, and good report, not being dismayed, how odious and contemptible soeuer it bee in the world: and what trouble, afflictions, or persecutions, may come vpon vs, for well discharging our consciences in this
behalfe: Saying euery one with the Apostle, Rom. 1.
Rom. 1.16. I am not ashamed of the Gospell of Christ: it is the power of God to saluation. And with the Prophet Dauid, Psalme 119.
Psa. 119.46 I will testifie of thy Statutes, euen before Kings, and will not be ashamed.

div.head: The second Branch.
div.p:
Hauing spoken at large, of the acknowledging, or confession of the truth: Now, as touching the second part of this definition, and to make it also as plaine, that Christian Religion consisteth not in a verball, but in a true, and sincere confession, or acknowledging of the truth: That is is not inough to professe Christ, and his Gospell, and to be sound, and resolute in the matter but that the manner also must be duely respected, that it bee sincere, vpright, vnfained, and free from all hypocrisie, and dissimulation: Let vs obserue, and know, that such professors only haue euermore been accepted, and approued of God. There haue alwayes beene two sorts of such, as haue made profession of the truth: the profession of the one sort, consisting onely in words, and outward shewes: but the profession of the other, not onely outward, but proceeding from a
faithfull, and sincere affection. Of both these sorts, had our Lord Iesus Christ experience, Iohn 6. Some of the Iewes followed him from place to place, with honest, and good hearts, vnfainedly desiring to be taught, and instructed by him in the way of saluation; not murmuring when they heard any thing deliuered which they vnderstood not; nor taking any occasion to be so offended, as to forsake, and giue him ouer: but they constantly cleaued vnto him, and continued with him, as with the Sonne of God, and the onely Lord of life, and saluation.

But another sort, and as it is very probable, the greater part followed him, with more regard of their bellies, then of their soules, hoping, that hee would haue alwayes fed them to the full, and plentifully furnished them with all manner of earthly good things, without any care, or paines on their behalfe. But when they saw their expectation deceiued, Ioh. 6.26, 27, &c. & heard Christ reproue such carnall affections, and exhort them to labour, not for the meat which perisheth, but for the meat which endureth to eternall life: then they began to murmure and grudge, and to bee so highly offended
at him, and with his doctrine, as in great displeasure, and despight, vtterly to forsake, and giue him euer. In Gen. 4.
Gen. 4.4. it is plainely recorded, that when there were but foure persons, which worshipped the True God, externally witnessing their Religion, in offering the first fruits of the Sheepe, and of the ground: yet one of them, namely Cain, was a very hypocrite: his profession of Religion, and worship, was onely outward, and therefore reiected of the Lord: but Abel his sacrifice and seruice, was not onely outward, but proceeding from a faithfull, and sincere heart. According as Heb. 11.
Heb. 11.4. the Holy Ghost thus testifieth to his notable commendation: By faith Abel offred vnto God, a greater sacrifice then Cain, by the which faith he obtained witnes that he was righteous. In the Families of Abraham, and Isaac; Isaac and Ismael; Iacob and Esau receiued circumcision alike, which was then the externall signe of their profession; by reason whereof, they were all accounted the worshippers, and seruants of God: but yet onely Isaac and Iacob were true worshippers, and faithfull seruants, as Heb. 11. & 12.
Heb. 11.18. cha. 12.16. In Psalme 50. the Lord
himselfe expostulateth the matter, & with great authoritie reasoneth with such, whose religion is only in words, and outward shewes, Psa. 50.16, 17.23. saying, What hast thou to doe, to declare mine Ordinance, that thou shouldest take my Couenant in thy mouth, seeing thou hatest to be reformed, and hast cast my words behinde thee? But vnto the other, he speaketh thus, Hee that offereth praise, shall glorifie mee: and to him that disposeth his way aright, will I shew the saluation of God.

For the further description also of both these sorts of professors, belong the Parables which Christ vseth in the Gospell, of the Field, Floore, & of the Net: as Mat. 13.
Mat. 13.24 &c. &c. For as in a Field that is sowne, there comes vp not onely good Corne, but Thistles, and other weeds: and in a threshing Floore there is not onely pure wheat, but also chaffe: and as in a Net, that is cast into the water, there comes vp not onely good things, but also bad: So in the visible Church, among such as professe the Gospell, there are not onely such as are sincere, & faithful, but hypocrites also, and faithlesse worshippers, and seruers of God: Not onely such as with good consciences,
pure hearts, and faith vnfained, doe serue and obey the Lord: but such also, as are euen Reprobate to euery good worke, and whose end is to bee cast eternally from the presence of God, and to be burnt as chaffe in the fearefull furnace of his indignation and wrath.
Thus it being manifest, that there haue alwayes beene these two sorts of professors: Now let vs more particularly examine their seuerall properties; and how herein they differ one from another.

The first sort doe professe Christ, and his Gospell, but not in truth and sin • erity: They haue onely a shew of true Religion and godlinesse, being void of al faithfull obedience towards God. But the Religion of the other sort is in all goodnesse, righteousnesse, and truth, they still endeuouring to practise, and performe in the whole course of their conuersation, whatsoeuer they know and professe, according to the will and Word of God. They content not themselues in saying, Lord, Lord: we are Christians; wee are Protestants; and we professe the Gospel: but they haue a care, and conscience to amend their liues, and to bee reformed in that
which is amisse: Whose knowledge is not fruitlesse, nor their faith dead, but they are zealously inflamed to walke according to their knowledge, and to approue their faith to be liuely, with the liuely fruits of holinesse, and righteousnesse. As the Hypocrites greatest care is to be well esteemed of among men: So, the true Christian, how he may be well approued of in the sight of God. As the one sort work their saluation securely, coldly, and carelessely: So, the other in feare and trembling, as they are taught by the Apostle, Phil. 2.
Phil. 2.12. & cha. 3.13, 14. striuing against the corrupt lusts, and motions of their hearts; and with the Apostle, chapter 3. forgetting that which is behind, and endeuouring themselues vnto that which is before, yea, following hard towards for the price of the high Calling of God in Iesus Christ. Againe, as the Hypocrite hath no settled resolution, in life and death to obey the truth, and will of God; but is mutable, wauering, and vnconstant in all his wayes: the other cleane contrariwise, with full purpose of heart, according to the exhortation of Paul, and Barnabas, Acts 11.
Act. 11.23. doe cleaue vnto the Lord. The Hypocrite will oftentimes
abstaine from the grosest sinnes, & speake against such as are defiled with them: but then neuer are so touched with the sight and feeling of their own sinnes, as to cry out with the Apostle, Rom. 7.
Rom. 7.24 O wretched man that I am, who shall deliuer mee from this body of death? They will not sticke sometimes to doe that which is necessary, and commendable; but they neuer do any thing with such affections as Gods Children doe, who are allured with the mercy of God, and loue of Christ: as Psal. 130.
Psal. 130.4. But mercy is with thee, that thou maist be feared. And as the Apostle saith of himselfe, and of all the rest of the faithfull, 2. Cor. 9. 2. Cor. 9.14. The loue of Christ constraineth vs, &c. Many more particulars might bee remembred to manifest this difference betwixt the true-hearted Christian, and the carnal Gospeller, or counterfet Professor. But by this we may cleerely see, and discerne, that it is no sufficient argument to proue any man to bee a good Christian, and in the state of grace, and saluation, because he comes to the Church, heares the Word, receiues the Sacrament, and will say that he is no Papist, &c. For all this, and much more, did the Iewes in time
past, and yet, as the Apostle teacheth, Rom. 2.
Rom. 2.28. were but Iewes outward: And so, all this, and much more may wee doe at this day, and yet be but Christians outward: we may come to the Church, heare the Word, receiue the Sacraments, professe the Religion established, and yet bee but Hypocrites. And the Reasons are: First, because the promises of Gods Reason 1 grace, and mercy in Christ, are not tyed to such outward circumstances, and obseruations, but belong onely to such as are elected, and humbled by Gods Spirit, to walke in the obedience of his good will. Reason 2 And secondly, because God abhorreth all halting in his seruice, and will not accept the hart by halues, nor be serued by piecemeale, as Saul did, 1. Sam. 15. 1. Sam. 15.15, &c. but hee will haue the whole heart to bee giuen vnto him, as that which hee especially respecteth, and aimeth at. And therefore Pro. 23.
Pro. 23.26. My sonne, giue mee thy heart, and let thy eyes delight in my wayes.

Vse 1 And now to make some vse of this. First we see by that which hath been spoken, that to approoue our selues good Christians, wee must not content our selues with outward circumstances in Religion:
but hauing a reuerend feare of the Lords Maiesty imprinted in our hearts, and inwardly in our soules, respecting his blessed will, and faithfully remembring his vnmeasurable loue, and tender kindnesse towards vs in Christ Iesus: Wee must performe all outward circumstances, in comming to the Church, in hearing the Word, &c. as fruits of our true, and inward zeale to Gods glory, and as testimonies of our obedience, and thankefulnesse to his Maiesty, in regard of his manifold mercies towards vs, and then shall we be accepted in them, and in euery of them. Whereas, if the heart and minde bee not sincere and sound, and do not directly aime at Gods glory, and at the obedience of his commandements, though we be neuer so forward in all outward respects: yet shall we in no measure be accepted, but vtterly reiected of him. He will say vnto vs, as he said vnto the Iewes, Esay 1.
Esay 1.12. Who required this at your hands, to tread in my Courts? For as the Apostle saith of Circumcision, so it is true of Christiā Religion, that it is especially within, in the heart and in the Spirit: the glory, and praise thereof being not of men, but of God, Rom. 2.
Rom. 2.29.

They that content themselues with a bare profession of Religion, hauing no care, nor conscience withall, to glorifie God, and to s • ale the assurance of their owne saluation in the sound fruits, and effects of it: All such are vtterly vnworthy the name, and Title of Christians; the Doctrine of the Gospell cannot be said to haue taken root in their hearts: the fruits which proceed from them, are not ye fruits thereof, planted in their hearts by Gods Spirit: but the fruits and effects of their infidelity and hardnes of heart, ingrafted in them by the spirit of Satan, as a sure Seale of their iust condemnation. According as of this difference, speaketh our Lord Iesus Christ himselfe, Math. 7.
Math. 7.21. Not euery one that saith vnto me, Lord, Lord, shall enter into the Kingdome of Heauen: but he that doth the wil of my Father, which is in Heauen. And, Not the hearers of the Law (saith Saint Paul, Rom. 2.
Rom 2.13.) are iust before God, but the doers of the Law shall be iustified. And therefore, Iam. 1.
Iam. 1.22. Bee ye doers of the Word, and not hearers onely, deceiuing your owne selues. Hereunto also appertain the words of our Lord Iesus Christ vnto his Disciple, Luke 6.
Luke 6.46. Why
call ye me Lord, Lord, and doe not the things which I say? Plainely thereby teaching, that such as professe themselues to be the seruants of Christ, must haue an holy desire and endeuour, to walke in the obedience of his Commandements; or else wil he vtterly disclaime, and disallow all their profession, and protestations of religion, and doing him seruice, as but meere hypocrisie, and words of lyes. And trust not in lying words (saith the Lord, Ier. 7.
Ier. 7.4.) saying, The Temple of the Lord, The Temple of the Lord; this is the Temple of the Lord.

Seeing the heart in truth and sinceritie, Vse 2 must bee ioyned with the mouth, in word, and profession: it highly standeth vs vpon to pray vnto God, for a right reformation of our hearts. For, euen as the water that floweth out of a corrupt fountaine, must of necessitie be vnsauoury, and vnwholsome: so as long as the heart and minde, from whence all the actions of mans life proceede, doth remaine corrupt, and vnsound, it is vtterly vnpossible to performe any thing that is holy and pure before the Lord. Rightly therefore doth the Apostle, Ro. 12. exhort the faithfull,
that to the end they may offer their bodies a liuing sacrifice,
Ro. 12.1, 2. holy, and acceptable vnto GOD, they should beginne at the change of their minde: Be ye changed (saith he) by the renuing of your minde. For as when a man intendeth to haue a fruitfull increase, either of Corne, or of any other commodity: hee will first apply himselfe, to cleere, and roote out of his Land, all euill Weeds, Brambles, and Bryers, that may hinder the growth of it: so, to the end wee may beare fruit vnto God, in such an holy, and religious conuersation, both concerning his Maiestie, and concerning one another, as his name may be effectually glorified in these our mortall bodies: We must first be clensed of all corrupt, and naughty affections, inclinations, and lusts, which are as so many brambles, and hurtfull weeds in our hearts, and minds; and which, vnlesse they be plucked vp by the rootes, will so hinder, and choke all the motions of Gods grace, & so allure vs to the vanities of this world, that we shal neuer be able to perform any holy obedience vnto ye Lord. This doth our Lord Iesus Christ confirme, Math. 6.
Math. 6.2 • . If the light that is in thee,
bee darknesse, how great is that darknesse? The heart, the minde, and vnderstanding of man, ought to be light, and shining, euen as at the first it was so created; but by originall sinne, it is become the seat, cause, and fountaine of all darknes, & of all manner of sins that are continually committed against both God, and Man. And now, if the heart, and minde, which as a light and bright burning Candle, should direct, and gouerne all our actions, and enterprises: if that be darknesse: if that bee corrupt, defiled, and disordered: how great (as Christ saith) is that darknesse? No maruell is it then, though men doe most licentiously wallow in all kinde of vngodlinesse and sensualitie. For this cause most notably, Ephes. 4.
Ephes. 4.18, 22. &c. doth the Apostle exhort the faithfull, to cast off, concerning the conuersation in time past, the old man: and put on the new man, which after God is created in righteousnesse, and true holinesse. Whereby hee plainely sheweth, that it is of necessitie, that wee haue the affections, and dispositions of our hearts and mindes cleane altered, and transformed; to will, to desire, and doe that which is good and holy in the
sight of God; or else it is vtterly vnpossible, to haue any comfortable assurance that we belong to eternall life. But now, this so great a change and alteration in the heart and minde, is no worke of nature:1. Cor. 2.14. For the naturall man perceiueth not the things that are of Gods Spirit: but it is a speciall worke of Gods grace, and therefore by faithfull and feruent prayer, to bee sought at his hands. For vnlesse hee change our hearts, wash the filthinesse of our soules, renue our minds, regen • rate our affections, sanctifie vs vnto holinesse, and of carnall men, make vs spiritually minded; we shall alwayes remaine corrupt, prophane, vncleane, and abominable: And no vncleane, or abominable thing, shall enter into the Kingdome of God; as it is expressely pronounced, Reu. 21.
Reu. 21.27.

div.head: Que. 3. What doth that truth teach vs?
div.p: Answ. What wee are to know, and beleeue concerning God; and what to know, and beleeue, concerning our selues, Ier. 9.23, 24. Io. 17.3. Col. 2.13, 14, 15.

ALthough very high, and exquisite is the true knowledge, & very many the points and principall branches of our Christian Religion, wherein, euery one that looketh to be saued by the Death of Christ, ought soundly to bee grounded, and established: yet may they all be comprehended, and knit vp in these two: to know God, and to know our selues. Insomuch, that if we know God truely, and as he ought to be knowne: and on the other side know our selues, as wee ought to know our selues: then haue we attained to an excellent measure of true Christian knowledge: whereas contrariwise, if wee be without this knowledge of God, and of our selues, what shew soeuer we make in the world, and what opinion soeuer we haue of our selues: yet
can wee haue no true peace of conscience, nor sound ioy in the holy Ghost: wee can haue no assurance that wee are right Christians, but euen strangers from the Couenant of Grace, who haue no inheritance among the Saints. But if any, at the hearing of this, be ready to imagine that this is an easie knowledge, and may soone be attained: let not such deceiue themselues, but seriously consider, and vnderstand, that whereas our Christian Religion is said to consist in the true knowledge of God, and of our selues: the meaning is not, that it is sufficient for a Christian man to know, that there is a God; but (as the Prophet Ieremy saith, he must know, and vnderstand, that the Lord is God: that hee sheweth mercy; and how, for what cause, and to whom hee sheweth mercy: that hee worketh righteousnesse, and executeth iudgement: and how, and for what cause, he doth these things in the earth. We must know him to be our onely True God and Iesus Christ whom hee hath sent, to be our alone Sauiour, and Redeemer. Again, concerning our selues, it is not inough to know, that wee are creatures created by God, but wee must
know, how, by what meanes, and so what end we were created, in what estate wee remaine, and in what estate we shall continue, in respect of saluation, before God. It is not then so easie a matter to haue this knowledge in substance and truth, as many are apt to thinke, the whole summe of true wisedome, and godlinesse, beeing comprehended in it. We that are the Ministers, and preachers of the Gospell, apply all our study about this knowledge, and yet are neuer able to attaine the height, and fulnesse of it.1. Cor 13.9. When we haue done all we can, yet wee still know but in part, and prophesie but in part: And therfore how farre the common and generall multitude, which little, or neuer study vpon she matter, and little profit by that which is taught them: how farre (I say) they must of necessity be, from a full, and sufficient measure of vnderstanding herein, euery mans conscience cannot but assure him. When wee thinke vpon God, we see, that infinite are the things, which may sooner be sought, and inquired, concerning the knowledge of him, then either found out, or plainely expounded. For which cause, we must neuer speake, nor
thinke of him, without great reuerence, and Religion. And to the end we may doe so, wee must alwayes consider on the one side, how great, and vnsearchable his Maiesty is; and what worship, feare, and seruice is due vnto him. And on the other side, how vile, and abiect our owne estate and condition is; how weake, or rather how corrupt, and peruerse iudgement we are, especially in those things that do concerne diuine and spirituall vnderstanding. For this is the right way to true Christian wisedome, and knowledge. And these two parts of it are so linked and knit together with a mutuall knot, that which of them goeth before, or ingendreth the other, it is a hard matter to discusse. Reason 1 For whosoeuer knoweth not God, he cannot possibly know himselfe; And whosoeuer knoweth not himselfe, hee cannot possibly know God. And such a one, as is ignorant both of the knowledge of God, and of himselfe, he is ignorant of all happinesse, that may any way concerne himselfe; his estate is most miserable, what shew so euer to the contrary, he may carry in the world, to bleare the eyes of men.

Againe, as euery one is by the knowledge Reason 2 of himselfe, and his owne misery, not onely pricked forward to seeke God, but led, as it were, by the hand, to finde him out: so is it also certaine, that a man neuer commeth to the knowledge of himselfe, vnlesse hee hath first beheld the face of God, and from the beholding thereof, doe descend to the consideration of himselfe. For such is the pride, that is naturally planted in vs, that wee alwayes thinke our selues to bee righteous, wise, and holy inough, vntill such time, as wee be manifestly conuinced of our owne vnrighteousnesse, filthinesse, and vncleanenesse: the which is done, not by looking vpon our selues onely; but vpon the purity also, and holinesse that is in God, which is the rule, whereby this iudgement is to be tryed. For in as much as we are naturally inclined to hypocrisie, a certaine vaine resemblance of righteousnes doth sufficiently content vs, in stead of true righteousnes indeed.
