So long as we looke no further then the earth, we wonderfully please, and sweetly flatter our selues, in our owne wisedome, power, & strength; but if wee once begin to raise vp our
thoughts to God, and to consider what a one he is, and how exact is the perfection of his righteousnes, wisedome, & power, after the rule whereof we ought to be framed: then, that which before did please vs in our selues with a false pretence of righteousnes, shall become loathsome vnto vs, as very hainous wickednesse: that which did maruellously deceiue vs vnder the colour of wisedome, shall then stinke before vs as extreme folly: that which did beare the face of strength, shall be proued to be most miserable weakenesse: So slenderly doth that which is good in our eyes, answere in proportion, the excellent purenesse that is in God.

Much more might be added to amplifie this: but we shal haue occasion to consider further of it, in the next point. In the meane season, you may see by this already deliuered, how rightly the summe of Christian Religion, is said to consist in the knowledge of God, and of our selues.

For as the true knowledge of God doth rightly bring sauing health; and as the same aboundantly sufficeth to sanctification, and saluation to all faithfull Christians: And againe, as without this
knowledge, all other knowledge is nothing worth. It being euen eternall life, as Christ himselfe affirmeth, thus to know God: euen so ye knowledge of our selues, and of our owne miseries, is necessarie to the obtaining of inestimable comfort and consolation. And as to bee ignorant of God, is a damnable ignorance: so also not to know our owne wretchednesse, is a blindnesse most miserable.

Let vs therefore bee zealous in prayer continually vnto God, Vse. that through his grace, wee may attaine to the true knowledge of both these points: And let vs willingly suffer our selues to be instructed in them, by the diligent hearing of the Word of God preached, by reading the Scriptures, with such godly and learned Expositions, as are made thereof: as also by often conference with the Minister, and such others as may be able to informe and helpe vs. For if wee know not our owne misery, and the greatnesse thereof, wee cannot know the greatnesse of Gods mercy, neither can we desire him to deliuer vs from the greatnesse of our sinnes. And if we doe not desire deliuerance from our wretchednesse, it is not possible that
we should obtaine it, because God hath promised it, onely to them that seeke it: As Mat. 7. Math. 7.7. Aske, and it shall be giuen you; Seeke, and ye shall finde; Knocke, and it shall be opened vnto you. Also before chap. 5. Chap. 5.6. Blessed are they, that hunger and thirst after righteousnes; for they shall bee satisfied. And againe, chapter 11. Cha. 11.28. Come vnto mee, all ye that are weary, and laden, and I will ease you.

div.head: Quest. 4. What is God?
div.p: Answ. God is a Spirit, which is most simple, most holy, eternall, infinite, of inestimable glory, maiestie, and power, all-sufficient, onely wise, onely good, most iust, most mercifull, and therefore one.

div.head: EXPOSITION.
div.p:
BEfore I enter into the particular branches of the description: Séeing that not onely the naturall man, (as the Apostle teacheth, 1. Cor. 2.1. Cor. 2.14.) but euen hee also that is most spirituall, and hath attained to a most exquisite measure of perfection, neither hath, nor can
comprehend those things with a cleere and absolute knowledge, that do concerne the diuine Maiesty, which is so cloathed with such an incomprehensible brightnes, and glory, as cannot be expressed with all mans wisedome. And yet, notwithstanding, such is our estate and condition, who are mortall men liuing in this world, that wee can bee ignorant of nothing, with greater danger: forasmuch as to this end we were created, and are called to heauenly grace; that we should know, acknowledge, worship, feare, serue, and glorifie him. For this cause, not grounding any opinion vpon mens determinations, or weake definitions, (lest wee worship the inuentions of our own hearts, and follow the toyes of foolish braines:) but that we may speake rightly, iudge truely, and to the honour of his high and heauenly Maiesty: Let this alwaies stand with vs for a perpetuall rule, that God cannot bee rightly knowne, but by his Word; and that if wee curiously search, and inquire further of him then the Scriptures doe teach, we are worthy to be blinded, and punished for ouer-great presumptiō. We may reade, Exod. 19. Exod. 19.9.12. how that before that
singular and notable communication wherein the Lord God in the Mount of Sinai talked with Moses, in the hearing of the people of Israel; hee said vnto him: Thou shalt set marks vnto the people round about the Mount, saying, Take heed to your selues, that ye goe not vp to the Mountaine, nor touch the border of it: whosoeuer toucheth the Mount, shall surely dye, &c. So, wee see, that it was present death to passe the bounds, and limits which were prescribed.

It is euident also in the Scripture, that the most entire, and dearest friends of God stood amazed, and trembling, as often as God in any outward shew, of his owne accord, did offer himselfe vnto their sight. Examples of such dismaying wee haue, Iudges 13. Iudges 13.22. and Esay 6. Esay 6.5. and in diuers other places, as wee shall sée further hereafter. In some of which, this was a common saying, Wee shall dye, because the Lord hath appeared vnto vs. And therfore the History of Iob, to throw men downe, with the knowledge of their own folly, weakenesse, and vncleannesse, bringeth alwayes the principall proofe to conuince them, from the description of Gods
wisedome, strength, and purenesse. And that not without cause: For we see, Gen. 18. Gen. 18.27. how Abraham, the neerer that he came to behold the glory of God, the better did hee acknowledge himselfe to be dust and ashes. We may see also, 1. Kings 19.1. Reg. 19.13. how Elias could not abide his comming vnto him with vncouered face: and which we also reade of Moses, Exod. 3. Exod. 3.6. So terrible is the beholding of his Maiestie. And this is that which the Prophet Esay speaketh of, chapter 24. Esay 24.23. The Sunne shall blush, and the Moone shall bee abashed, when the Lord of Hosts shall raigne: that is to say, when hee displayeth his brightnesse, and bringeth it to our sight, in comparison thereof, the most brightest thing of all shall be darkened.

Many more examples and testimonies might be alledged: but this must alwaies stand firme, and certaine, that concerning God, those things that are of him, and in him, neither is the minde of man able to conceiue what they be; how great they be, nor of what fashion they are, neither can the eloquence of any mans mouth vtter words answerable to so great a Maiesty.

For if it could be conceiued in the mind, Reason 1
or vttered with the tongue; then would it be found lesse then the speech, and minde of man, wherein it is comprehended. Though we say all of him whatsoeuer we can, yet shall wee still rather name something of his, then himselfe. For as at the seeing of the brightnesse of the Sunne, the sight of our eyes doth so dazell, and wax dimme, that we cannot behold it cleerely: euen so is it with the sight of our mindes, in all our thoughts concerning God. Look how much wee endeuour our selues to comprehend the things of God: by so much are wee blinded in the light of our cogitations.

Reason 2 For what (I say againe) can fully or sufficiently be thought or spoken of him, that is aboue all loftinesse, higher then all height; deeper then all depth; lighter then all light; cleerer then all cleerenes; stronger then all strength; mightier then all might; wiser then all wisedome; and more better, iuster, and gentler, then all goodnesse, iustice, and gentlenesse? All kinde of vertues must needs be lesse then hee, that is the Father, and Fountain of them all. So that God may truely be said to be such a certaine Being, as vnto which nothing
may be compared. Notwithstanding, forasmuch as the Scripture, which is the Word of God, (applying it selfe to our weakenesse, and imperfections) doth minister vnto vs meanes, by termes, and phrases of speech, to bring vs to some such knowledge of God, as may suffice vs whiles we liue in this world: The Lord hauing therein so reuealed himselfe, that we may know, how truely to feare, worship, and serue him, according to his will, and vtterly withall, to expell and banish farre from vs, all idle, vaine, and foolish fancies, and cogitations of God, which are very ready to enter into the heads and hearts of naturall men. Wee will therefore, (as with feare and trembling, in regard of his high and excellent Maiesty: so with boldnes, and confidence, through his assistance, and in regard of this warrant and reuelation:) proceed now to the particular branches of that description, which I haue propounded: The Scripture affording sufficient testimony for the proofe of euery of them, as I haue partly shewed before, and as shall more fully appeare (God willing) in that which followeth.

div.head: God is a Spirit, Ioh. 4.24. 2. Cor. 3.17.
div.p:
Exposition.The word Spirit, is many wayes taken in the Scripture: but by this description, is the Lord God distinguished from all other Spirits. And the meaning of the word is, not onely that God is inuisible, according as it is said, Ioh. 1. Ioh. 1.18. No man hath seene God at any time: And 1. Tim. 6.1. Tim. 6.16 that hee onely hath immortalitie, and dwelleth in the light that none can attaine vnto, whom neuer man saw, neither can see: but also that by his nature, and substance, he is without a body; not like either man, or any other creature, in any shape, qualitie, or naturall proportion: And therefore said our Sauiour, Luke 24. Luke 24.39 Handle me, and see: for a Spirit hath not flesh and bones, as ye see me haue. Whereupon follow these two notes: First, that he is to be worshipped in Spirit and Truth; as our Lord Iesus Christ himselfe teacheth, Iohn 4. Ioh. 4.24. God is a Spirit, and they that worship him, must worship him in Spirit and Truth. Euery thing affecteth that which is according to its naturall inclination, and loatheth, and disliketh whatsoeuer is repugnant to the same. That which is earthly, delighteth in
things earthly, and not in heauenly; and that which is heauenly, delighteth in things heauenly, and not in earthly. So, if the Lord God did consist of a bodily, and corporall substance, then would he be delighted with outward, and bodily worship and seruice: but séeing hee is not bodily, but altogether spirituall, therefore neither doth he expect, neither can he possibly be pleased with externall shewes, the same being so contrary to his nature.

The second note is, that hee cannot be represented, or expressed, by any image or similitude whatsoeuer. For séeking hee is of such a glorious, and incomprehensible Maiestie, as cannot be sufficiently described by any eloquent tongue of man or Angell, how shall any thing made of gold, and siluer, of wood or stone, possibly doe it, hauing neither life nor mouing, nor any other thing resembling the true, eternall, and euerliuing God? To whom will you liken God (saith the Prophet Esay, ch. 40. Esay 40.18.) and what similitude will ye set vp to him? And Deut 4. Deut. 4.15, 16, &c.
Take therefore good heede to your selues, for ye saw no image, in the day that the Lord spake vnto you in Horeb, out of the middes of the fire, that you corrupt
not your selues to make you a grauen image, or representation of any figure, whether it be male or female, &c. Wee may sée also in diuers other places, how the Lord setteth his voyce against all counterfait shapes of him, denouncing them guilty of forsaking GOD, and of direct fighting against his glory, who couet to haue any visible forme of him: For that his Maiestie is defiled, when hee being without a body, is likened to a bodily matter; being inuisible, to a visible image; being a Spirit, to a thing without life; and being incomprehensible, to a lumpe of wood or stone, or any other such like thing: as Esay 42.44, &c.
Esay 42.8. Es • y 44.9, 10, 11. &c.

div.head: Which is most simple. Exod. 3.14. Ia. 1.17.
div.p:
Exposition.By this word, and terme of spéech, the eternall Essence of God is distinguished from all things that are, whether in heauen, or in earth: As if we should say, that God is such an eternall Essence, and Being, as is without all comparison, without all composition • , immutable, true, in all things like himselfe; I Am that I Am, said he to Moses, Exod. 3. Exod. 3.14. Also thou
shalt say to the children of Israel, I Am hath sent mee vnto you. Hée is that Being, to whom nothing is lacking, which in all things, and vnto all things, is sufficient to himselfe, who néedeth no mans ayde, yea, who alone hath all things that doe belong to the perfect felicity both of this life, and of the life to come, and which only, and alone can fill, and suffice all his people, and all his creatures.

div.head: Most holy, 1. Sam. 2.2. Leuit. 19.2. Reuel. 15.4.
div.p:
He is rightly said to be most holy,Exposition. not onely because naturally, and substantially he is so, and vnto whose Holinesse no Angels or Saints may bee compared in any measure at all, a God so holy, and pure, that he cannot abide the least sparke of iniquity, neither can any vncleannesse or vnrighteousnesse haue place with him, as Psal. 5. Psal. 5.4, 5. Thou art not a God that loueth wickednesse, neither shall euill dwell with thee: the vniust shall not stand in thy sight, thou hatest all them that worke iniquity: And 1. Sam. 2. There is none holy as the Lord: but also, because he is the fountain of all holinesse, sanctifying, purging, and
consecrating vs to himselfe, by his holy Spirit, and separating vs from all vncleannesse, that wee might serue him in holinesse and righteousnesse, all the dayes of our life.

div.head: Eternall. Psal. 90.1, 2. Rom. 16.26.
div.p:
Exposition.That is to say, of such a Being, as is without beginning, and without ending, as Psalm. 90. Psal. 90.2, 4 Before the mountaines were made, and before thou haddest formed the earth, and the world: euen from euerlasting to euerlasting thou art our God. And a little after, A thousand yeeres in thy sight, are as yesterday when it is past, and as a watch in the night. Also Psal. 102. Psal. 102.12, 26, 27. where he saith, that the heauens, and the earth shall perish, but the Lord God shall endure, they all shall waxe old as a garment, and as a vesture shalt thou change them, and they shall be changed, but thou art the same, and thy yeeres shall not faile. And before, But thou, O Lord, doest remaine for euer, and thy remembrance, from generation to generation. Hee is the same, that alwayes hee hath béene, not weakened by age, nor made féeble by length of yeeres, but is at this present, and shall be for euer, of the same
glory, and maiestie, power, and sufficiencie, for the effecting of whatsoeuer pleaseth him, as he was at the first. As again, Esay 41. Esa. 41.4. I the Lord am the first, and with the last I am the same. And Chap. 44.
Chap. 44.6. I am the first, and the last, and without mee there is no God. To this effect also Dan. 6. Dan. 6.26 and in many other places that might bee remembred. Let the dayes be neuer so many, that we can call to an account, and let vs multiply yeeres into the longest continuance, that in our thoughts wee may possibly comprehend, so as thousand thousands be before vs, and ten thousand thousands in our minde, yet is all this nothing in comparison of God, with whom, as the Apostle Peter saith, 2.2. Pet. 3.8. Epist. One day is as a thousand yeeres, and a thousand yeeres, as one day. And now, as the Lord as touching his Essence, and Being, is after this manner, eternall, and euerlasting, and so as neither by dayes, nor times, he is to be measured, and comprehended: so is the very same consideration to be had, of all the Essentiall qualities, and properties of his nature, as his wisedome, power, righteousnesse, truth, goodnesse and mercy, as besides the manifold testimonies, and authorities
of the Scripture: this is very cleare, in the sensible féeling, and continuall experience, and in the preseruation and gouernment of all the creatures vpon the face of the earth, to the very same end, for which at the first he created them. As also in the calling, and sanctifying of his Elect, and in his iudgements vpon the wicked, with infinite other particulars that might be remembred. Euery one plainely approuing, that the God that now is, is the same that was, and of whom there shall neuer be any end. As Reuel. 1. Reuel. 1.8. I am Alpha, and Omega, the beginning, and the ending, which is, and which was, and which is to come, euen the Almighty.

div.head: Infinite. Iob 11.7. Psalm. 139.7, &c. Ier. 23.23.24.
div.p:
Exposition.That is to say, comprehending all things, and cannot possibly be comprehended. A God, that is present at all times, and in all places, and filleth with the presence of his glorious Maiestie, both heauen, earth, and hell, and all at one instant The Apostle Paul was a man endued with excellent gifts, and graces of Gods Spirit, preferred aboue the rest, to
the hearing & vnderstanding, of the deepe secrets of Gods wisedome, and counsell, as 2. Cor. 12.2. Cor. 3.2, 3, 4. where hee testifieth of himselfe, that hee was taken vp into the third heauen, yea euen into Paradise, and heard words which cannot be spoken, which are not possible for man to vtter. And yet durst hee not take vpon him to giue a reason of all the wayes, and actions of GOD, but being highly astonished at his infinite wisedome, satisfieth himselfe, and cutteth off all obiections, with an exclamation, and wondering at the same, saying, Rom. 11. Rom. 11.33 O the depth of the riches, both of the wisedome, and knowledge of God: how vnsearchable are his iudgements, and his wayes past finding out! This confirmeth the Prophet Dauid also, Psal. 36, Psal. 36.6. where he saith, That the righteousnesse of GOD is like to a mighty mountaine, and his iudgements are like a great deepe. And hereupon also doth Zophar demaund of Iob, chap. 11. Iob 11.7. Canst thou by searching finde out God? canst thou finde out the Almighty to his perfection? Plainely giuing to vnderstand, that so infinite, and incomprehensible is God, that the depth of his counsels cannot be attained vnto; and therefore a
vaine, and an intolerable presumption, to seeke further after it, then it hath pleased him to reueale, and manifest the same in his holy Word. The secret things (saith Moses, Deut. 29. Deu. 29.29.) belong to the Lord our God, but the things reuealed, belong to vs, and to our children for euer.

div.head: Of inestimable glory, Maiestie, Exod. 4.34, 35. chap. 33.20.
div.p:
Exposition.Of this, much hath been spoken before • . And it may further be considered in the example of Moses; who, as we reade, Exod. 33. was faine to be put into the cleft of a Rocke, and to be couered in the same with the hand of God, because he was not able to behold the glory of the Lord, as the same passed by him. The Story is this, Moses hauing triall of the gentlenesse and goodnesse of the Lord, so as there was nothing which he obtayned not at the hands of God: he thereupon becommeth bold to desire, that he might see him in his glory, and maiestie: I beseech thee (saith he) shew me thy glory. Whereunto the Lord answered, I will make all my good goe before thee,
Exod. 33.18, 19, &c.
and I will proclaime the name of the Lord before thee, &c. And a little after,
Thou canst not see my face, that is, haue a full sight of my substance, the beholding of that belonging only to the blessed Spirits that are already glorified in eternall felicity. But there is a place by me (saith God) and thou shalt stand vpon the rocke, and while my glory passeth by, I will put thee in a cleft of the rocke, and I will couer thee with my hand, that is, with a cloude, or some such thing. After, I will take away my hand, and thou shalt see my backe parts, some imperfect image of my glory, but my face, that is, the glory of my Maiestie it selfe, shall not be seene. Such is our weaknesse, and corruption through sinne, that wee cannot abide the beholding of the Lords wonderfull maiestie, according as hereof wee haue another example in the people of Israel, at his appearing vnto them at Mount Sinai, Exodus 20. and Deut. 5. Exo. 20 19. Deut 5.27, 28, 29. it being there recorded, that why- the Lord stood vpon the Mount, not without glory, and maiesty, and vttered with his owne mouth, a briefe summe of his Law, and Religion, the people being astonied, and almost vtterly confounded with his excellent glory, said to Moses, Talke thou with vs, and we will heare, but let not
God talke with vs, lest we dye. And God receiuing their offer, said vnto Moses, I haue heard the voyce of the words of this people which they haue spoken vnto thee: they haue well spoken, all that they haue said: O that there were such an heart in them to feare me, &c.

div.head: And power, Esay 40.10.
div.p:
Exposition.The generall necessity of faith must euermore haue this speciall included in it, to beleeue, that God is of sufficient might and power to effect, and accomplish whatsoeuer pleaseth him, as Math. 19. Mat. 19. • 6 With God all things are possible. This speciall was included in the generall faith of Abraham, without which hee could neuer haue beléeued the promises of God. Without a firme faith, Gen. 15. •
Chap. 22.17 I say, in Gods omnipo
• encie, and Almighty power, how could Ab •• ham possibly haue beleeued, that his seed shou • d be as the dust of the earth, and as the Stars of the heauen in multitude, and that in his seed all the Nations of the earth should be blessed, when as hee himselfe was already old, and his wife not only old, but also barren? This in the iudgement
of flesh and bleed, was altogether vnlikely, and vnpossible, Rom 4.19.20, 21. but yet Abraham knowing that there was nothing vnpossible with God, considered not his owne body, as the Apostle saith, Rom. 4. nor yet the deadnesse of Saraes wombe: hee staggered not at the promise of God through vnbeliefe, but was strong in the faith, giuing glory to God: and being fully perswaded, that what he had promised, hee was able to performe. The like faith and resolution in Gods Almighty power, was also in the virgin Mary, beleeuing that shee should conceiue, and bring forth a Son, Luke 1.38. although she had neuer knowledge of any man, because God who had said it, was able to effect it. There is to no man giuen full, and perfect strength: but to one man is giuen to doe this, and to another that: but the might and power of God is not particular, but vniuersall: it can haue no determination, limitation, or restraint, but it is vtterly free, full, and absolute, so that hee can doe what be will, when, as farre foorth, and howsoeuer it pleaseth him. The mighty of this world be terrible, because they can kill the bodies of men, but that might of theirs, is so limited, that
they cannot kill the soule, Mat. 10.28. but after they haue slaine the body, their power is at an end. But God, when he lusteth, can cast both body and soule into hell fire. His Almightinesse is also continuall, vnchangeable, and euerlasting: not determinable by any processe of time, but as long as God himselfe endureth, (who hath neither beginning, nor end of dayes.) so long his power endureth, without being subiect to any passions, impediment, or incommodity, and therefore most notably, Psal 115. Psal. 115.3. Our God is in heauen, hee doeth whatsoeuer he will.

div.head: All-sufficient, Gen. 17.1.
div.p:
Exposition.That is, he is able of himselfe (without the helpe of any) to performe, and bring to passe whatsoeuer hee hath decreed, and whatsoeuer pleaseth him. For this cause, Iob 8.3. doth the Scripture call him the Almighty God, because by his might he can doe all things, because hee is Lord of all, and hath all things subiect to his command. Rom 9.29, 19. Hee is called also the Lord of Hoasts, in the power of which most high, and mighty God, is heauen, and earth, and whatsoeuer is contayned in them,
aboue, or vnder them. Whatsoeuer hee commandeth, that must of necessity bee done, nothing is able to withstand his will, there is nothing but he can, and will doe it, if it stand with his good will and pleasure, and if his iustice, and mans saluation doe require it. I am God all-sufficient, said the Lord to Abraham, Gen. 17. Gen. 17.1. which is as much in effect, as if hee had said, that he was strong, & mighty enough to protect him. For our faith cannot otherwise stand, vnlesse (being certainly perswaded, that the onely guard, and protection of God is sufficient for vs:) wee boldly despise, whatsoeuer in the world is against our saluation.

div.head: Onely wise, Rom. 16.27.
div.p:
The Lord God alone,Exposition. and none but God, may truly and properly be said to be wise & prudent: as Rom. 16. Rom. 16.27 To God only wise. And 1. Tim. 1.1. Tim. 1.17 in a like conclusion of thanksgiuing, Vnto God onely wise (saith hee) be honour and glory, for euer and euer, Amen. If a man should dispute with God, saith Iob, Chap. 9. Iob 9.3, 4. hee could not answere him one of a thousand, hee is wise in heart. And againe, Chap. 12. Iob 12.13. with him
is wisedome, and strength, he hath counsell and vnderstanding. In another place also doth hee make a difference betweene the wisedome that remaineth with God, and that measure of wisedome, which he hath appointed for men. For after he hath spoken of the secrets of nature, he concludeth, Chap. 28. that wisedome is to be found in God onely, and hid from the eyes of all liuing creatures. Iob 28 12, 13, 14, 15, 23. Where is wisedome found, saith hee, and where is the place of vnderstanding? Man knoweth not the price thereof, for it is not found in the land of the liuing. The depth saith, It is not in me: the Sea also saith, It is not in me. Gold shall not be giuen for it, neither shall siluer be waighed for the price thereof, &c. And a little after, But God vnderstandeth the way thereof, and he knoweth the place thereof. Infinite arguments & experiences haue there bin from time to time, and continually are of his excellent wisedome, as in the creation of heauen and earth, according to that of the Prophet, Ier. Chap. 51. Ier. 51.15. He hath established the world by his wisedome, and stretched out the heauens by his discretion. In the creation also of man, and in the wonderfull disposition of all the members
of his body; in the gifts of his minde, and in the gouernment also and direction of all his creatures, from the least, to the greatest, to the very same end, for which he at the first ordayned them. Notable wisedome, and discretion, are many of the sonnes and daughters of men endued withall, some after one manner, and some after another, as is daily seene by infinite Presidents, and examples. All which in euery degree, forasmuch as it floweth, and proceedeth from God: it must needes be concluded, that his wisedome is infinite, as the Prophet speaketh, Psal. 147. Psal. 147.5.

div.head: Onely good, Math. 19.17.
div.p:
There is none good, but God alone,Exposition. neither any thing that truly deserueth to be accounted good, but what proceedeth onely from him. So that whensoeuer we attribute any good, either vnto man, or to any other creature, and call them good, (as we vsually so call many things) wee must take heede that wee respect them not as they are in themselues, but acknowledge, that all the praise, honour, and glory, belongeth vnto the Lord, who onely, and alone, is good, G n. 1.31. and the fountaine of all
goodnesse, and righteousnes. The works of the first creation do witnesse this truth, all which as they were very good, so doe they shew foorth the goodnesse of the Maker, as good fruites proue the tree to be good, from which they are gathered. Secondly, who can rehearse the thousand part of those things, which be daily bestowed by Gods goodnesse, Math. 5.45 not onely vpon the godly, but euen also vpon the wicked, whom in iustice and righteousnesse he might destroy? And if wee seeke the Scripture, Psal. 73.1. Psal. 118.1. Jam. 3.15. the testimonies of Gods goodnesse therein, are excéeding many. But I neede not stand much vpon this, wherein there is neither difficulty, nor doubt, but all things as manifest, anb as cleare as the Sunne. And surely in the nature of God, there is nothing which a true Christian man can receiue greater comfort of, nor which he should honour with more admiration, then his endlesse and infinite goodnesse.

div.head: Most iust, Deut. 32.4. Psal. 145.17.
div.p:
Exposition.As the Lord God is righteous in all his wayes, and holy in all his workes, as the Prophet pronounceth, Psal. 145. Psal. 145.17. euen so
doth he so iustly, and vprightly proceed in euery circumstance, and respect, as that there is no cause at all for any to complaine of wrong, or partialitie, in the least measure that is. This doth the Apostle teach and confirme, Rom. 2. Ro. 2.2.5, 6. where hee saith, that the iudgement of God is iust, and according to truth. He offereth wrong to no man, neither when hee punisheth sinne, nor when hee spareth sinners, although he shew mercy but to a few, and throw downe great multitudes into eternall condemnation: but as the Apostle addeth, & as it is his very property, hee rendereth to euery man according to his workes. Men oftentimes in the pronouncing of their censures, and sentences, greatly erre, and iudge amisse: Sometimes for fauour; sometimes at the intreaty of friends; sometimes for feare of displeasure; sometimes through corruption of bribes, and hope of gaine; sometimes through the instigation of false witnesses; sometimes vpon malice, and sometimes through ignorance, and want of sound wisedome to discerue, acquitting those as guiltlesse, who deserue to bee punished, and condemning those as guilty, who
haue not offended: but as the Apostle speaketh, Act. 17. Act. 17.31. He will iudge the world in righteousnesse, by that man whom hee hath appointed. Before his iudgement seat, there neither is, nor shall be any dawbing, or saluing vp of bad matters, no inducement by gifts; no affection, or partialitie, in respect of persons; no fauouring of the cause for the sake of friends, for feare of foes, or any displeasure: no cunning shifts can there take place, to blinde the eyes, or to peruert the iudgement, but euery person shall receiue an eternall sentence of euery cause, according to the truth and equity of it. And thus is the Iudge of the world approued most iust.

div.head: Most mercifull, Psal. 36.5, 7.
div.p:
Exposition.God is mercifull, not to all that haue neede of his mercy; for such mercy should not stand with his iustice: but he is mercifull to all them that craue mercy at his hands, in the name and mediation of Iesus Christ, and with a true faith in his righteousnesse and Redemption. Hee is mercifull to all such as are truely humbled with the heauy loade and burthen of their sinnes, and are touched with godly
sorrow, and remorse of conscience, in regard of their transgressions. For to shew mercy vnto such, is no derogation to the Iustice of God: forasmuch as our Lord Iesus Christ by the shedding of his bloud hath made satisfaction for them. Infinite are the particular proofes, and experiences of the mercy and goodnesse of God, which might bee remembred both concerning Soule and body, this life, and that which is to come: Hee being the Author and fountaine of all good things, generally and without exception, which wee either doe, or can possibly enioy, and haue imparted vnto vs; as Iam. 1. Iam. 1.17. Euery good g • uing, and euery perfect gift is from aboue, and commeth from the Father of lights. But yet t • the reconciliation of the world vnto himselfe, by Iesus Christ, and in stretching out the armes of his louing kindnesse to the saluation of all such as truely feare him, and embrace his promises, whether Iewes, or Gentiles, is it most of all apparant, and very wonderfull: Yea surely, so surpassing excellent is this mercy of God aboue all his workes, and all other his mercies that can possibly bee remembred, that if we should doe nothing
else, but continually laud and glorifie his Maiestie for the same, yet should our praises come farre behinde the highnesse and excellency of his grace and fauour. None can sufficiently extoll and magnifie this wonderfull mercy. Rightly may wee say hereof with the Prophet, Psa. 36. Psal. 36.5. That it reacheth vnto the Heauens. And sufficient cause haue we in regard hereof, to confesse with the same Prophet againe, Psal. 103. Psal. 103.8. That the Lord is full of compassion and mercy. In that (I say) whereas wee are by nature the children of wrath as well as others; aliants from the commonwealth of Israel, strangers from the Couenants of Promise, and had no hope, and were without God in the world, as the Apostle speaketh, Ephes. 2. Ephe. 2.3.12. Chap. 4.18. hauing our cogitations darkened, &c. as Ephes. 4 and being full of all vnrighteousnesse, &c. as Rom. 1. Rom. 1.29. He hath vouchsafed to receiue vs vnto mercy, and freely in Christ Iesus to forgiue our sinnes: Yea, so to accept vs through the free imputation of his righteousnes, and obedience, as if in our selues wee were holy and righteous.

div.head: And therefore one, Deut. 6.4. Psal. 18.31. 1. Cor. 8.6.
div.p:
Necessarily doth it follow,Exposition. vpon that which goeth before, that God is one. Not one of these diuine Attributes, which haue been remembred; agreeing, or being to be applyed to any other, but to one only true God. This alwayes herewith, being religiously obserued, and vnderstood, that these are essentiall properties of the Deity, and so attributed vnto him, that they place nothing in him that is compound, or diuerse from his substance; but look whatsoeuer they point him out to be, the very same he is in his owne nature. We must know (I say) that there is nothing in God, which is not God himselfe. So that when it is said that God is holy, iust, good, mercifull, &c. it is to be vnderstood, as if hee were said in plain termes, to be holinesse, iustice, goodnesse, and mercy it selfe. To proue that there is but one true, eternall, and euerliuing God, who only, and alone, is to be beleeued in, called vpon, worshipped, loued, feared, serued, and obeyed, the Scripture affoordeth plentifull Testimonie. As first, Mar. 12. in the answere
of our Lord Iesus Christ vnto a certaine Scribe, who demanding of him which is the first commandement of all?
Mar. 12.28, 29, &c. Exod. 20.2. Deut. 6.4. Deu. 32.39. He answered out of Exodus 20. and Deut. 6. The first of all the commandements is, Heare, Israel, The Lord our God, is the onely Lord, &c. Whereunto the Scribe replyed, saying, Well, Master, thou hast said the truth, that there is one God, and that there is none but he: And to loue him with all the heart, and with all the vnderstanding, and with all the soule, and with all the strength, &c. is more then all burnt offerings, and sacrifices. Moses in the end of his Song, Deut. 32. bringeth in God thus speaking of himselfe: Behold now, for I am hee, and there is no gods with mee: I kill, and giue life; I wound, and I make whole, neither is there any that can deliuer out of my hand.

But this being a truth, which is not denyed, but beléeued, and confessed among the very Iewes, and Turkes, who glory much in the acknowledging of one onely God: I will therefore passe from it, and procéed to shew, in as few words as I can, how this onely True God doth offer himselfe to be considered of vs, in a Trinitie of persons.

div.head: There are three eternall, and equall persons of the Godhead, distinguished by their proper difference, and yet not separated one from another. The Father, the Sonne, and the Holy Ghost.
div.p:
That there are these three distinct persons; and yet in Essence,Exposition. but one onely Eternall, Almighty, and incomprehensible God: I will alledge for proofe, two or three speciall Testimonies of the Scripture, among many other that might be remembred. There are three (saith S. Iohn 1. Epist. 5.1. Ioh. 5.7.) that beare Record in Heauen; the Father, the Word, and the Holy Ghost, and these three are one. In Mathew 28. Math. 28.18, 19. All power is giuen vnto me (saith Christ) both in Heauen, and in Earth. Go therefore teach all Nations, baptizing them, in the name of the Father, the Sonne, and the Holy Ghost. Also Ioh. 15. and 16. Ioh. 15.26. cha. 16.13. &c. he hath these words, When the Comforter is come, whom I will send vnto you from the Father, euen the Spirit of Truth, hee shall leade you into all truth, &c. Heere haue we expresse mention of the person of the Father, from whom the Spirit is sent: secondly, of the person of the Son which sendeth him: and thirdly,
of the person of the Holy Ghost, or blessed Spirit which is sent vnto vs. Hereunto belong also the testimonies of Iohn the Baptist, Ioh. 1. chap. 3. Ioh. 1.32, 33.34. cha. 3.34, 35, 36 And what can be spoken more cleerely, for the proofe of the distinction and properties of the three Persons in the Trinity: then this Luke 1. Luke 1.35. where the Angell Gabriel declaring the mysterie of the Lords Incarnation; speaketh after this manner to the blessed Virgin Mary: The Holy Ghost (saith he) shall come vpon thee, and the power of the most Highest shall ouershaddow thee; therefore also that holy thing that shall be borne, shall be called the Sonne of God. Heere wee haue the person of the Highest, which is the Father; the persons of the Sonne, and of the Holy Ghost, are expressed with their properties; being neither mingled, nor confounded.

These places are sufficient to proue the truth of this point; as that wee must so beleeue in God, that wee referre one, and the same glorification to euery Person. For there is no difference of Faith in this respect. We must not haue a greater Faith in the Father, then in the Sonne, and in the Holy Ghost: but the measure,
and maner of it, must be one, and the same, equally consisting in each of the thrée Persons: so as by this meanes, we may confesse a Vnity of Nature, in the Trinitie of Persons.

These three persons are distinguished (I say) by their proper difference, insomuch, that to the Father wee must attribute the beginning of working, and creating, we must hold him for the fountaine, and spring of all good things; to the Son, we must attribute the wisedome, and gouernment of the things that are made; and to the holy Ghost, the power and efficacie of working and executing. And although the eternity of the Father, is also the eternity of the Sonne, and of the holy Ghost, (for God can neuer be without his wisedome, and power; and in the eternity, neither first, nor last is to be sought) yet is it most requisite to obserue this order in the blessed Trinity, to set the Father in the first place: in the second place the Sonne which commeth of him; and in the third place the Holy Ghost, which proceedeth from them both.

The minde of euery one inclining to consider, first God. Reason afterward his wisedome
which springeth from him; and finally the power, whereby hee executeth the Ordinances, and Decrées of his counsell.

Vse 1 For some vse of this point, wee must learne from hence, so to beleeue in God, that we neuer confound the seuerall properties of the Godhead, which in respect of our weake capacitie, are thus termed the persons of the Trinity; but that wee confesse, that they alwayes remaine distinct one from another, and yet without any manner of separation. It is but one Sunne that shineth in the Firmament, although three distinct things be perceiued in it: Light, Brightnes, & Heat. For these thrée, as they rise all together, so they cease all at once. The light goeth not before the brightnesse, nor the brightnesse before the heat. And although one thing be attributed to the light, another thing to ye brightnesse, and a third thing to the heat; yet they worke all together inseparably: euen so, as I said, are the three properties, or persons of the Godhead to be considered, so as they may be acknowledged both distinct, & coeternall, but yet vnseparable.

Vse 2 This Doctrine of the Trinity is necessary
to bee learned, and vnderstood of all true Christians, and that in respect of Gods glory, and of our owne saluation. For no man shall bee saued without the knowledge of the Father: Mat. 11.27. but the Father is not knowne without the Sonne; whosoeuer therefore denyeth the Sonne, hee hath not the Father, as 1. Ioh. 2.1. Ioh. 2.23. Againe, No man is saued without faith in Christ the Sonne, as Ioh. 3. Ioh. 3.36. And how shall any man beleeue in him, of whom he hath not heard? as Rom. 10. Rom. 10.14. It highly therefore standeth vs vpon, to haue the knowledge of the Sonne of God, that wee may beleeue in him to eternall life. In like manner; No man is saued without the knowledge of the Holy Ghost: For if any man haue not the Spirit of Christ, he is none of his, as Rom. 8. Rom. 8.9. but no man can receiue the Spirit, without he know him: whosoeuer therefore knoweth not the Holy Ghost, cannot be saued: according to that of our Sauiour, Ioh. 14. Ioh. 14. that the world cannot receiue the Spirit of Truth, because it seeth him not, neither knoweth him.

div.head: Quest. 5. What are wee to know, concerning our selues? Answ. What we are by Nature, and what by Grace. Quest. 6. What are we by Nature? Answ. We are by Nature the children of wrath, full of sinne and corruption, and heires of Hell, and condemnation. Ephes. 2.3. Rom. 7.18, &c.
EXPOSITION.
div.p:
THis is not to bee vnderstood of mans nature, as he was in his first estate, and before his fall. For the nature of man by Creation, and in his first beeing, was without sinne: yea, euen after the very image and likenesse of God, as Gen. 1. Gen, 1.26.27. Let vs make Man in our owne Image (saith God) according to our likenesse. Also, Thus God created Man in his Image, in the Image of God created hee him: that is to say, in righteousnesse, and true holinesse, as the Apostle expounds it, Ephes. 4. Ephes. 4.24. He gaue vnto man, not onely a minde to know, and acknowledge rightly
the Nature, the Will, and the workes of God: but also a will freely to obey God, and to apply all his desires, inclinations, and doings, according to the will of God. As his body, in respect of the outward forme, and proportion, was maiesticall, beautifull, gracious, purchasing feare, and reuerence of the inferiour creatures, and fauour euen in the sight of God: Immortall also, wherof there can be no question, seeing death came in by reason of sinne, as Rom. 5. Rom. 5.12. and 1. Cor. 15.1. Cor. 15.56. So, the happinesse of Adam in like maner, as touching his soule, was exceeding great, he hauing a minde, not onely illuminated with the true knowledge of God, and of all other things which did any way belong vnto him: but his will and affections were also free from all immoderate desires, and grieuous passions, which might any way molest or trouble him. His whole person was adorned with this crowne of glory, that he had the Lordship and dominion of the inferiour creatures giuen vnto him. And to conclude all in a word; in the presence of God did he liue most happily, and with him he had most louing and familiar conuersation. God many wayes reuealing
himselfe vnto him, especially in the Garden, wherein he had placed him And this may rightly be called perfect felicitie: For hee who hath God, who is the Fountaine of all blessednesse, ioy, and pleasure, hath all things belonging to perfect happinesse: as Psal. 16. Psal. 16.11. Thou wilt shew me the path of life. In thy presence is the fulnesse of ioy, and at thy right hand there are pleasures for euermore.

Whereas therefore it is said, that wee are by nature the children of wrath, &c. it must be vnderstood of our nature, as it is now degenerate, and corrupted. For such a fearefull exchange haue wee made by sinne Man by his sinne, and disobedience, in eating the fruit, whereof the Lord had said vnto him, Thou shalt not eate of it, did separate himselfe from God, lost the coniunction which he had with him; yea, all holinesse, and happinesse, both spirituall, and personall, and was cast out of the presence of GOD, and out of Paradise, wherein God did reueale himselfe, and his glory to man after a speciall manner; and so hee losing the fountaine of happinesse, did withall lose all the streames that flowed from thence, belonging either to soule
or body. Thus, you see, Reason how we are become by nature the children of wrath, &c. For whatsoeuer gifts it pleased ye Lord to bestow vpon the nature of man, he left the same with Adam: and therefore when Adam lost them, after he had receiued them, he lost them not onely from himselfe, but from all his posteritie. The History of the fall of Man, is expressely recorded, Gen. 2. Gen. 2.15, &c. In which it appeareth, that the frée liberty of choise, which God permitted to the will of man, he so abused, that he kept not the Law of his Iustice, but swarued therefrom, and most wretchedly transgressed the Commandement of God, by obeying the Diuell, and in giuing credit to his lying speeches, performing thereby vnto the Diuell such faith, and obedience, as was due to God alone; whereby hee stripped and bereaued himselfe, and his posteritie of the state of perfection, and goodnesse of nature, and the grace of God, and those good gifts of righteousnesse, and the Image of God, which in his cre • tion were ingrafted in him; he partly lost them, and partly corrupted, and defiled them: by this meanes casting headlong both himselfe, and all his off-spring, into sinne, death, and
all kinde of miseries in this life, and into eternall punishment in the life to come. Of this wretched and miserable estate, (thus become naturall, as naturally descended from our first Parents; and so infecting, and corrupting all the parts and faculties of soule and body, as that by nature, we haue now no power so much as to thinke a good thought, to desire, or to performe any thing, purely, and holily before the Lord: but are all without exception, spiritually dead in trespasses and sinnes:) the holy Scripture witnesseth in diuers places: as Ioh. 5. Ioh. 5.21.25 where our Lord Iesus Christ termeth them euen dead, that are the very elect of God. Not hauing relation to the death of the body, nor speaking of such as lye in the graues; but vnto the power and dominion, that sinne, and naturall corruption hath ouer all men, and wherewith they are so miserably intangled, and ouerwhelmed, as that there is no more power in man by nature, to recouer the spirituall life lost, then there is in a dead carkasse to restore it selfe to a naturall life. In this sence so speaketh the Apostle of the faithfull, Ephes. 2. Ephes. 2.1.5 and Col. 2. Col. 2.13. plainely; signifying, that as dead
men are destitute of all strength, & are able to doe nothing to execute the functions of this life: so by nature standeth the case with all, vntill such time as they be regenerate, and borne anew. The Lord (saith Moses, Gen. 6. and 8. Gen. 6.5. cha. 8.21.) saw that the wickednesse of man was great, and that all the imaginations of the thoughts of his heart are onely euil continually euen from his youth. Hereupon also saith the Prophet Ier. cha. 17. Jer. 17.9. The heart of man is deceitfull, and wicked aboue all things, who can know it? And in this regard Iob 15. Iob 15.16. is man called Abominable and filthy, which drinketh iniquity like water. Also Psalm. 51. Psal. 51.5. Behold, I was borne in iniquity, and in sinne hath my mother conceiued me: and Io. 3. Io. 3.6. That which is borne of the flesh (saith Christ) is flesh. And Rom. 8. Rom. 8.6. to be carnally minded, is death. And Io. 8. Io. 8.34. Whosoeuer committeth sinne, is the seruant of sinne. And hereunto also belongeth that, which the Apostle beateth vpon out of the Psalme, there is none righteous,
Rom. 3.10, 11, 12. Psa. 14.1, 3. no not one, There is none that vnderstandeth, there is none that seeketh GOD: they haue all gone out of the way, they haue bin made altogether vnprofitable, there is none that doeth good, no not one. Euery of these
testimonies plainely prouing, not onely, that as our Father Adam was himselfe corrupt, depraued, and full of sinne, so hath hee begotten all vs his children corrupt, depraued, and full of sinne, and wretchednesse, it being vnpossible, that flesh should bring foorth any thing, but that which is fleshly, and corrupt. And therefore Gen. 5. Gen. 5.3. it is said, that Adam begat a child in his owne likenesse, after his image, that is to say, corrupt, and sinfull, as himselfe was: but also, that so long as we remaine meere naturall men, we doe not only delight, and please our selues, to will, to desire, and to performe whatsoeuer is according to the lusts of our owne hearts, but whatsoeuer also we doe but muse, and thinke vpon, it is corrupt, and whatsoeuer we doe, in the whole course of our life, it is euen abominable, and guilty of eternall death before the Lord.

If our Father Adam had continued in his innocencie, then as the bodies of his posteritie should haue beene maiesticall, and excéeding comely in euery part, so should their soules haue beene also without inordinate appetites, and vnlawfull lusts, all their thoughts, words, and actions,
should haue beene pure, holy, sound, and good. But by reason of his transgression, as he begat a Son in his owne likenesse: euen so doe all his posterity beget Sonnes and Daughters like themselues, in all manner of corruption and prophanenesse. And whereas many Fathers, being afterward regenerate, and born themselues anew, through the mighty worke of Gods grace, doe beget such children, as are, in like manner, godly, and well affected: this is not by any naturall act of theirs, but through the speciall worke of the holy Ghost; The grace of God goeth not by descent; A godly Father cannot with all his owne godlinesse, and skill, engraffe it in his Sonne, but as our Sauiour speaketh, Io. 3. Ioh. 3.8. The winde bloweth where it listeth. According, as besides the testimonies of the Scripture, in Adam, who had Cain, as well as Abel, in Abraham who had Ishmael, as well as Isaac, &c. this is manifest by experience. Many good and godly Preachers, hauing lewd and vngracious children: And many other godly and religious Christians, whose sonnes and children doe swarue as farre from the steps of their Fathers, and proue
as vnlike vnto them in all kinde of vertue, and godlinesse, as if they had neuer heard from them any godly exhortation, nor séene any good example, to induce them thereunto. All which proueth the great corruption of our nature, and not, if the Father be a good and godly man, the Son of necessity must be so too: but that whatsoeuer goodnesse be either in Father, or in the Sonne, it commeth wholy from the speciall grace, and free gift of God.

Reason 2 And surely not without iust and good reasons, is the nature of man thus degenerate, and he become the child of wrath, and a worthy inheritour of hell, and condemnation. For all manner of sinne is so filthy, and noysome, that it doth not onely defile those that commit it, but euen all their actions of greatest deuotion: as Leuit. 18. Leu. 18.24. and Ezech. 20. Ezech. 20.30, 31. where they that commit it, are expresly said to be defiled with it. As also Hag. 2. Hag. 2.14, 15. where it is said, that as the touching of holy flesh by a polluted person, doth make it vncleane: So is this people, and so is this Nation before me, saith the Lord, and so are all the workes of their hands, and that which they offer here, is vncleane.

Secondly, as the Lord God hateth all Reason 3 them that worke iniquity, as the Prophet saith, Psal. 5. Psal. 5.4, 5. so, he cannot in his iustice but also punish them, as being in his account, and in very deede, his vtter enemies. And what hee threatneth, and thundreth out against his enemies, wee may see among other places, Psalm. 92. Psal. 92.9. For lo, thine enemies, O Lord, (saith Dauid) for lo, thine enemies shall perish, and all the workers of iniquity shall bee destroyed. And if together with this, wee did also consider, in what measure the hatred of God is against sinne, how farre it proceedeth, in what bounds it is comprehended (if it haue any bounds or limits at all) we should runne into an infinite discourse, the hatred of God against sinne, being indeede infinite, altogether without measure, or limitation, no tongue of men, or Angels, being able to make it manifest, as it is in truth. But let vs now consider, what vse may be made of this.

As heereby the Popish doctrine of Vse 1 Fréewill is euidently discouered, to be false, and blasphemous, they attributing that to the nature of man, which is the speciall worke of Gods grace, and blessed
Spirit. The which assertion of theirs, although we disclaime, yet doe we not hold; neither doth it follow vpon that which hath now beene spoken, that man by nature is no better then a stone, or stocke, without any vnderstanding, or will at all left, but that by sinne hee is spoyled of all ability, either to vnderstand, to will, or to doe any thing aright. He is spoyled (I say) not of his will, but of the soundnesse of his will; that which in his first nature was sound, and good, being become in quality euill, and naught. To will euill wee are able, but to will well, there is in vs, no power, or ability at all.

Vse 2 Secondly, wee may gather from that which hath beene deliuered, that it is a first step to Gods grace, when men truly know, and acknowledge themselues to be wretched, and miserable sinners, by nature the children of wrath, and in the state of condemnation. The knowledge of this being a knowledge of so great weight, and importance, that without a true feeling, and consideration thereof, there can be no true feeling, or consideration of the grace, and mercy of God in Christ Iesus, nor any fit matter for the same to worke vpon. But
yet, howsoeuer this be the naturall condition of all without exception, yet fewe there be that truly know it, and fewer that doe vnfainedly acknowledge it, Cain, Pharaoh, Esau, Ahab, Iudas, saw their seuerall sinnes to be very great, and in some sort made confession of them, but they neither seriously considered their sinne, as sinne, nor vnfainedly made confession of them, but all they made shew of, was in hypocrisie, and dissimulation, to bleare the eyes of God, if it had beene possible, and so to escape the fearefull execution of his heauie wrath, which they saw likely to fall vpon them, as he was a iust, and righteous Iudge. If wee diligently search, and examine our selues, wee may finde this corruption of nature, euen in our best actions, and of greatest deuotion. I will discouer it in one, or two, that you may the better discerne it in all the rest. When through the motion of Gods Spirit wee prepare our selues to prayer; if we looke into the corners of our hearts, wee shall finde much vnfitnesse for so holy an action, and no such cheerefulnesse as we ought to haue: and in the action it selfe of prayer, great weaknesse, many idle and wandring
cogitations, and so, as very often, wee haue one thing in our mouthes, and another thing in our mindes. Vpon examination, wee shall finde our faith in God, and in Christ full of much infidelity, and distrust: That we seldome, or neuer come to the hearing of Gods word, so prepared as wee should doe, and in the act of hearing, are so hindred from a religious attention, through by-thoughts, and wandring imaginations, arising from the corruption of nature, and cast in our way by Satan, the arch enemy of our saluation, that oftentimes we returne home againe, without reaping any profit, or comfort by that which is taught. And thus stands the case with vs in all other actions, and duties of Gods worship and seruice, wee neuer comming to the Lord with all our heart, soule, & minde, a great part of euery of them being intangled with the cogitations, or delights of earthly things.

Vse 3 The third and last vse then hereupon must be this, that seeing we are all naturally sinners, and the children of wrath, no man being able truly to say, that his heart is cleane, Pro. 20.9. Iam. 3.2. but in many things (as Saint Iames saith) we sinne all, that therefore
wee be duly mindfull, as wee tender the glory of God, & our own saluation,1. Ioh. 1.8, &c. not onely with penitent hearts to acknowledge our wretched and miserable estate, by reason of this sinne which cleaueth so fast vnto vs, with all other our open, and secret sinnes which spring from thence, our pronenesse to that which is euill, and our backwardnesse, and vntowardnesse to that which is good: but also to pray and beseech the Lord, to draw and bring vs out of this bondage of corruption and misery, into the glorious liberty of his adopted children, and to sanctifie vs to serue him in holinesse and righteousnesse, all the dayes of our life.

div.head: Quest. 7. What is our estate by grace?
div.p: Answ. By grace, wee are freed from the power and dominion of sinne: of the children of wrath, wee are made children, and heires of God, yea co-heires with Christ, Eph. 2.1. Io. 1.12. 1. Io. 3.1. Rom. 8.17.

ALthough all, without exception,Exposition. are by nature the childrē of wrath, full of sinne, and corruption, and
heires of hell and condemn • tion, yet such among them, as do belon • to eternall life, the Lord doth not alwayes leaue in that wretched and miserable estate, but in due and conuenient time doth call and separate them from the rest, whom he doth not acknowledge for his owne; vouchsafing vnto them his holy Spirit, by whose regeneration and sanctification, their corrupt and carnall affections are reformed, and from whom they receiue power, to subdue their lusts, to fight against the temptations of the world, the flesh, and the deuill, and not onely to hunger and thirst after holinesse and righteousnesse, but to embrace, and put the same in practice. This teacheth the Apostle, Ephe. 2. Ephes. 2.1. where directing his spéech vnto the Elect of God, And you (saith he) hath he quickned, that were dead in trespasses and sinnes. And to the same effect, Col. 2. Col. 2.13. Also Ro. 8. Rom. 8.10. If Christ be in you, the body is dead because of sinne, but the Spirit is life because of righteousnes. Plainely therein teaching, that the Spirit of God is neuer idle, nor vnfruitfull, in t • e hearts of those in whom it is: but as on the one side it doth mortifie their sinfull lusts, and corrupt affections, so as although sinne
be in them, yet it doth not raigne in their mortall bodies, that they obey it in the lusts thereof, as the Apostle exhorteth, Rom. 6. Rom. 6.12, Though they walke in the flesh, yet doe they not warre after the flesh, as hee speaketh again, 2. Cor. 10.2. Cor. 10.3, 4, 5. Euen so on the other side, doth it quicken and inflame them, for the glorifying of God, and sealing of their owne saluation, in the fruits of holinesse, and righteousnesse, according to their seuerall places and callings, all the dayes of their life. And surely this is a notable effect of Gods grace, and blessed Spirit in the hearts of Gods children, and heerein doth it appeare to be mighty indeede, when as after this manner it casteth downe holds, the imaginations also, and euery high thing, which exalteth it selfe against the knowledge of God, and bringeth into captiuity, euery thought to the obedience of Christ, as the Apostle teacheth, 2. Cor. 10.2. Cor. 4, 5. when it maketh a man being by nature the child of wrath, to be the child of God; being by nature vnclean, prophane, abominable, and prone to all manner of euill, to be cleane contrary to his naturall disposition, zealous of Gods glory, holy and blamelesse in life and conuersation.
When as, although the substance of the body remaineth the same it was before: yet the heart, the minde, and the affections, are altered and transformed, to will, to desire, and to doe that alone which is pleasing, and acceptable in the sight of God. This is that new birth that our Sauiour Christ speakes of, Ioh. 3. Ioh. 3.3. and without the which hee plainely pronounceth, that no man can haue any entrance into the Kingdome of heauen, saying, Except a man be borne againe, hee cannot see the Kingdome of God. Plainely therein teaching, that the first birth of all men in Adam, is vtterly corrupt, and subiect to sinne and death; And that vnlesse it please the Lord, to make vs new creatures, and to repaire vs according to his owne image: wee can neuer be fit inheritours of the heauenly Kingdome. This is the gift of regeneration, wherby a man, of a limbe of the deuill, is made a member of Christ, and of the child of Satan, the child of God. In regard of which effects, as our Lord Iesus Christ, in Io. 3. Ioh. 3.5. resembleth the Spirit of God to water, washing the sinfull soules of Gods Elect, as it is the property of water, to cleanse and purifie
the filth of the body: So Math. 3. Math. 3.11. is he compared by Iohn the Baptist vnto fire. For as it is the property of fire, to warme the body that is benummed, and frozen with cold: so when a man is frozen (as it were) and euen starke dead in sinne, it is the property of the holy Ghost, to warme and quicken his heart, and to reuiue him againe: yea to purge, and to eate the hidden corruption of sinne, out of the rebellious heart of man, euen as fire doth purge the drosse from the good metall: There being no drosse nor canker that hath so déepely festred into any metall, as sin hath done into the nature of man.

Thus you see, how wee are fréed from the power and dominion of sinne, not by any worke of flesh and bloud, but by the grace of God, according to that of the Apostle, 1. Cor. 15.1. Cor. 15.10. By the grace of God I am, that I am. And Rom. 7. Rom. 7.24, 25. after hee hath vttered many grieuous complaints against the flesh, and masse of corruption, remayning in him vnregenerate, and at length burst foorth into this pittifull exclamation, O wretched man that I am, who shall deliuer mee from the body of this death? hee presently magnifyeth ye grace of God, and
comforteth himselfe, saying, I thanke God through Iesus Christ our Lord. As if hee said, God the Father, of his méere grace and mercy, hath already begun my deliuerance, and will nor faile to effect it; for which cause, I yéeld vnto his Maiestie most humble and hearty praise & thankes. So that this withall is necessary to be obserued, that this freedome from the power and dominion of sinne, this grace of regeneration, and new birth, is onely begun in the children of God in this life, through the grace and power of the Spirit of God, and neuer so fully perfected or finished whiles we are here, but that there remain many remnants of the flesh, which continually following corrupt affections, doe so moue warre against the Spirit, and regenerate part, that wee cannot haue any motion that is pure and vncorrupt, neither can we performe any action so soundly and perfectly as we desire: As this confirmeth the Apostle, Gal. 5. Gal 5.17. where speaking of the deare Saints and seruants of God, saith, That the flesh lusteth against the spirit, and the spirit against the flesh, and that these are contrary one to the other, so that they cannot doe what they would.
Now among some other, there are these two especial reasons, wherefore the Lord doth onely begin, and not perfect our regeneration in this life. First, that finding Reason 1 (so long as we are in this earthly Tabernacle) no end or stay of the conflict and combate betwixt the Spirit and the flesh, we might haue so much the more longing after the glory and blessednesse of the heauenly Kingdome, wherein wee shall appeare before God, perfectly righteous, and perfectly holy. A second reason is, Reason 2 that the Lords power may be made perfect in our weakenesse, and that seeing we are saued by meere grace,2. Cor. 12.9. Ephes. 2.8. Ier. 9.23, 24 and not by workes: our reioycing might not be in our selues, but onely in God, as the Prophet Ier. exhorteth, Chap. 9.

Concerning the worke of redemption, in a further consideration, how we are redeemed from the guiltinesse of sinne, and from the slauery of Satan, and so, as the Apostle speaketh, Rom. 8. Rom. 8.1. There is now no condemnation to them that are in Christ Iesus. Wee shall haue fit occasion to remember it, when we come to the 10. and 11. questions. And therefore not now to enter into it, but to make some vse of that
which hath already beene spoken.

Vse 1 First, seeing God is the Author of this our freedome, from the power and dominion of sinne, that therefore wee ascribe the honour and prerogatiue of so great a grace onely vnto him, and feeling the same spirituall worke of our new birth in any measure begun in vs, let vs yeeld vnto his Maiestie vnfayned praise and thanks.

Vse 2 Secondly, let vs learne to know and vnderstand the greatnesse and excellencie of this grace of God, that wee may prize and esteeme it according to the worth and worthinesse thereof. For this is a principle and point of doctrine, which vnto euery naturall man soundeth very harsh, and seemeth most strange, yea too nice and precise: Few there he that rightly vnderstand what it meaneth, and fewer that imbrace and entertaine it, when they doe vnderstand it, with any liking, or delight. And surely no maruell. For what can be more contrary to such a one, who hath his heart and minde wholly set vpon the pleasures and commodities of this life, then to heare and consider, that he must be borne againe, be wholly cast (as it were) into a
new mould, haue his heart cleane changed, and his naturall affections, and inclinations, quite altered and transformed, or else hee cannot bee saued? This maketh some to wonder (as Nicodemus did, Io. 3. Ioh. 3.4.9.) This is strange learning, say they, & how is this possible? Can a man enter into his mothers wombe, and be borne againe? And as it makes some to wonder, so othersome to wauer, and doubt, as Pauls hearers did, Acts 17. Act. 17.32. nay, some to mocke, give, and iest at it, as othersome of them did. None at all take pleasure in it, those few onely excepted, in whom this change is begun, through the mighty working of Gods Spirit. It is therefore vndoubtedly to be accounted a speciall gift of Gods grace, if when we heare this truth of doctrine preached vnto vs, we perceiue our eyes to be opened for a right conceiuing, and vnderstanding of it, and our hearts and mindes illuminated, and entertaining of it. For, a man can receiue nothing, except it bee giuen him from Heauen, as Ioh. 3. Ioh. 3.27.

For a third vse; let vs take it to heart, Vse 3 and resolue vpon it, as a most certaine and infallible truth, that there is no man liuing
at this day, neither euer was there any from the beginning of the world, (our Lord Iesus Christ onely excepted) although he were neuer so learned, neuer so holy, and righteous, but he had great néed of this new birth; of this freedome from the power and dominion of sinne; yea, so great need, that without the same, it was vtterly vnpossible for him to be saued. Nicodemus, was a man, not only of the learnedst sort amongst the Iewes, but euen also of the best affectioned to the feare of God: and yet we may see, Ioh 3. how our Lord Iesus Christ would not exempt him from this second birth, but tels him plainly that he must be borne againe,
Ioh. 3 7. or else hee could not possibly bee a fit member for Gods Kingdome. And therefore maruell not (said he) that I say vnto thee, Yee must be borne againe. The Prophet Dauid was an excellent, holy, and good man, according to Gods owne heart, as the Scripture testifieth; & yet, in what high account he had this grace of regeneration, his earnest prayer to God for it, Psa. 51. Psa. 51.10, •• . doth plainely approue. Create in mee a cleane heart, O God, and renue a right spirit within me, &c. The Apostle Paul was also an excellent
and chosen vessell of the Lord, a notable instrument in the Church of Christ, for the conuersion and saluation of infinite multitudes: and yet, what great need he had of his deliuerance from the bondage of corruption, it appeareth plainely as in other places, so especially, Rom. 7. Rom. 7.14, 18. &c.
Wee know (saith hee) that the Law is spirituall, but I am carnall, sold vnder sinne. And againe, I know that in mee, that is, in my flesh, there dwelleth no good thing. And therefore afterward cryeth out, and relyeth vpon Gods grace and mercy, as I noted before. And now, if the case thus stood with these holy and excellent men of God, let vs take heed, that none of vs take any conceit, either in regard of our outward estate in the world, or in respect of any learning, wisedome, knowledge, goodnes, godlinesse, or vprightnesse, that wee may peraduenture suppose to be in our selues aboue other men, to flatter, and perswade our owne hearts, as though wee had no need of this change, and alteration of our hearts, minds, and inclinations. For from whence (I pray you) springeth such neglect, and contempt of Gods Word, as is amongst vs? How is it, that so many men
and women are so often, and so easily staid at home from the hearing of it; and so few profit by hearing, when they are present? That there is such vaine swearing, and irreuerent vse of Gods name in the mouths of some? Such prophaning of the Lords day? Such hatred, and heart-burning, malice, and enuy? Such whoredome, drunkennesse, & Alehouse-hunting? Such pride, and vanity? From whence is couetousnesse, oppression, deceit, lying, slandering, mocking, backbiting, and the like? Surely the fountaine, and well-spring, from whence all these disorders and offences doe slowe and proceede, is no other but the heart and mind of man remaining in its naturall estate, vnchanged, vnregenerate, vnsanctified. And therefore let men flatter themselues as they list, and perswade themselues as they thinke good, that they are sound within, and need not any change from their present condition; that they surely feare God well enough, and are in the state of grace and saluation as well as any other: yet so long as these and such like vnsauoury fruits & effects, are to be seene arising in them, & procéeding from them: it is as cleere as the
light, and as good as a thousand witnesses to conuince them, that their hearts are not vpright, neither before God, nor man: And that vnlesse they be changed, and become new hearts, they are in the very high way to condemnation.

Last of all, seeing it pleaseth not God, Vse 4 to giue to his children an absolute perfection in this life, but reserueth the same vntill we be clearely rid of the burthen of this mortalitie, according as besides the testimonies of the Scripture; this, (as I shewed in the former principle) euery true Christian feeling heart, hath continuall experience of, in the actions of al our life, nothing beeing performed in such sincerity and vprightnesse as it should be, no not the very duties of Gods worship, and seruice: but both in prayer, and in hearing Gods Word, we are oftentimes interrupted, with idle, vaine, and wandring cogitations: that therefore wee be duely mindfull, with true zeale, and feruency of spirit, to pray and beseech the Lord, that it would please him to goe forward with this most excellent worke of our regeneration, and new birth: so, that although it cannot be fully finished, whiles wee are
heere; yet at leastwise, wee may by his grace, attaine to such perfection, as not onely to fight, but also to preuaile against the corruption of our hearts, and notwithstanding all the temptations of the world, the flesh, and the Diuell, offer vp our bodies, and soules, liuing, and holy sacrifices, acceptable vnto God through Iesus Christ: According as such speciall grace hath the Lord promised, Ezech. 36. Ezech. 36.26. vnto all such as are truely desirous of the same, saying, A new heart will I giue you, and a new Spirit will I put within you, and I will take away the stony heart out of your body, and I will giue you a heart of flesh.

div.head: By grace we are not onely freed from the power and dominion of sinne: but also made the children and heires of God; yea, coheires with Christ.
div.p:
Exposition.Rightly are wee said to be the children of God by grace, because nothing else can be alledged, as any cause, or reason of our exaltation to so great honour and dignity, but onely the meere grace and free mercy of God, who so loued vs, as S. Iohn speaketh, 1. Epist. 3.1. Ioh. 3.1. Behold, what loue the Father hath giuen vs (saith hee) that wee
should bee called the sons of God! Where the Apostle (as you see, setteth forth this loue, with a note of admiration and attention, as a matter of no small moment, but religiously to bee admired, and regarded. For is it not (indeed) a wonderfull and vnspeakeable loue, that we being by nature the children of wrath, Ephes. 2.3. should yet be accounted, and be indéed the sonnes and daughters of God? that we being in our selues, most wretched and miserable sinners, should be so highly aduanced, as to be the brethren of Christ? And doth it not proceed from speciall grace and fauour, Heb. 2.12. that we being worthy of nothing but of eternall death and condemnation, should be coheires with Christ, and accounted worthy inheritors with him, of eternall life and saluation? Surely, this loue, this grace and mercy, is so surpassing excellent, as that it can neuer be sufficiently expressed; much lesse then possible to be deserued.

We account it a great honour and dignity, to be the sonnes & children of rich and wealthy Parents; of Noble, and Honourable P •• sonages, and especially of great Princes, and Monarks. And surely, so it
is, if we looke no further then the world. But if with a spirituall eye, and regenerate consideration, wee enter into the examination of the matter, we shall finde, that euen the poorest, and miserablest creature that is in the world (if hee bee through Christ, the adopted childe of God,) is in a farre more blessed and happy estate, then the other with all their riches, and worldly honour, if together with these outward good things, they haue not receiued the Spirit of Adoption.

Reason 1 For why? The Princes, the Nobles, and rich men of the world, though they giue their children all that they haue, yet all is but vaine and vncertaine riches: the time of their enioying them is but small: and yet in this small space of time, innumerable are the inconueniences that they are subiect vnto. So that oftentimes it comes to passe, Eccl. 2.7, 8, 9, &c. Esay 40.8. that a man is rich, and in honour now; and within a little while, base, & beggerly, hauing little or nothing of his owne, to sustaine himselfe withall. Whereas, the honour, and wealth, which God bestoweth vpon his adopted children, is incorruptible, and euerlasting. The one perisheth, Ioh. 6.27. (as our Sauiour speaketh, Ioh.
6.) the other endureth to eternall life. Farre more excellent therefore is the estate of Gods children, then the condition of the sonnes and children of men. And so high a Prerogatiue is it, to haue God to be our Father.

For this our heauenly Father, as hee Reason 2 surpasseth all men in goodnesse and mercy; so is his loue much greater towards his children, then the loue of any earthly parent can be towards his; according to that of Esay 49. Esa. 49.15, 16. Can a woman forget her Child, and not haue compassion on the Son of her wombe? though they should forget, yet will not I forget thee, &c. And Mat. 7. Math. 7.11. If ye that are euill (saith Christ) can giue to your children good gifts: How much more shall your Father which is in Heauen, giue good things to them that aske him? Herein Reason 3 againe, towards his children, doth his goodnes appeare; that although hee hath of his owne, Math. 3.17. a deare and onely begotten Sonne, in whom (as the Scripture saith) he is well pleased; yet vouchsafeth he to adopt many other sonnes and daughters to himselfe; yea, and to make them heires with the same his naturall and dearely beloued Sonne, giuing them possession of
one and the same inheritance with him. For as it is, Rom. 8. Rom. 8.17. If wee bee children, then are we also heires. Moreouer, whereas, among the sonnes and children of men, not all are heires, but commonly the eldest, and first borne: in this adoption, all the children are heires, as well the yongest, as the eldest.

Reason 4 Now further, as Gods loue towards his children, is free without desert, and great without comparison: so is it also constant and perpetuall; the Scripture shewing in many places, that God is not like vnto mortall men, who in their loue are wauering, and vnconstant: but that in him there is no variablenesse,
Iam. 1.17. Io. 13.1. Phil. 1.6. nor shadow of turning. Whom he loueth, vnto the end he loueth them. And in whom he hath once begun a good worke, hee will not faile to performe it, vntill the day of Iesus Christ. And as it is 1. Sam. 15.1. Sa. 15.29 The strength of Israel will not lye, nor repent: for hee is not as a man, that he should repent. And Numb. 23. Nu. 23.19. Hath hee said, and shall not hee doe it? Hath he spoken, and shall not hee accomplish it? His gifts and callings are without repentance, as Rom. 11. R • m. 11.29 As God is vnchangeable in his essence, as Mal. 3. Mal. 3.6. I am
the Lord, I change not: so is he vnchangeable in his loue. And therefore by Saint Iohn 1. Epist. is he expressely called Loue. 1. Io. 4.8. For God (saith he) is loue. But if any man aske heere by the way, whether the loue of God be such towards his children, as that hee neuer hateth nor disliketh them vpon any occasion whatsoeuer? I answere that the Lord God indeed is often angry with his children, as a louing Father, and doth oftentimes seuerely chasten and correct them; but he neuer hateth them. For his loue towards them, being (as you haue heard) perpetuall, and constant: it cannot be, that hee should hate them at any time. Againe, he doth neuer deny them his mercy, but doth shew mercy vnto them after they haue sinned. Hee indueth them also with faith, repentance, and with all other graces of sanctification, freely also pardoneth and forgiueth their sinnes, and accepteth them as righteous through the righteousnesse of Christ. All which are euident arguments, that hee doth not hate them. Loue and friendship among men, if it be true and sincere, is most pleasant: but to be thus beloued of God, and in account with him as his children, is not
onely much more pleasant, but also much more honourable; and not onely much more honourable and glorious, but also much more profitable; and not only much more profitable, but also much more constant then all the loue and friendship of Reason 5 mortall men. For by this loue and kindnesse of the Lord, wee haue communion with Christ, then the which, what can be more sweet and pleasant? And what can be either more honourable, or more profitable, then to bee the brethren of Christ, and coheires with him? Againe, as I haue shewed before, whom God once receiueth into his loue, he will still loue such a one with vnfained loue, and performe all the parts of a tender Father. And now, as there is no loue or kindnes in the world, so pleasant, so honourable, profitable, or constant, as is the loue of God; so is there none in the world, if it be of any worth, so easie to be obtained. For the Lord neuer denies his loue to any that in sincerity of heart are desirous of it: No, although in many respects, they be vtterly vnworthy to be partakers of it: Vouchsafing it to euery one that beleeueth in Christ, and hath a care and conscience to obey his wil,
howsoeuer in the manner of obedience, they discouer much infirmitie, and can doe nothing so soundly as he requires. But I will now proceede to another priuiledge and prerogatiue of sonnes.
