The Children of God, by the grace of Adoption, beeing the brethren of Christ, and coheires with him, haue a right of inheritance not onely to the Kingdome of Heauen, but euen also to this world. The Apostle, Heb. 1. Heb. 1.2. speaking of Christ, saith, Hee is made heire of all things. If of all things, then of the world. According to that also, Psal. 2. Psal. 2.7, 8. Thou art my Sonne, this day haue I begotten thee. Aske of me, and I shall giue thee the Heathen for thine inheritance, and the ends of the earth for thy possession. In this fence, and no otherwise, then by reason of this adoption obtained by faith in Christ Iesus, is Abraham said to be the heire of the world.
Rom. 4.13. And as Abraham, so all his seed according to the faith; all that are of the faith, being the children of faithfull Abraham, and blessed with him, as Gal. 3. Gal. 3.7, 9. For this cause thus pronounceth our Lord Iesus Christ, Math. 5. Math. 5.5. Blessed are the meeke, for they shal inherit the earth. And in 1. Cor. 3.1. Cor. 3.22, 23. All are
yours, and yee Christs, and Christ Gods. Whatsoeuer was lost in Adam, the same by Christ is restored againe. And man (as we know) when hee was created, was made according to the Image of God, to be ruler ouer all the inferiour creatures. And now if Christ hath restored this image, then hath he also rendred againe the principality that was lost; so as euen by the right of inheritance, all these earthly good things are ours. And howsoeuer this doth not now appeare: the children of God, the faithfull members of Christ, being in number the fewest; and hauing commonly of all others the least to doe in the world, poore, and of little countenance for the most part of them: yea, hated, despised, and rather persecuted of the world and of worldly-minded men then otherwise; yet in truth, and indeed, vnto them doth the heritage of al things in the world appertaine: and not to the wicked and prophane multitude, who now enioy the pleasures and commodities of the same, and vse them, and abuse them as they thinke good. Doest thou feare God from thine heart, and hast thou receiued the Spirit of Adoption, whereby in thy heart
thou canst call and cry, Abba Father? Then the lands and goods, the gold and siluer, the corne and cattel which thou possessest, are thine owne. But if thou doe not truely feare God, and art not by the grace of Adoption the Child of God: then know for a surety, although thou hast all these outward and earthly riches, in neuer so great and plentifull a measure, & doest order and dispose them at thy pleasure: yet in right they belong not vnto thee; thou possessest them vniustly to thine own damnation. Now, how a man shall examine himselfe, whether he be the Child of God or no, I haue partly shewed before, and haue often occasion to consider it at large. And therefore now in a word, whosoeuer doth truely & faithfully beleeue in Christ Iesus, and in his righteousnesse, and redemption, such a one is vndoubtedly the C • ild of God; & bee it more or lesse which he enioyeth, yet it is his owne: whereas they that are destitute of this faith, though they liue neuer so pleasantly, and at their hearts ease (as wee say) yet their wealth, their lands and goods are none of their owne before God; they vsurpe, and possesse the same wrongfully, and for it, one
day shall giue an account, and be called to an heauy reckoning before the dreadfull iudgement seat of God: The poore and miserable that are now in want, (and against whom they now harden their harts, and shut vp their compassions) hauing much more right to such wealth, then many of those that now possesse it: Speaking still of such poore, as truely feare God, and are by grace the Children of God; and who, howsoeuer they now cry in many places, and make pitifull mone, some through want of foode, some of apparell, some of fire, some through imprisonment, &c. and cannot be heard: yet a time of refreshing will come, when they shall bee comforted, and recompensed; and when the hard-hearted and miserable Worldlings, Vsurers, Oppressors, and wrong doers, who now make the world their god, and will neither freely distribute to the necessities of the Saints, Rom. 12.13 nor willingly pay that which they are assessed; (but although they possesse, some of them thousands, and othersome hundreds, will yet wrangle and contend sometimes for a shilling, and sometimes for much lesse:) A time will come (I say) when such, on the
contrary, shall be quite stripped out of all, and as the rich man in the flame of fire, (of whom we read Luk. 16. Luk. 16.24.) though they entreat neuer so much for a drop of water to coole their tongues: yet shall they languish most fearefully for euer, and not obtaine it.
But now let vs make some vse of that which hath beene spoken.

If men by grace be the children of God, Vse 1 then such as are destitute of this speciall grace, must of necessity be the children of the deuill. For no medium, or indifferent abiding can there be in this behalfe, betwixt the children of God, and the children of the deuill. As God by his Spirit ruleth in the hearts of all his Children, and sanctifieth them to serue and please him, and to seale the assurance of their owne saluation in the workes of holinesse and righteousnesse, according to their seuerall places and callings, and the diuers occasions that are offered: So doth the deuill on the contrary, raigne, and rule in the hearts of all his children of disobedience, whereby with delight and greedinesse they endeuour themselues to fulfill his lusts in all vngodlines and vnrighteousnes, Eph. 2.2. Ioh. 8.44.
to the dishonour of God, and to the sure sealing of their iust condemnation. As God by his Spirit worketh in his children a sound knowledge of his will, faith, repentance, patience, zeale of his glory, and such other grace: So doth the deuill labour, and endeuour to retaine and keepe his children in ignorance and infidelity, hardens their hearts against all repentance, and remorse of conscience in regard of sinne; so as although they be guilty of neuer so great and greeuous transgressions, yet penitently will they neuer acknowledge, nor make confession of them. Heere then is fit occasion offered, to try and examine our selues in what estate we stand before God, whether wee haue receiued the Spirit of Adoption, and be in the number of his deare and beloued Children or no.

Vse 2 To the end we may haue a comfortable assurance, that we are in this number, it highly behoueth vs to pray, and beseech the Lord to plant & establish in our harts, through the grace and power of his Spirit, a true and liuely faith. For by faith wee embrace the promises of GOD in Christ, and so are made his adopted Children,
according to that, Io. 1. Ioh. 1.12. As many as receiued him, to them hee gaue power to become the Sonnes of God, euen to them that beleeue in his name. And Gal. 3. Gal. 3.26. Ye are all the Sonnes of God by faith in Christ. Although wee be the sonnes and daughters of neuer so rich and wealthy parents, descended from the stocke and generation of neuer so godly and religious progenitours; yet wee may see in the example of the Iewes, Ioh. 8.39. (who had Abraham to their father,) vnlesse wee truly and faithfully beleeue in Christ, it is not possible to be the sonnes and children of God; the Euangelist in the place before alledged, most clearely teaching, not onely that we are then made the Children of God, when we receiue Christ, but also that Christ is no other way to be receiued but onely by faith. They that are endued with a true and liuely faith in Iesus Christ, although by reason of their naturall corruption, they oftentimes goe astray, and play the parts of disobedient children, yet through Christ they remaine neuerthelesse in this estate of grace. For the Euangelist doth not say, that they onely are preferred to this dignity and honour, who are pure,
and without sinne, worthy to be admitted into the fellowship of this heauenly kindred: For if the dignity should hang vpon such conditions, no man liuing could possibly be exalted thereunto: (all being sinners: in many things we all offending, yea our very righteousnes being but as filthy clouts, as Ro. 3. Ia. 3. and Es. 64. Rom. 3.10. Iam. 3.2. Es. 64.6.) And therfore notably saith the Euang. that it belongeth vnto them which beleeue in his name: that is, who acknowledging with true faith, the grace of God, offered in Christ, and through Christ, doe receiue and entertaine it in their hearts. Such onely doe receiue Christ, and they onely through him, are made the adopted childrē of God, and co-heires with Christ of eternall life; as to this effect speaketh the Scripture in many other places.

Vse 3 Thirdly, the experience and assurance of this great loue of God, in adopting vs for his Children, (we being by nature the children of wrath) ought to enflame our hearts with such feruency of loue towards him againe, as to prefer him aboue all things, and resolutely at all times, without being either afraid, or ashamed, to yeeld obedience to his blessed will.
Such a loue haue all the Children of God settled in their harts by the holy Spirit of God, as Rom. 5. Rom. 5.5. The loue of God is shed abroad in our hearts by the Holy Ghost which is giuen vnto vs. Which loue of ours towards God, must yet be acknowledged to proceede from the fountaine of his loue towards vs, he louing vs first, 1. Ioh. 4.19. as St. Iohn teacheth, 1. Epist. 4. And without whose loue towards vs, we should neuer haue beene affected with any true loue towards him. Now what it is to loue God aright, and as hee is to be loued, St. Ioh. 1. Epist. 2. doth plainely declare, saying, Hee that keepeth his Word, 1. Ioh. 2.5. in him is the loue of God perfect indeede: heereby wee know that we are in him. So wee see, that to loue the Lord God, with a sincere affection, is to keepe his Word, to yeeld obedience to his Commandements. This is that which the Lord requireth of all such as loue him, and heerein doth all the holinesse, and sanctification of Gods children consist. As this might further be shewed out of Deut. 6. and Chap. 30. Ioh. 14, Deut. 6.5. Cha. 30.19, 20. Ioh. 14.21. &c.

Last of all, seeing by this grace of Adoption, we are not only the children of God, Vse 4
and the brethren of Christ, but the brethren also of one another, according to that of our Sauiour, Math. 23. Mat. 23.8. All ye are brethren. This must teach vs to loue one another with brotherly loue, as Rom. 12. Rom. 12.10 Be affectioned to loue one another with brotherly loue. The husband loueth the wife, and the wife the husband; the father the child, and the child the father: and herevnto are they led, and allured, by the very law of nature: For we may see this kind of loue, euen among such as haue no spark at all of the true feare of GOD. But the loue wherewith Gods children are to loue one another, is such a loue, as whereunto men are drawne, and induced, not by nature, nor for worldly and carnall respects, but for conscience sake, respecting onely the good of such as are loued, and desiring and endeuouring to make them ioynt-partakers of such grace and goodnesse, as it hath pleased the Lord to bestowe vpon them. Thus to loue, will be a seale of our election, and as acceptable to Christ, as if it were done to himselfe. Yea, this affection sheweth, that we are liuing members in Christes body, it greatly pleaseth God, and hath praise with him. And thus
ought there to be among all Gods Children a communion of Saints, and that not onely because they are brethren and members of one body, but also in regard of their communion with Christ: Of which communion speaketh he himselfe, Ioh. 15. Joh. 15.5. saying, I am the vine, ye are the branches. And heereof also is the Sacrament of the Lords Supper a seale, according to that 1. Cor. 13.1. Cor. 10 16. The bread which we breake, is it not the communion of the body of Christ? As there is such a communion (I say) betwixt Christ, and the faithfull, he abasing himself, as if he were one of them, a friend to their friends, and an enemie to all such as are at enmity with them (of the swéetnesse, honour, profit, and constancie of whose loue I haue already spoken:) euen such in like maner ought to be the fellowship, the communion and loue of the Children of God among themselues, and as touching the reputation of friends, and enemies, none accounting him his friend, that is an enemie to the Gospell, either in the Ministerie or profession of it: so also in all other respects: cheerefully and willingly imparting, and communicating the good gifts of the minde, and the outward
and temporall good things of this life, for the helpe and comfort of one another, as occasion is offered: To reioyce with them that reioyce, and to weepe with them that weepe, as the Apostle exhorteth, Rom. 12. Rom. 12.15, 16. hauing such a Christian feeling and affection, as to transferre (as it were) the persons of our brethren vnto our selues, Heb. 13.3. considering their ioy and sorrow, as if our selues were in the same condition. Loue and vnity among brethren thus grounded and established, is like the dewe that falleth downe to giue nourishment to the ground: And like the Oyle that dropped downe from Aarons beard, as the Prophet vseth these similitudes, Psalm. 133. Psal. 133. plainely therein teaching, that when men embrace one another with true and vnfained loue, it is as when the fields & hearbs receiue nourishment by the dewe of heauen. And it is a thing that yeeldeth a very sweet sauour vnto God, as a good and acceptable sacrifice vnto him; yea euen like the smell of the holy Oyle, that was powred vpon Aarons head.

div.head: Quest. 7. What is Christ? Answ. Christ is the eternall Sonne of God, perfect God, and perfect man, in one person, Pro. 8.22, 23. Ioh. 1.1. Gal. 4.4. Heb. 2.14. Iam. 1.14. 1. Ioh. 4.2. Esay 7.14. Quest. 9. Had Christ alwayes these two natures in one person? Answ. Christ, as touching his Godhead, was without beginning, of one and the same Essence and Being with the Father, equall, and all one with him, in glory, maiestie, and power: And he became man, when he tooke to his diuine nature, our flesh in the wombe of the virgin Mary, like vnto vs in all things, except sinne, Esay 53.8. Ioh. 10.30. Phil. 2.6. Ioh. 5.21. Luke 1.35. Heb. 2.16, 17. Heb. 4.15.
EXPOSITION.
div.p:
THese three points (for the better vnderstanding of these two principles) doe fitly offer themselues
to be considered. First, that there are two natures in Christ, a diuine, and humane nature. Secondly, although there be two natures, yet there is but one person. And thirdly, how this vnion of both natures was made in one person. That there are two natures in Christ, it is euident as concerning his diuine nature, Ioh. 1. Io • . 1.1, 2, 3, 14. In the beginning was the Word, and the Word was with God, and the Word was God. By the Word in which place, that the Euang. vnderstandeth not that word of God which is spoken, and vanisheth, but the person of the Sonne of God: it is manifest not onely in that hee saith there expresly, that that Word was God, but addeth also, that All things were made by him. and without him was nothing made that was made: in him was life, and the life was the light of men. And yet more plainly, And the Word was made flesh, and dwelt among vs, and we beheld his glory, as the glory of the onely begotten Sonne of the Father, full of grace and truth. By all this compared together, it is very cleare, that our Lord Iesus Christ is the Word, and onely begotten Sonne of God, and that as he is the Word, and Son of God,
he is without beginning, hee is no creature, not taking his Essence with the things created, but his Being is eternall, and before all things. According as most notably, Pro. 8. Pro. 8.22, 23, 30, 31. doth Salomon bring in the person of the Sonne of God (whom hee there calleth the Wisdome of God) after this manner speaking of himselfe: The Lord hath possessed me in the beginning of his way, I was before his workes of old, I was set vp from euerlasting, from the beginning, and before the earth. And a little afterward, Then was I with him as a nourisher, and I was daily his delight, reioycing alway before him: And I tooke my solace in the compasse of his earth, and my delight is with the children of men. Now seeing in the beginning, God created heauen and earth (as Moses sheweth, Gen. 1.) And yet this Wisdome & Word of God (who is his eternall Sonne) was (as Salomon speaketh) before the same worke of creation: it is plaine, that hee had no beginning of Essence, but is from euerlasting and before all worlds. The Apostle Peter, 1. Epist. 1. saith of Christ,1. Pet. 1.20. That hee was fore-ordained before the foundation of the world. And Ioh. 8. he thus testifieth of
himselfe, Ioh. 8.58. Verily, verily, I say vnto you, before Abraham was, I am. He saith not, I was, or haue beene, for so should hee haue attributed no more to himselfe then to the Angels: for the Angels and celestiall spirits were in time before Abraham, and so was the very deuill: but in this phrase of speech, I am, hee exempteth himselfe from all moment of time, and proueth the sempiternity of his Diuinity, as hauing neither beginning nor end of dayes. For if he began not in the beginning, but was (as the Euangelist saith) in the same, then can it not be, but that as hee was without beginning, so shall hee also be without ending: As Reuel. 1. Reu. 1.8. I am Alpha, and Omega, the beginning, and the ending. He saith not, I haue ending, neither doth hee say, I haue beginning, but I am the beginning, and the ending. Infinite are the testimonies which might further be alledged for the proofe of this; but the point is plaine, and therefore now to the consideration of his humanity. That that Word, and eternall Sonne of GOD, which was with GOD in the beginning, and who being God, created all things that are, &c. That euen that Word (I say) vouchsafed so far
to abase himselfe, as to descend from heauen, and to become man like vnto vs in all things, except sinne: I might make this manifest by many testimonies of the old Testament, prophesying and foretelling that it should be so; but of this there being also no doubt amongst vs, two or three may suffice. In Esay 7. Esa. 7.14, 15. The Prophet prophecying of Christes humanity, hath these words, The Lord himselfe will giue you a signe: Behold, the virgin shall conceiue and beare a Sonne, and she call his name Immanuel, (or God with vs:) Butter and honey shall he eate, till he haue knowledge to refuse the euill, and to chuse the good. Also chap. 9. Esa. 9.6, 7. Vnto vs a child is borne, and vnto vs a Sonne is giuen, and the gouernment is vpon his shoulder, and hee shall call his name Wonderfull, Counsellor, the mighty God, the euerlasting Father, the Prince of Peace, &c. Hereunto may be added the promises that were made of him to Abraham, and before him to our first parents, Gen. 3. and chap 12. and 22. Gen. 3.15 Gen. 12.3. & 22.18. As also to Dauid, Ier. 23. Psal 89. I •• . 23.5, 6. Psal. 89 35.36, 37 But let vs see what the new Testament speaketh, of the accomplishment and fulfilling of that which was thus prophesied of before. Wee may see, Math. 1.
and Luke 3. Math. 1.1, &c. Luk. 3.23, &c. how diligently these two Euangelists doe draw the lineall descent of Christ, from the loynes of Abraham to Dauid, and from Dauid to the Virgin Mary, who, when the fulnesse of time was come, that he should be deliuered, brought forth a Sonne, who in all respects appeared to be true, and very man; And for which cause doth the Scripture call the said blessed Virgin, not a supposed mother, but a true & naturall mother, which, of the substance of her owne body, gaue true flesh, and substance of man, to the Son of God, according to that, Esay 7. which was alledged before. And for which consideration also, saith the Apostle, Gal. 4. Gal. 4.4. that God sent forth his Son, made of a woman, that is, according to mans nature. Further proofe may be had, Heb. 2. and chap. 4. 1. Tim. 3. Rom. 2. Heb. 2.14, 16. Heb. 4.15. 1. T •• . 3.16 Rom 9.5. but I passe to the second branch.

p.hi: Although there be two natures, yet there is but one person.

div.p:
Reason 1 For if there should bee two persons, then of necessity there must bee two Christes, according to the heresie of Marcion, who wickedly affirmed, that there were two Christes, the one crucified, and the other not. But for the cleare vnderstanding
of this deepe mysterie, that two natures remaine in the one person of Christ, a true Diuine, and a true humane nature, (either of them retayning its own disposition, and peculiar properties,) it is euident in the very same places of Scripture, which haue already beene alledged. As first, where the Prophet Esay, chap. 7. saith not only, that a Virgin shall conceiue, and bring forth a Sonne: but also addeth, that his name shall be called Immanuel, as I haue noted before. In these words (I say) doth the Prophet acknowledge both natures in Christ: for according to his Diuine nature, he is called Immanuel, or God with vs, and according to his humane nature, he is said to be conceiued and borne. Also in that saying, Esay 9. is this apparant: Vnto vs a child is borne, and vnto vs a Sonne is giuen. For Christ is giuen, who as concerning his Godhead is from euerlasting, and hee is also borne, hauing his beginning and being, as touching his manhood in the world. In Math. 22. Math. 22.42, 43. After the Pharises had answered touching the Christ, that he should be the Son of Dauid, he said vnto them, How then doth Dauid in spirit call him Lord, &c?
As if hee said, Seeing Christ is without doubt the Sonne of Dauid, and yet Dauid by the holy Ghost calleth him Lord, that is, very God, of the selfe-same power with the Father; it is plaine, that Christ is very man, and very God in one person. This therefore must of necessity, and vnder paine of condemnation, be both beléeued and acknowledged: And not only so, but that these two natures also, the diuine, and humane nature, are so conioyned and vnited, as that they are neither swallowed vp one of another, nor consounded or mingled together, but so, as the properties of each nature remaine safe, and distinct: And so, as we must worship not two, but one Christ, true God, and true man, as touching his Diuine nature, of the same substance with the Father, and as touching his humane nature, of the same substance with vs, alwayes except sinne. This is the summe of that which shall be necessary to be considered in this place, that the one of Christes two natures, is eternall, and without beginning; the other a created nature, hauing beginning; the one impassible, the other subiect to infirmities; the one Almighty,
and infinite, because it is God: the other limited & cōprehended, because it is Man.
div.q: The vnion of both natures in one person, was made after a maruellous manner.
div.p:
For whereas all other men generally both haue beene, and are conceiued by the seed of man, which being corrupt, hath made vs all naturally sinners, as we haue learned by that which goeth before, quest. 6. Our Lord Iesus Christ was not conceiued in the wombe of the blessed Virgin, by any seed of man, but by the Holy Ghost: who by his eternall power in her wombe, gaue a pure, and very humane body to the Sonne of God, so that hee became both God and Man in one person, the properties of each nature remaining safe, and vnconfounded, as was shewed before. If hee had beene conceiued by man, Reason 2 then had he not beene void of sinne, and so should hee haue beene vnfit to deliuer vs from sinne: And therefore Ioh. 17. Joh. 17.19. For their sakes (saith he) I sanctifie my selfe. And Heb. 7. Heb. 7.26. Such an High Priest became vs, who is holy, harmelesse, vndefiled, separate from sinners, and made higher then the heauens. The History of this is liuely set forth by the Euangelist Luke, chap. 1. how
after the Angell had told the blessed Virgin that she should conceiue in her womb, and bring forth a Sonne, & call his name IESVS: Shee asked him how this could be, seeing she knew not a man? Then the Angell answered,
Luke 1.31, 34, 35. and said vnto her: The Holy Ghost shall come vpon thee, and the power of the Highest shall ouershaddow thee; therefore also that holy thing which shall be borne of thee, shall be called the Son of God. Thus the points beeing cleere and manifest, that there are two natures in Christ, a Diuine, & a humane nature: Secondly, although there be two natures in Christ; yet there is but one person: and thirdly, that this vnion of both natures in one person, was made after a wonderfull manner: Now let vs come to the vses.

By this which hath been spoken, wee may see, that there is a double consideration to be had of Christs Diuinity: the one more secret and hid, as concerning his substance and being: as how hee is of the Father, how coeternall, and consubstantiall with him; how like vnto him in all things, equall in wisedome, power, and euery vertue: And againe, how so begotten of him, as that there is no separation
of Essence. For this (by the way) is necessary to be vnderstood, that whereas hee is said in the Scripture, to be begotten of the Father, and to come from the Father into this world: it must not so bee vnderstood, as though by being begotten, or by his comming from his Father, hee were separated from him: For howsoeuer it be so with vs, and that we are subiect to such diuisions, and separations: yet is it farre otherwise with God, and his Word, and onely Sonne, so as that his eternall Son, neither by being begotten, nor by any going forth is separated from the Father; euen as neither the brightnesse in passing from the Sunne, is separated from the Sunne; nor the heat in ascending from the Fire, is separated from the Fire; nor the counsell or wisdome of the heart in a wise man, is separated from the man in giuing good counsell, or in performing any wise or godly action.

The other consideration of Christs Diuinity, is more plaine, and apparant, appertaining to his workes and manifestations, whereby his Maiesty (which would otherwise remaine vnknowne, not onely to vs mortall men, but euen also to
the very Angels themselues, and heauenly spirits) doth now brightly shine, and shew it selfe. In the first of these, the Holy Ghost in the Scripture, is briefe, and sparing; but in the other, large and ample.

Vse 1 Which must teach vs to take diligent heed, that wee stay not too long, nor beat our heads too much, in the consideration of the diuine Essence, lest with the brightnesse of the same most high and excellent mysterie, our mindes and hearts be rather dulled, and confounded, then in any measure lightned, and instructed. And on the other side, that we exercise our selues, and spend a large and long continuance in the contemplation and reuelation of the same incomprehensible Essence. My meaning is, that both in the one, and in the other, we proceed so farre, and no further, then the bounds and limits of Gods Word. Whatsoeuer is reuealed in the Word of God, either concerning the blessed Trinity, or touching any other matter, the same, and euery part thereof, we must zealously settle our selues to know and vnderstand: (it being to this end committed to writing, that we should glorifie God, in the knowledge, profession, and
practice of it:) but whatsoeuer the Lord hath not reuealed therein, Rom. 15.4. Deu. 29.29. wee must not so much as thinke vpon it; being assured that it is the Lords will, that wee should remaine in ignorance of the same: As Deut. 29. The secret things belong to the Lord our God; but the things reuealed, belong Vse 2 vnto vs, and to our children for euer.

Secondly, as nothing, then a serious consideration of that which hath been spoken, can possibly be more ioyous and comfortable vnto all Gods Children, who truely and faithfully beleeue in Christ, then to consider (I say) that euen the same Christ, who abased himselfe to take our flesh, and to haue sence and feeling of our infirmities, is God from euerlasting, able to relieue vs in all miseries, and calamities, and to deliuer vs from the same: That hee, who is our Mediatour, Atonement-maker, and suffered for our sinnes, is the Lord of life, and saluation, able, and willing to forgiue vs our sinnes, and to exalt vs to the partaking of eternall glory: euen so on the other side, can there be nothing more terrible, and discomfortable to the children of this world, to the carnall, and prophane, then to consider, that
the very same Christ, the wholesome doctrines and exhortations of whose Word and glorious Gospell, they reiect, and wilfully transgresse; and whose faithfull seruants, both in the Ministery and profession of it, they contemne, derive, and persecute, is a God of power, a God of vengeance, able, and ready to tumble them headlong into the bottomlesse pit of Hell and condemnation, among the Diuell and his Angels, where shall be weeping, and gnashing of téeth; and out of which there shall neuer be any redemption.

Vse 3 Thirdly, as the obstinacie, and wilfull blindnesse of the Iewes, is hereby discouered; who, although they had Moses and the Prophets, dayly read and preached among them, and professed a continuall expectation, and looking for of the Messiah, according thereunto; yet when hee was come, most reprochfully notwithstanding reiected him, as Ioh. 1. Io. 1.11. Hee came vnto his owne, and his owne receiued him not. So it teacheth vs, that to the end we may attaine to the true knowledge of Christ, for the settling and reposing of a true & liuely faith in his name, for our saluation; and that our faith▪ and hope in him may not
wauer, but continue firme and vnmoueable in al temptations: that therfore in the feare of God, and with due reuerence and attention we apply our selues to the searching, hearing, and consideration of the holy Scriptures. And as in all other places, because euery word is pure and full of instruction, profitable to teach, to improue, to correct, and to instruct in righteousnesse, that the Man of God may be absolute, beeing made perfect to all good workes, as the Apostle teacheth, 2. Tim. 3.2. Tim. 3.16, 17. so especially in such places of the Old Testament, as prophesie and foretell of his comming, incarnation, and of his humiliation, & sufferings: And in such places of the New Testament, as make mention of the full accomplishment, and performance of that which was spoken of before. For this is a notable way (through the gracious assistance of Gods Spirit) to attaine vnto that which we desire in this behalfe: According as hereunto most plainely exhorteth our Lord Iesus Christ himselfe, Ioh. 5. Ioh. 5. •• . saying; Search the Scriptures, for in them ye thinke to haue eternall life, and they are they, which testifie of me.

div.head: Quest. 10. Was it of necessitie, in regard of our saluation, that Christ should haue two Natures, and be in one person, both God and Man?
div.p: Answ. It was a matter of so great necessity, in regard of our saluation, that Christ should haue two Natures, and be in one Person, both God and Man; that he could not otherwise haue ouercome death, and the Diuell, vnder whose captiuitie we were holden; neither haue satisfied Gods iustice for our sinnes, nor reconciled vs vnto him, 1. Ioh. 3.8. Heb. 2.14. Gal. 4.4, 5. 2. Cor. 5.21. 1. Pet. 2.24. 1. Ioh. 2.1, 2.

div.head: EXPOSITION.
div.p:
THe strength of sinne and death, and the power of Satan bee such, as that no vertue, or strength of Man, no nor of Angels, can doe any good to dissolue the same. The strength of man cannot, because all mankind are naturally
suppressed, and held captiue in this bondage. And therefore as Iob demandeth, chap • er 14. Iob 14.4, Who can bring a cleane thing out of filthinesse? So may I say, Who is able (being himselfe a prisoner, & bound) to deliuer him that is bound, and in prison also? The strength of Angels could doe no good herein: for the nature of Angels cannot take away the euill of sinne from mankinde, by which Satan doth raigne in the World. Wherefore the strength of God was in any case requisite; Reason 1 yea, such a Redeemer, as being indued with the power of God, should both take away the euill of sinne, which is in our flesh, and also destroy the kingdome of Satan. But Christ being in one person both God and Man, did all this, he being stronger then Satan, and whose Spirit alone is able to heale our hearts, and to deliuer vs from the power of condemnation. By this means also he had ye right of redemption. For as touching his Godhead, he Reason 2 is our Creator, and wee his creatures; & concerning his manhood, by taking our flesh, he is become our brother, as the Apostle teacheth, Heb. 2. Heb. 2.11, 12. Hee is not • shamed to call vs brethren, saying, I will declare
thy Name vnto my Brethren.

Ob.But here it may be demanded: If Christ redeemed vs by giuing a ransome: how then did he violently take vs away from Satan, and destroy his kingdome? That hee redeemed vs for a price, or ransome; the Apostle 1. Cor. 6. and 7.1. Cor. 6.20. chap. 7.23. doth witnesse, saying; Ye are bought for a price. And againe, that he stoutly ouercame Satan, and His guard destroyed his kingdome, and violently carried away the spoile: thus witnesseth he of himselfe, and of his conflict with Satan, Luke 11. Luke 11.21, 22. When a strong man armed keepeth his palace, the things that he possesseth are in peace▪ But when a stronger then he commeth vpon him, and ouercommeth him, he taketh from him all his armour wherein he trusted, and diuideth his spoiles. And the Apostle also Heb. 2. Heb. 2.14. making mention of the triumph of Christ, in the spoile of Satan, saith, that hee destroyed him that had the power of death, that is, the Diuell.

Sol.For the better vnderstanding of this, wee must know that those things are spoken of Christ, in sundry respects. Whereas hee redeemed vs by a ransome; that is not to bee referred vnto Satan, but vnto
God the Father, vnto whom hee gaue in ransome for vs his own bloud. According to that Ephes. 1. Ephes. 1.7▪ By whom (saith the Apostle) wee haue redemption through his bloud. And 1. Pet. 1.1. Pet. 1.18, 19. Ye are not redeemed with corruptible things, as siluer and gold &c. but with the precious bloud of Christ. And 1. Tim. 2.1. Tim. 2.6. who gaue himselfe a ransome for all men. This ransome he gaue (I say) to God his Father. For he offered himselfe vnto him as the Mediator, & the price of his bloudshed for a sacrifice: Not to Satan (as I said) but to God his Father. And therefore Heb. 9. Heb. 9.14. How much more then shall the bloud of Christ, which through the eternall Spirit offered himselfe without spot to God, &c? Againe, whereas hee is said to deliuer vs with strong hand: that is to bee referred vnto Satan, the Prince of this World, whose power and kingdome hee destroyed, deliuering them who were detained captiues.
But here againe, if it bee demanded,Ob. 2. wherefore he gaue a ransome to God the Father, seeing we were not his, but Satans prisoners?

The ransome was giuen,Sol. not to the wrongfull Tyrant, but vnto him that had
right to condemne vs, that is, to GOD, whom our first Parents and our selues Reason 3 had grieuously offended; his iustice was to bee satisfied; and whereas there was none that could doe this, but he alone that was free from all transgression, Heb. 4.15. and disobedience: He therefore sent his eternall Word, the second person in the Trinitie, to take vpon him our flesh, that beeing man like vnto vs in all things, except sin, he might, as the Apostle speaketh, Rom. 8. Rom. 8.3. condemne sinne in the flesh. For this purpose, did our Lord Iesus Christ offer himselfe to God the Father, as a ransome of redemption for vs all; that being deliuered frō the right of condemnation, and guiltinesse of sinne, we might be made at one with him.

And this atonement destroyed the strength and power of sinne, and Satan: it being vnpossible that Satan should hold them any longer prisoners, who were made at one with God, by the ransome of redemption. Now all this was done vpon the Crosse; both the ransome of our redemption was giuen to GOD the Father, to reconcile mankinde, when he shed his bloud for vs, and the power of sinne,
and Satan was destroyed withall; according to that, Heb. 2. which I noted before: and Col. 2. Col. 2.14. putting out the handwriting of Ordinances that was against vs, which was contrary to vs, he euen tooke it out of the way, and fastened it vpon the Crosse, &c.

Thus you sée some reasons, wherefore the eternall Word, and Sonne of God, Christ Iesus, tooke vpon him our nature, and ioyned the same to his Godhead, and so became both God and Man in one person, that so hee might bee a fit Reconciler, and Atonement-maker betwixt God and man. Hee vtterly to this end abolishing and taking away sinne, which was the cause of Gods iust anger. And so, as the Lord God, by his intercession, is not onely appeased, and pacified; but also by, and for his Mediators sake, hath bound himselfe with this Couenant and promise, that he will freely forgiue the sinnes of all those that truely beleeue, and that hee will not faile to giue them eternall life. This is the Couenant which the Lord hath made with vs through Christ; the which Couenant of reconciliation is dayly confirmed vnto vs in the Sacraments,
as wee shall prooue (God willing) in that which followeth.

Reason 4 Nay, we may sée further, that it was a matter of so great necessitie, that our Lord Iesus Christ should haue two natures, and be in one person both God and Man, that vnlesse he had been so, it had beene vtterly vnpossible for any flesh to be saued. So great is otherwise the disagréement betwixt our sinne and corruption, and the most excellent purenesse and cleanenesse that is in God. For seeing all our misery and destruction doth spring from hence, that wee by the corruption of our nature, are estranged, and separated from God: it must needes follow on the other side, that from hence springeth our whole saluation, that wee bee ioyned againe with God, the fountaine of life, and true felicitie. The which coniunction, by reason of the corruption of our nature, and wickednesse of our hearts, is vtterly vnpossible to be had, without a Mediator and reconciler. For we in Adam are become darkenesse, the seruants of sinne, and subiect to death and condemnation: whereas on the other side, God is Light, and in him is no darknesse at all; yea, most excellent pure,
and perfect righteousnes. And what agreement can there bee betwixt light and darknes; betweene righteousnes, and vnrighteousnes; Christ, and Belial? as 2. Cor. 6.2. Cor. 6.14, 15. Now if the Lord Iesus had not been in one person both God and Man, he could not thus haue performed the office of a Mediator; he could not by intercession, death, and redemption, haue set vs frée from the guiltinesse of sinne and death, nor from the tyranny of Satan; his righteousnes could not haue béen imputed vnto vs; he could not haue purged vs from all iniquitie, nor haue made vs coheires with him of the Kingdome of Heauen.

Some other reasons may bee added,Other Reasons, to proue the necessity of two natures in his one person. It was necessary that Christ should haue a diuine nature, and bee God, that he might know the will of God, and reueale the same vnto vs. For wee of our selues cannot see God, and his will: but we know (as Saint Iohn saith 1. Epist.) that the Son of God is come, 1. Ioh. 5. •
and hath giuen vs an vnderst • nding, that we may know him that is true. And Ioh. 1. Ioh. 1.12.26.14.2, 3. No man hath seene GOD at any time, the onely begotten Sonne which is in the bosome of the
Father, hee hath declared him.

Secondly, that the price of our Redemption might be equiualent, and of the like worthinesse, as the offence was in the sight of God, which could not haue beene, vnlesse that person, which was the Sonne of God, had dyed for vs. For neither gold nor siluer, nor any other precious thing could redeeme vs, but onely the precious bloud of Christ, who was a Lambe without blemish, 1. Pet. 1.18, 19. and without spot, as the Apostle Peter speaketh, 1. Epist. 1. Vnlesse, he had been God, he could not haue giuen vs power to become the sonnes of God; Ioh. 1.12. Heb. 7.17. he could not haue beene our eternall high Priest, nor perpetually sit at the right hand of God, Rom. 8.34. to make intercession for vs. Hee could not haue been present, at all times, and in all places, to gather his Church, to direct the hearts of the faithfull, to heare their prayers, and to forgiue their sinnes. He could not haue raised the dead to life, abolish death, exercise iudgement, nor giue eternall life to those that loue his comming.

Of the like necessitie was it, that hee should be man. First, the iustice of God did require, that as man had offended, and
brake his law and commandement: so man should also fully satisfie for the same, that his righteousnesse may iustly bee imputed vnto others. Secondly, that the appointed Messiah and Sauiour might sustaine that punishment, which by Gods sentence was due for sin, as namely Death, but GOD alone could not haue died. Thirdly, that wee might haue the more sure comfort & confidence, in our necessities to appeale to the throne of Gods grace, seeing hee being our high Priest, Heb. 4.15. was very man as we are, and partaker of our infirmities. And lastly, that we might be the more certainely assured of our resurrection, and that both in body and soule wee shall vndoubtedly enioy eternall life, séeing our Lord Iesus Christ, hauing the same nature that wee haue in all things, except sinne, hath raised it from death, and carried it with him into heauen, there as our Head, kéeping possession for vs, vntill the time, that wee, as members of his mysticall body, shall be ioyned to him. For where the Head is, there must the members be, as Ioh. 12. Ioh. 12.26. Where I am, there shall also my seruant be. And chap. 14
Ioh. 14.2, 3. I goe to prepare a place for you, I will come againe,
and receiue you vnto my selfe, that where I am, there ye may bee also. Now for some vse.

Vse 1 In that God sent downe in this sort, his eternall, and onely begotten Sonne, to take our flesh, and to become man, like vnto vs in all things, except sinne, that he comming betwixt Gods iustice and our sinnes, satisfying his iustice, and making amends for all our iniquities, might turne from vs his wrath and displeasure, and purchase for vs reconciliation with his Father, remission of sinnes, righteousnesse before GOD, and eternall life in heauen. Heerein (I say) hath God commended his loue and fauour towards vs, much more effectually and aboundantly then in any other thing whatsoeuer. When he created the world for our sakes, hee declared therein a manifest testimony of his good will towards vs; and so also when he created vs, and all other creatures for our vse: but yet in neither of these respects is his loue so apparant, as in the giuing of his Sonne: For what should wee haue beene the better for the world, or what would our creation haue any thing at all auayled vs, vnlesse wee
had beene made acceptable vnto him in his Beloued? especially considering how soone we degenerated from that integrity, and perfection wherein hee created vs, so as by nature we are now no better, then the very children of wrath, and heires of condemnation? Of this loue of God, testifieth the Scripture in many places, as Rom. 5. Rom. 5.8, 9. God commendeth his loue towards vs in that, while we were yet sinners, Christ dyed for vs, much more being iustified by his blood, wee shall be saued from wrath through him. And 1. Ioh. 4.1. Ioh. 4.9, 10. In this was manifested the loue of God towards vs, because that God sent his only begotten Sonne into the world, that we might liue through him. Herein is loue, not that we loued God, but that hee loued vs, and sent his Sonne to be the propitiation for our sinnes. And Ro. 8. Rom. 8.32. He spared not his owne Sonne, but deliuered him vp for vs all. Abraham is greatly commended in the Scripture,
••• . 22.12, 16. for that he would haue offered his sonne Isaac; and it is recorded as a token of great loue: but is not this an argument of farre greater loue, that God should giue his Sonne for vs? Hee is the God of heauen, and earth, and yet had he a gracious respect vnto vs
wretched sinners, who being naked in our selues, he cloathed vs with the righteousnesse of his Sonne, so as now our righteousnesse excelleth the righteousnesse of all others. The experience and consideration of which wonderfull loue, and kindnesse of God towards vs, ought to perswade our hearts with an vndoubted assurance and resolution, that there is nothing else of what nature and quality soeuer it be, but the Lord, out of his rich treasury, will most willingly and cheerefully impart, and communicate the same vnto vs, if in his heauenly wisedome and prouidence he seeth it to be fit for his own glory, and our good. He hath already bestowed vpon vs, the best and the most precious Iewell that hee had, namely, his dearely beloued Sonne, vnto whom no one, nor all the things in heauen and in earth, are worthy in any measure to be compared. How then (as the Apostle addeth) shall hee not with him also freely giue vs all things? It cannot be, that the Lord should denie his children any good thing, seeing for their sakes, he hath not spared his owne Sonne.

Vse 2 Secondly, as a rare and wonderfull
loue GOD the Father shewed towards man, in the sending of his Sonne, so no lesse rare and vnspeakeable loue did the Sonne himselfe expresse, in that he vouchsafed to come downe from heauen, where hee raigned in equall glory and maiestie with the Father, to take vpon him our flesh, and to submit himselfe to all our infirmities, sinne onely excepted. For by Christ we haue not onely all spirituall and heauenly blessings, as Ephe. 1. Eph. 1.5. hee being made vnto vs (as the Apostle speaketh, 1. Cor. 1.1. Cor. 1.30.) Wisedome, Righteousnesse, Sanctification, and Redemption: but whatsoeuer also belongeth to this present life, as 1. Cor. 3.1. Cor. 3.22, 23. All are yours, and ye are Christes, and Christ is Gods. Hee is the heire of all things, as Heb. 1. Heb. 1.2. and whatsoeuer the Father hath, belongeth vnto him: as Ioh. 16. Ioh. 16.15. All things that the Father hath, are mine. And wee through the grace and mercy of God, are adopted co-heires with him, as Rom. 8. Rom. 8.17. Whereupon it must needes follow, that if we haue Christ the Lord, and heire of all good things, there is no cause for vs to doubt, but that whatsoeuer is fit and necessary, shall be imparted vnto vs.

Vse 3 Thirdly, whereas our Lord Iesus Christ, being in one person both God and man, hath ouercome Death and the Deuill, vnder whose captiuity we were holden, hath satisfied Gods iustice for our sinnes, and reconciled vs vnto him: It is not that we should liue at our owne liberty and disposition, and behaue our selues as we think good: but that (as the Apostle speaketh, Rom. 14. Ro. 14.8, 9.) Whether wee liue or die, we might be the Lords. For Christ therfore dyed, rose againe, and reuiued, that hee might be Lord both of the dead and liuing. That which a man hath dearely bought, and duly payd for, he may well account it to stand with great reason, that the same should be wholly at his direction, and not at the wil and commandement of another. Our Lord Iesus Christ hath dearely bought vs, being vtterly lost in our selues, not with gold or siluer, but with his owne precious blood, as I noted before; and therefore doth it stand with great equity and reason, that we should now be wholly imployed in the seruice of his Maiesty, and not in the seruice of our owne lusts, and corrupt affections, as by nature wee are enclined. This was the end of
Christes incarnation, wherefore he tooke vpon him our sinnes, with the curse and condemnation due vnto them, that we being deliuered from the guiltinesse of sin, Luke 1.74, 75. Tit. 2.14. from the wrath of God, and torments of hell, might be his peculiar people, sanctified to serue him in holinesse and righteousnesse all the dayes of our life; euermore acknowledging, that the best seruice we can doe, is vtterly of no value, in comparison of the least of his mercies towards vs.

div.head: Quest. 11. How did Christ performe this, according to his flesh, and humane nature?
div.p: Answ. By his humiliation, and suffrings, wherein hee became obedient vnto the death, euen to the death of the Crosse, Phil. 2.7, 8.

div.head: EXPOSITION.
div.p:
OVR Lord Iesus Christ, being anoynted to be our high Priest, (not according to the order of Aaron, who needed a Successour but) according to the order of Melchizedech, to
continue for euer, was appointed of God his Father, Heb. 7.3. to be a propitiatory sacrifice, and satisfaction for our sinnes by his sufferings, as by the onely sacrifice of reconciliation, to deliuer both our bodies and soules from eternall death and condemnation, and to purchase for vs the fauour of God, righteousnesse, and life. By his sufferings (I say) the which to this end, and to bring this to passe, how great and wonderful they were, what sorrowes and temptations hee endured, and into what low and base condition for this cause hee was brought, and submitted himselfe vnto: The Euangelist Mathew, chap. 26. and Luke, chap. 22. Math. 26.37, &c. Luke 22.4, &c. doe expresse at large: As how hee began to wax sorrowfull, and grieuously troubled, and as one full of anguish, said vnto his Disciples, My soule is heauy euen vnto the death: That such was his terrour and feare, that he not onely at two seuerall times desired his heauenly Father to deliuer him from the bitternesse of his Crosse and Passion; and so wonderfully cast downe, that there was neede of the presence of an Angell to comfort him, and for very paine and griefe swet drops of blood, but also as one almost
vtterly giuen ouer, and despairing of release, cryed out, My God, my God,
Math. 27.16. why hast thou forsaken mee? This was vndoubtedly a wonderfull abasement, and humiliation, most bitter anguish and extremity, the like whereof hath neuer been felt, neither can possibly be endured of any other. And what was the reason of it? Hauing taken vpon him the burthen and Reason 1 guiltinesse of all our sinnes, which were most wonderfull loathsome, and odious before the face of God, and with the huge weight whereof hee was grieuously pressed; and therewithall also setting before his eyes, the Tribunall seat of God, and the heauenly Iudge himselfe, ready armed with incomprehensible vengeance against the same: No maruaile if (his Godhead, being as it were hid, and remaining secret for a time) according to his flesh, and humane nature, he was after this manner so wonderfully perplexed and amazed, though he so bitterly complained and cryed out. He conceiued in death, somewhat more terrible then the separation of the soule from the body, as namely, the horrible curse and punishment, which, in the wrath and iudgement of God, was iustly
kindled against our sinnes, the guiltinesse whereof he had so taken vpon him, that he was of necessity to sustaine, whatsoeuer the extremity of their haynousnesse had deserued. From hence procéeded his feare, Reason 2 his sorrow, and tribulation. For what is more heauy, what more intolerable then the wrath and vengeance of God? What comparison can there bee betwixt that which hath an end, and that which hath no end? The wrath of God is endlesse, the strength of man, in respect thereof, vtterly nothing at all; infinitely and to far too weake for the Maiestie of God. This so great wrath of God, did our Lord Iesus Christ féele sensibly and indéede, in his whole humanity, both in soule and body. For we must not thinke that bodily death it selfe, could so haue terrified the Sonne of God, if he had not séene and considered, that hee was to vndergoe the wrath and iudgement of God.

Thus farre did it please our Lord Iesus Christ to humble and abase himselfe for our sakes, and by such humiliation and sufferings, to performe the part and office of a perfect Sauiour and Redéemer. Of all which there was so great necessity,
that without the same, the mysterie of our saluation could not possibly haue béene fulfilled.

If hee had not suffered these anguishes Reason 3 and extremities at all, we should haue remained in the guiltinesse of sin and death, without any hope of eternall life. If hee had suffered but onely in body, he should haue béene the Redéemer and Sauiour only of our bodies: It was of necessity therfore, that our Sauiour and Redéemer should both in body and soule sustaine the curse and punishment due vnto our sins, that so through Faith in his redemption, we might both in body and soule be eternally blessed. This was the cause of his humiliation and sufferings, yea of whatsoeuer he endured both in soule and body. Wherefore hee became our high Priest, and made himselfe an offering and a sacrifice for sin, yea such a sacrifice, as wherevnto the very curse of God was ioyned: As Gal. 3. Gal. 3.13. Christ hath redeemed vs from the curse of the Law, when hee was made a curse for vs; for it is written,
Deut. 21.23 Cursed is euery one that hangeth on tree. He tooke that to himselfe which was ours that he might impart vnto vs that which was his; hee
tooke our sinnes and cursednesse to him: he indued, and enriched vs with his blessednes. For this cause in diuers places of the Scripture, is he called Sinne, and an offering for sinne: As 2. Cor. 5.2. Cor. 5.21. Hee hath made him to be sinne for vs, which knew no sinne, that wee should be made the righteousnesse of God in him. And Es. 53. Esa. 53. Yet the Lord would breake him, and make him subiect to infirmities, when hee shall make his soule an offering for sinne. For this, no doubt, did all the Prophets fore sée in Spirit, that our Lord Iesus Christ should be accounted the greatest sinner and transgressor, that euer was vpō the face of the earth. Not that hee himselfe had any spot of sinne, but because he tooke the sinnes of the world vpon him, and for them dyed vpon the Crosse. For this cause it was, that (as the Prophet fore-told) hee was accounted among transgressours and trespassers. Whatsoeuer sinnes either haue béene committed, are, or shall be hereafter, by any, or all of Gods elect and chosen, from the beginning of the world vnto the end, they were all imputed vnto Christ, and hee bare the burthen of them: According to that of the Prophet againe, He is
despised, and reiected, hee is a man full of sorrowes, and hath experiences of infirmities: we hid (as it were) our faces from him, he was despised, and we esteemed him not. Surely hee hath borne our infirmities,
Esa. 53.3, 4, 5, 6, 8. and carried our sorrowes, yet we did iudge him, as plagued, and smitten of God, and humbled. But hee was wounded for our transgressions, he was broken for our iniquities, the chastisement of our peace vvas vpon him, and with his stripes we are healed. All wee like Sheepe haue gone astray, wee haue turned euery one to his owne way, and the Lord hath layd vpon him the iniquity of vs all. And a little after, For the transgression of my people was he plagued. Whereunto agréeth that of the Apostle Peter, 1.1. Pet. 2.25. Epist. 2. Who his owne selfe, bare our sinnes in his body on the tree, that vvee being deliuered from sinne, should liue in righteousnesse, by vvhose stripes ye vvere healed. For this cause, Ioh. 1. Joh. 1.29. is he called the Lamb of God vvhich taketh away the sinne of the vvorld. And Heb 10. Heb. 10.14, 18. the Apostle saith, that vvith one offering hee consecrated for euer them that are sanctified. All these places serue plainely to proue, that our Lord Iesus Christ, when he purchased for vs eternall
redemption, offered himselfe for a sacrifice vpon the Crosse, that he might sanctifie vs for euer. The force and efficacie of which sacrifice, continueth without any end: According to this most comfortable sentence, a little after in the very same Chapter, Where remission of these things is, there is no more offering for sinne.

The Instruments which the Lord vsed to bring Christ vnto his death, were most wicked, as Satan, the high Priests, Iudas and Pilate; for who, but such as were most wicked, could haue found in their hearts to accuse, and condemne him, that was most innocent and harmelesse? Yet the Lord vsed them in such sort, as by their meanes, that worke was brought to passe, which of all other workes of God, was most holy, and most admirable, as namely, the Redemption of Gods Elect. These wicked ones, although they apprehended Christ, arraigned, accused, condemned, and crucified him, yet was his death neuerthelesse a voluntary and willing death, freely, and of his owne accord, giuing vp himselfe to suffer all that was inflicted. For if he had beene vnwilling to dye, and
had not willingly yeelded himselfe into their hands; neither they, nor all the world could possibly so farre haue preuailed against him: According to that, Io. 10. Ioh. 10.17, 18. I lay down my life, that I might take it againe: No man taketh it from me, but I lay it downe of my selfe: I haue power to lay it downe, and haue power to take it againe; this commandement haue I receiued of my Father. And this is also further manifest by the mighty power which hee expressed, in throwing the armed multitude to the ground, which came to apprehend him, as Ioh. 18. Ioh. 18.6. For, assoone as he had said vnto them, I am hee, they went backward, and fell to the ground. And by his speech to Peter, Math. 26. Math. 26.53, 54. Thinkest thou that I cannot now pray to my Father, and he will giue mee moe then twelue legions of Angels? how then should the Scriptures be fulfilled, which say that it must be so? Hee might also haue preuented Iudas, and confounded him in his deuillish purpose, before it tooke any effect at all, if it had so pleased him, seeing he perfectly knew the same beforehand, as we may see, Mat. 26. Ioh. 13. Mat. 26.21 Ioh. 13 26. But for our sakes he would not, but would rather suffer the wicked Traytor
to haue his deuillish desire, and to endure the vttermost villany that the tyrannous Iewes could doe vnto him; rather, I say, then any part of our Redemption should remaine vnperformed, the which without this manner of humiliation and suffering, could not possibly haue been effected. For this cause, said he not to Iudas, Leaue off thy deuillish purpose: but, That thou doest,
Ioh. 13.27. doe quickly. Neither said he to Peter, Fight manfully, and get my deliuerance by force of Armes: but, Put vp thy Sword into his place,
Mat. 26.52 for all that take the sword, shall perish with the Sword.

Vse 1 And now who can sufficiently admire and maruell at it? Who can sufficiently ertoll, and magnifie this wonderfull loue of the Sonne of God? Wee were not his friends, but his enemies, by reason of our sinnes; and yet, that hee should endure such, and so many things for vs: this is assuredly such rare and surpassing kindnes, as can neuer be sufficiently expressed: For what would haue become of vs, and of our saluation, if he had not thus farre abased himselfe; the iustice of God, being not possibly to haue beene satisfied any other way? For sinne is so odious in the
sight of God, that he cannot but punish it with an extreme punishment wheresoeuer he findeth it. Our Lord Iesus Christ then standing in our roome, was therfore of necessitie, not onely to suffer the miseries of this life, but also to dye, that the very extremity of the punishment, which we had deserued, and which wee should haue borne, being laid vpon him, wee in him might fully satisfie the iustice of God, and so haue cause to glory with the Apostle, Rom. 8. Rom. 8.33, 34, 35, &c. and to say, Who shall lay any thing to the charge of Gods Elect? It is God that iustifieth; who is he that condemneth? It is Christ that dyed, yea, rather that is risen againe, who is euen at the right hand of God, who also maketh intercession for vs; who shall separate vs from the loue of Christ, &c? And a little after; I am perswaded that neither death, nor life, nor Angels, &c. shall be able to separate vs from the loue of God, which is in Christ Iesus our Lord.

Secondly, although it is manifest, that Vse 2 the death of Christ depended vpon Gods Decree, and nothing came to passe in his humiliation, and sufferings, but what God had determined for the glory of his name, and for the good and saluation of
his people, according to his owne words, Math. 26. Mat. 26.24 and Luke 24. Luk. 24.46. and to that of the Apostles, Acts 2. & chap. 4. Acts. 2.23. chap. 4.27, 28. yet it followeth not, that either Iudas, or any of the other instruments whom God vsed, are therefore in any measure to bee commended, or excused; but rather to bee accounted (as they were indeed) most bloudy and cruell murtherers of the innocent and guiltlesse; forasmuch as they had no respect at all, either to the fulfilling of the Lords Decree, or to the saluation of his people, but were carried to iniquity; some by malice, some by pride, some by couetousnesse, some by one vngodly and carnall respect, and some by another: According as all obiections herein, most notably preuenteth the Apostle Peter in the same place of Acts 2. where hee saith expressely, that hee was taken by the hands of the wicked. And whereas our Lord Iesus Christ pronounceth a most fearefull woe and curse vpon Iudas, Math. 26. Mat. 26.24. that it had beene good for him that he had neuer been borne. Whereby it is cleere, that although it was ye Decree of God, that Christ should suffer all that he did (which Decree in it selfe was good and holy) yet the execution
of the Decree, in regard of the instruments, was most wicked; and farre better it had beene for them all, (as Christ said of Iudas) if they had neuer beene borne.

Thirdly, the truth of this point directly Vse 3 tendeth to the confutation of the Papists, who, besides the alone Passion and sufferings of Christ, most grossely and wickedly maintaine workes of satisfaction; partly of their owne, and partly of the Saints departed, which they adde to the Passion of Christ, as though that alone were not sufficient, cleane contrary to the many testimonies of the Scripture which haue beene remembred. And whereas they also blasphemously affirme, that in Christ we haue forgiuenesse of the fault, but not of the punishment: they manifestly spurne against the Word of God, which plainely teacheth, that Christ is our Sauiour, Redeemer, and Aduocate; who hath deliuered vs, not onely from part of our sinnes, but from all our sins; not onely from part of the punishment, which our sinnes had deserued, but also from euery part thereof, as we haue seene sufficiently proued in that which goeth before. And
indeed, it should otherwise greatly impeach the wisedome of God, if hee should send downe his Sonne, the second person in the Trinity, into this vale of misery, heere to take our flesh, & in the forme of a Seruant, and abiect man, to suffer a most vile and reprochfull death, and all to bee in the end but a party-Redeemer, and a party-Sauiour, and to yéeld a great part of the glory and honour thereof vnto another. No, no, he is God, he giueth not his glory vnto others. He onely (onely hee, I say) is our full, and perfect Reconciler and Redeemer, and all the residue that I haue spoken of before. This is the doctrine of the glorious Gospell of Christ, which we teach, beleeue, and professe: this is no new doctrine, but that which was conceiued in the bosome of Gods wisedome, before the beginning of the world.

Vse 4 Last of all, the consideration of Christs death and sufferings, must worke in vs a godly sorrow for our sins; forasmuch as our sins were the cause of all the paines, sorrowes, and calamities, which our Lord Iesus Christ did sustaine, and indure, both in life and death. So often (I say) as we remember the humiliation and sufferings
of our Lord Iesus Christ, so often should we thinke vpon our sinnes, arraigning, as it were, accusing, and condemning our selues in regard of them: and euermore withall keep this in mind, that Christ suffered not for himselfe, but for our offences, which were the proper cause of all his woe and misery. And therefore, as Christs Passion was grieuous, and bitter vnto him; so should our sinnes bee bitter and grieuous vnto vs. This wee must alwayes remember, and this vse (among the rest) we must be religiously carefull to make, as often as wee thinke vpon the Death and Passion of Christ; or else shall wee neuer reape any sound benefit thereby.

div.head: Quest. 12. How is Christs obedience, and the fruit and effect of his humiliation and sufferings, applyed vnto vs, and made ours? Answ. By a true and liuely faith, Mar. 16.16. Luke 7.50. Ioh. 5.24. Act. 10.43. Acts 13.39. Rom. 3.23, 24, 28. Quest. 13. What is a true and liuely faith?
div.p: Answ. A true and liuely faith is a supernaturall worke, wrought in the heart of man by the Spirit of God, whereby we apprehend, receiue, and apply vnto our selues, Iesus Christ, with all his benefits, righteousnesse, and Redemption, Mat. 16.17. Rom. 10.9. 1. Cor. 12.9. Rom. 4.5. Gal. 2.16. Gal. 3.11, 14, 22. Ephes. 2.8.

div.head: EXPOSITION.
div.p:
THis word Faith is diuersly taken in the Scripture; but the question beeing heere of a true and liuely Faith, which is the instrumentall meanes
of our saluation, I will not speake of it in any other sence, but prosecute the point, according to the definition which I haue propounded: That Faith is a supernaturall worke: that is to say, a worke not wrought by the nature or will of man, but which is of the free gift of God the Father; and so, as they who truely beleeue, do beleeue through the grace & mercy of God. This is manifest by the plentifull testimonies of the Scripture: As Ioh. 6.
Ioh. 6.37.44. All that the Father giueth me (saith Christ) shall come vnto me. And a little after: No man can come to mee, except the Father which hath sent mee, draw him. Plainely thereby teaching, that it is vnpossible for any, either to attaine vnto the true knowledge of him, or to take hold of his obedience, righteousnes, and redemption, with a true and liuely faith, vnlesse it please God to illuminate their mindes, and to bend and frame their hearts & affections thereunto. To this agreeth the answere of our Sauiour againe vnto Peter, Math. 16.
Math. 16.16, 17. Where, after Peter had made this notable confession of faith, saying; Thou art Christ the Sonne of the liuing God: Iesus said vnto him, Blessed art thou Simon the
sonne of Ionas; for flesh and bloud hath not reuealed this vnto thee, but my Father Reason 1 which is in Heauen. Vnder the person of one man, admonishing all men thereby, that faith is a speciall gift and grace of God, and that the whole praise therof must be attributed onely to him, forasmuch as our mindes by nature, are vtterly void of vnderstanding, to perceiue the mysteries of the heauenly wisedome hidden in Christ: and all our sences faile in this behalfe, vntill God doe open our eyes, to see his glory in the face of Iesus Christ: To another is giuen faith by the same Spirit, saith the Apostle, 1. Cor. 12. And for this cause, did our Lord Iesus Christ promise vnto his Disciples the Spirit of Truth, Ioh. 14 and chap. 15.
Ioh. 14.16.26. cha. 15.26. vnto which Spirit he assigneth this proper office, to teach them all things, and to bring all things to their remembrance which hee had told them, because in daine should the light shew it selfe to the blind; vnlesse the same spirit of vnderstanding should open the eyes of their minde. So that the holy Spirit of God may rightly bee called the Key, by which the treasures of the heauenly Kingdome are opened vnto vs: and
his inlightening ye eye-sight (as it were) of our minde, to see & take hold. And for this cause also doth the Apostle Paul, 1. Cor. 3.6, &c.
2. Cor. 3. so much commend the Ministery of the Spirit, because in vaine, & vtterly without fruit or profit, should the Ministers and preachers of the Gospell, teach and preach vnto the people, vnlesse Christ the inward teacher of the heart, doe draw all those hearers with his holy Spirit, to faith and obedience, whom God his Father hath giuen vnto him.

The seat and abiding place of this true and liuely faith, and wherein it is planted by the holy Spirit of God, is the heart or soule of man: Insomuch, that as there is no worke good, except it proceed from faith, (for whatsoeuer is not of faith,
Ro. 14.23 •
is sinne) so is there no true faith, except it be rooted in the heart. For with the heart, man beleeueth vnto righteousnesse, as the Apostle speaketh, Ro. 10.
Rom. 10.10 Now that faith which is seated in the heart, as it consisteth not in a generall knowledge, and perswasion of Christ, but layeth sure hold vpon the promises of God in him: so doth it continue in him that once hath it, vntill he enioy the end thereof, which is the saluation
of his soule. And as it is thus constant as touching the abiding; so also as touching the fruits and effects thereof, in holinesse and righteousnesse of life. So that as a good tree will bring forth good fruit; Mat 7.16, 17, 18. so he that is a faithfull man, will be sure to glorifie God in good workes.

But now in the third place, to make it yet more plaine, that it is the nature and property of a true and liuely faith, to apprehend, receiue, and apply Christ Iesus his righteousnesse, benefits, and redemption, to the free and particular forgiuenesse of the sinnes; to the iustification and saluation of euery one that hath it: And because this is a matter of great importance, and most necessarie to comfort and confirme the consciences of all Gods children; howsoeuer the Papists (measuring the portion of Gods Children by their owne carnall sence and conceit) doe contradict, and spurne against it: I will therefore spend a little more time in the opening of it.

Reason 2 Such a faith doth the Spirit of God plant now in our hearts, as was begotten in the hearts of men by our Sauiour Christ himselfe. For as there is but one
God; so there is but one true and iustifying faith, as Ephes. 4.
E • hes. 4.5. but by that faith they were particularly perswaded of the remission of their sinnes, and of their iustification consequently, and saluation, as appeareth, Luke 7.
Luke 7.48.50. where our Sauiour saith to the Woman, Thy sinnes are forgiuen thee; thy Faith hath saued thee: Goe in peace. So Math. 9.
Math. 9.2. Hee saith to the sicke of the Palsie, Bee of good comfort, thy sinnes are forgiuen thee. And therefore the faith which is now begotten in vs, doth also particularly perswade vs of the remission of our sinnes, and of eternall saluation.

Secondly, the Apostle saith, Ephes. 3.
Ephes. 3.12.
Reason 3 that through faith, we haue entrance vnto God, with boldnesse and confidence. And therefore by faith the Beleeuer is particularly perswaded of the remission of his sinnes, and of his reconciliation with with God. For with what boldnesse or confidence can a poore sinner come before God, being terrified with the threatnings of the Law, with the temptations of Satan, and with the consideration of his owne vnworthinesse, and selfe-guiltinesse, if it be not particularly assured, that
his curse is borne by Christ; that hee is forgiuen the whole debt of his sinnes, and reconciled vnto God.

Reason 4 Thirdly, whatsoeuer wee are bound to pray for, that we may be assured of; nay, we ought stedfastly to beléeue that we shal receiue it: As this is euident, 1. Ioh. 5. 1. Ioh. 5.14, 15. This is the assurance that wee haue in him, that if wee aske any thing according to his will, he heareth vs. And if wee know that hee heareth vs, whatsoeuer wee aske, wee know that wee haue the petitions that wee haue desired of him. And the Apostle S. Iames, chap. 1.
Iam. 1.6. would haue vs aske in faith without wauering: that is, not doubting to receiue that we aske: but we are taught to pray for remission of our sinnes: Math 6.12. therefore we ought certainely to beleeue that our sinnes are remitted; and so consequen • ly, that wee are iustified, called, elected, and shall bee saued: as Rom. 8.
Rom. 8.30. Whom hee did predestinate, them also hee called; whom hee called, them also he iustified; and whom he iustified, them also he glorified.

Reason 5 Againe, that faith is not a doubtfull opinion, but a certaine perswasion; not a generall notion, but a particular assurance,
whereby wee doe apply and appropriate vnto our selues those things which we doe beleeue, touching Election, Iustification, and Saluation: it may appeare by the properties, and names which are giuen vnto it in the Word of God: As Heb. 11.
Heb. 11.1. where faith is said to be a subsistence, ground, or present being, of things hoped for. So that hope waiteth for them in time to come; but faith enioyeth them as being present: as namely, in respect of the certaine assurance, and particular application of the promises vnto our selues. It is there also called an euidence, which word is quite contrary to doubting, as signifying a manifest demonstration. In Chapter 10. there is also ascribed vnto it fulnesse of perswasion; Heb. 10.22. Let vs drawe neere with a true heart, in full assurance of Faith. Which full assurance we cannot haue, if wee stand in doubt of Gods loue, and whether we belong to him or no.

The testimonies of the Scripture are herein also very plaine: As 1. Iohn 3. 1. Io • . 3.14. where hee saith not that we hope well, but that we know, neither that wee shall be; but, We know that wee are translated from death to life, because we loue the brethren.
And Rom. 5. where hee saith not, that we wauer, Rom. 5.2. or stagger, but that wee stand firm • ly by faith; that wee doe not feare nor timorously hope, but euen glory, and triumph in our reioycing: the words are these: Wee haue accesse through Faith vnto Gods grace, wherein wee stand and reioyce vnder hope.

So that although our sinnes bee manifold▪ our vnworthinesse great, and our faith weake, yet if it be true, it may also be certaine in the assurance of Gods loue to eternall life: because it is not grounded vpon our worthinesse, but vpon Gods frée Reason 6 iustifying, and accepting of vs as righteous in Christ: and vpon Christs Death, Resurrection, and Intercession for vs, which is a most sure foundation, that cannot faile.

Hereunto may further be added the examples of the deare Seruants of GOD, whose faith hath remained firme, & without wauering in the times of great tryals, and temptations. As of Abrahams faith, as the Apostle speakes of it, Rom. 4.
Rom. 4.18. & • . Of Dauid, Psal. 23.
Psal. 23.4. Though I walk through the valley of the shadow of death, I vvill feare no euill, for thou art with mee. And
Psal. 27.
Psal. 27.1. The Lord is my light, and my saluation, whom shall I feare? The Lord is the strength of my life, of whom shall I bee afraid? So Iob in the midst of his afflictions, sheweth his certaine assurance and Faith, as chap. 13. Though he slay me,
Iob 13.15. chap. 19.25, 26. yet will I trust in him. And chap. 19. I know that my Redeemer liueth, &c. And how confidently doth the Apostle Paul speake to this purpose, Rom. 8.
Rom. 8 38. when hee saith that he is perswaded, that nothing shall bee able to separate vs from the loue of GOD?
But to proceed to some vse.

As the Papists, in denying faith to be a Vse 1 confident and sure perswasion, doe spoile it of the better part of it; so in affirming that faith is not necessarily ioyned with knowledge; but that it is inough for common Catholikes to say, that they beleeue, as the Church beleeueth, though they know nothing themselues in particular; they rob it of another part: For faith cannot stand with ignorance, but necessarily bringeth wt it an illumination of the mind, as it worketh stablenes in the heart. How shall they beleeue in him (saith the Apostle, Rom. 10.
R • m. 10.14 1. Pet. 3.15. of whom they haue not heard? And Saint Peter saith, chapter 3. that wee
〈2 pages missing〉
apply to our selues the promises of Gods free grace, and mercy in Christ Iesus. For in the question of saluation, these two, Faith, and Christ crucified, haue a mutuall relation, and must alwayes concurre, and be ioyned together. Faith, as the instrument which apprehendeth; and Christ, as the obiect, which is apprehended. For neither doth the Passion of Christ saue without Faith, neither doth Faith helpe, except it bee in Christ. In whomsoeuer these two thus accord, and ioyne together, that man may rightly be said to be in the state of grace, and so stand vpright in the way of saluation.

This Faith thus seated in the heart by the Spirit of God, maketh those that haue it, patient in aduersity, thankfull in prosperity, zealous, and resolute in the truth, and fruitfull in the workes of holinesse and righteousnes, Gal. 3.26. which are by Iesus Christ to the glory and praise of God. It maketh, Rom. 5.1. of the children of wrath, the Children of God. It effecteth in vs true peace of conscience; it purifieth the heart, as Acts 15.
Acts 15.9. 1. Pet. 1.9. Rom. 14.23 and the end of it, as the Apostle Peter teacheth, is the saluation of the soule. Without this faith we can doe nothing
but sinne; wee cannot please God; yea, without this Faith, Heb. 11 6. there is no remedy but to die, and perish in our sinnes. For as it is Ioh. 8.
Ioh. 8.24. Except ye beleeue that I am he, ye shall dye in your sinnes.

Thirdly, seeing this Faith is so necessary Vse 3 to saluation, that Iesus Christ doth profit him nothing at all that is without it: it standeth vs highly vpon, by the vse of all ordinary meanes which the Lord hath vouchsafed, to make our selues sure of it, and to grow, and goe forward therein daily more and more. The Apostles had some Faith in Christ, euen when he first called them; but how notably they increased therein, the History of the Gospell doth plainely record. As also how necessary they accounted the growth and encrease of Faith to be, for the comfortable assurance of their saluation: their humble prayer vnto Christ, Luke 17▪
Luke 17.5. saying, Lord, increase our Faith, doth manifestly approue. Many other examples of the growth, and increase of the Faith of Gods Elect, there are in the Scripture, as of those that were conuerted by Peter, Acts 2.
Acts 2.41, 44. Of the Eunuch baptized by Philip, Acts 8. Of Cornelius, cha. 10.
Acts 8.39. Cha. 10.15. Of the Gentiles,
cha. 13. of Lydia. cha. 16. And of Dionysius, Damaris, and certain other, Act. 17.
Chap. 17.34 Euery one of these notably tending to proue, that through the sanctifying grace of Gods Spirit, it is an inseparable property of Gods Children, after they are once called to grow, and increase from Faith to Faith, not to stand at a stay, but to be alwayes going forward, vntill they attaine vnto such an excellent measure and perfection, as that resolutely & without doubting, and wauering, they be able in particular to say of themselues, that nothing shall preuaile, to depriue them of their saluation, nor to make voyde the loue and fauour of God towards them in Christ Iesus. This, of all other degrees of Faith, is the most excellent: and vnto this degree must euery Christian (vpon the danger of condemnation) labour to attaine; and so, as how ignorant, doubtfull, and wauering soeuer they bee in other matters, (yet through the witnesse of Gods Spirit in their hearts) they rest resolutely assured of the truth of Gods promises, to their saluation.

div.head: Quest. 14. By what ordinary meanes doth the holy Ghost worke this Faith, in the hearts of Gods children.
div.p: Answ. By the Ministerie and Preaching of Gods word, Rom. 10.14, 17. Ioh. 5.24.

div.head: EXPOSITION.
div.p:
