THat the hearing of the Gospell preached, is the ordinary meanes, which the Lord hath sanctified, for the begetting and planting of Faith in the hearts of his Elect, and so, as without the ordinary meanes of Preaching, there is no ordinary way to attaine to Faith, and so consequently, no ordinary hope or assurance either of a comfortable deliuerance from the power of darknes, or of a glorious exaltation to the light of life. This is manifestly proued, Ioh. 12. Ioh. 12.16, 4 • . Whosoeuer beleeueth in mee, (saith Christ) shall not remaine in darknesse; and if any man heare my words (that is, the Doctrine of my Gospell preached) and beleeue not, &c. Which plainely importeth, that howsoeuer
some may heare, and not beleeue; yet is hearing the ordinary meanes appointed of GOD, for the obtayning of Faith. This is further confirmed, Rom. 10. Rom. 10.14, 17. Faith commeth by hearing, and hearing by the Word of God: And a little before, How shall they heare, without a Preacher? And Acts 16. Acts 16.31, 32. said the keeper of the prison to Paul and Sylas, What must I doe to be saued? And they said, Beleeue in the Lord Iesus Christ, and thou shalt be saued, and thine houshold. And they preached vnto him the Word of GOD. We may see also, Ioh. 5. how our Lord Iesus Christ restrayneth the assurance of saluation, vnto those that heare his Word, and by the hearing therof attaine vnto Faith. Verily, verily, I say vnto you, he that heareth my Word, & beleeueth in him that sent me, hath euerlasting life, &c. Plainly thereby insinuating, that as without Faith there is no saluation, so no Faith ordinarily, without the hearing of the Word. Extraordinarily the Lord hath, and may giue Faith, without the hearing of the Word preached: but that ordinarily hee neither hath, nor will, besides the Testimonies already alledged, the History of the Eunuch, Acts 8. doth
clearely approoue. It being there recorded, that although hee read the Prophet Esay very diligently, yet could hee not attaine so much as to a sound knowledge, much lesse to a true Faith, vntill Philip (by the instinct of the Spirit) preached Christ vnto him. Vnderstandest thou (saith Philip) what thou readest?
Acts 8.30, 31, 35. How can I (saith hee) except I had a guide? that is, one to open and expound it vnto me. And a little after it followeth, that Philip opened his mouth, and began at the same Scripture, and preached vnto him Iesus. For this cause is it recorded to the commendation of a great multitude, Luke 5. Luke 5.1. that they preased vpon Christ, to heare the Word of God. And cha. 12. Chap. 12.1. that there gathered together such an innumerable multitude of people to that end, that they trode one another. Commēdable also is the example of Cornelius, Acts 10. Acts 10.7, &c. Acts 16.14. Acts 17.34 Ioh. 8.47. in hearing the Word of God, and in sending for Peter to that end: of Lydia, Dionysius, Damaris, &c. Also Io. 8. He that is of GOD (saith our Sauiour) heareth Gods Word, that is, hee will hunger and thirst after it, and earnestly desire to be fed and nourished by it. But hee that hath no care to heare the Word • f God, he plainly
discouereth himselfe, not to be of God; For doth not Christ say, Ioh. 10.27. My Sheepe heare my voyce? And the Apostle saith as you heard before, that Faith commeth by hearing: we are not Christs then, vnlesse we heare his voyce, neither can wee haue Faith, vnlesse the Doctrine of the Gospel sound vnto vs: and as without Faith there is no saluation: so, no Christ, no God. Luke 20.38 Gal. 2.20. For God is not the God of the dead, but of the liuing, and to liue without Faith we cannot, and to haue Faith without the hearing of the Gospell, it is vnpossible, vnlesse it please God to deale extraordinarily, which hee doth not vse to doe at this day: And therefore wee must not tempt him in looking for it.

But now to make this plaine withall, that the holy Spirit of God must worke together with the Ministery of the Word, for the settling and establishing of Faith in the hearts of those that heare it, or else the outward sound thereof in the eare, wil be vtterly fruitlesse, and doe no good in this behalfe. Hereof there was sufficient experience in the most part, of those that heard the voyce of Christ, Ioh. 5.38. whiles he was conuersant in the world. Few among the
whole multitude, faithfully beléeuing, Io •
12.37▪ 38. and embracing his Word. This was also manifest in the example of Pharao, who although hee were oftentimes exhorted, and admonished to yeeld, and submit himselfe, Exod. 9 34, 35. and that with expresse messages from Gods owne mouth, yet for want of this grace, his heart nothing at all relented, but he waxed worse and worse. And this is also too manifest at this day by lamentable experience. The Word of God, although most purely preached, and plainly pronounced, yet sounding in the eares of the greatest part, as if it were vttered with a stammering tongue, & in a strange language, as the Prophet Esay speakes, Esay 28.11. Chap. 28. becommeth vnto them as the words of a booke that is sealed vp, daily hearing, but little profiting, and this is through want of the gracious assistance of Gods blessed Spirit: the voyce of the Minister without this, (let his Doctrine be neuer so good, and holy, & pronounced with neuer so great zeale, and desire of the peoples saluation) onely sounding in the eare, & being vtterly vnable to pierce the hart. So truly it is said that Paul planted, 1. Cor. 3.6. Apollos watred, but God gaue the increase.

This alwayes herewithall being duly obserued, that how fewe soeuer doe profit by Gods Word to Faith and Saluation, and how obstinately soeuer the greater part doe oppose themselues, and harden their hearts: yet is the Word neuer preached in vaine, nor the labour fruitlesse that is bestowed herein: the name of God being glorified, and his will fulfilled, euen as well in the hardning of the wicked, and in the making them without excuse, as in the calling and saluation of such as doe belong vnto him. According as to this effect speaketh the Lord himselfe, Es. 55. and the Apostle Paul,
Es 55 10, 11. 2. Cor. 2.15, 16. 2. Cor. 2. Wee are vnto God (saith he) the sweet sauour of Christ, in them that are saued, and in them that perish; to the one wee are the sauour of death vnto death, and to the other, the sauour of life, vnto life.

But now, that the Doctrine of the Gospel, which is in it selfe▪ the sauour of life, and the power of God to saluation, should thus be a sauour of life, and a Word of saluation but vnto some, and a sauour of death, to the death and destruction of many that heare it, that it should be effectuall, to open the eyes of some, and to sanctifie
their hearts, and to blinde the eyes, and harden the hearts of others: This commeth to passe, as in the Lords speciall loue and fauour towards his Elect, and chosen Saints, in regard of whom reioyceth our Lord Iesus Christ, Luke 10. Luke 10.21 and giueth thanks vnto his heauenly Father: euen so, through his iust and righteous iudgements, vpon the malice, infidelity, prophanenesse, and hard-heartednesse of such wicked ones, who are ready to peruert euery good thing to their own destruction, and to take occasion by the Word of life, and health, to haue their venome stirred vp, for the poysoning & infecting of their soules and bodies much more dangerously then before: No otherwise then a sore eye by the light of the Sunne, and by looking stedfastly vpon it, becomes much worse, and more incurable then before.

And now to make some vse: is it so, Vse 1 that it is not enough for the attayning of the true sauing, and iustifying Faith, to come to the hearing of the Gospell preached, vnlesse the grace of Gods Spirit be graciously present to prepare, and sanctifie the eares, and the hearts, and to make it powerfull, and effectuall to the peace, and
〈2 pages missing〉
certaine means to keep off death, and for a time to maintaine life, so hath ye soule certain means to preserue the life therof, and to put away death. The meanes to preserue the life of the body, is (as you know) meate, and drinke, as the Prophet Dauid, Psal. 136.
〈◊〉 . ••• .23 speaking of God, saith, which giueth foode to all flesh, shewing thereby that all flesh hath neede to bee sustayned with foode. For we quickly hunger, if we want the same, and not onely hunger, but euen consume and perish. Now, looke what meate and drinke is to the body, so is the preaching of the Word of GOD to the soule, that is, vnto the nourishing and Reason 1 strengthening of Faith in the soule, because by the continuall preaching of the Word, our Faith is daily confirmed in the assured hope of Gods pr • mises, concerning the free forgiuenesse of our sins, through the death and passion of our Lord Iesus Christ.

Vse 1 Of which truth, if all that are in the places of Gods Ministers, were so perswaded as they should bee, there is no doubt, Io • . 21.15, &c. 1. Pet. 5.2. but many of them would with more care and conscience, apply and endeuour themselues, to approue their loue
both towards Christ, and towards his people that depend vpon them, to feede them with the bread of life,2. Tim. 4.2. and that in season, and out of season, then now they doe.

And the like also may be said, of all such Vse 2 as either carelesly and vnprofitably heare such wholesome Doctrines and Exhortations, as are taught and deliuered, or suffer themselues to be ouercome with sléepe, or else absent themselues, by keeping at home, or by wandring abroad about their worldly affaires, when the holy exercises of Religion are in hand. If such men and women (I say) were also perswaded, that the hearing of the Word of God, is as necessary for the preseruation of their soules in good estate before God, as meate and drinke is for the nourishment of their bodies: they would not account such slight occasions (as they now pretend) to be sufficient excuses to keepe them away, but they would come one day as well as another, & in the after-noone, as well as in the fore-noone; they would hunger & thirst after this food of life, and haue their consciences checking them within, for euery default in this behalfe. If they did either know (as I said) how great a want the
〈2 pages missing〉
of our requests longer then we would; yet must we not distrust, nor bee discouraged, but alwayes comfort our selues with this vndoubted assurance, that hee is faithfull who hath promised, who also will doe it. For yet a little while (saith the Apostle) and he that shall come,
Heb 10.23.37, 38. will come, and will not tarry. Now the iust shall liue by Faith: but if any man withdraw himselfe, my soule (saith the Lord) shall haue no pleasure in him.

div.head: Conference.
div.p:
Next vnto the publike Ministery and preaching of the Gospell, there is nothing more profitable to the edification of Gods people, for the nourishment of Faith, and for the increase of all other good gifts and graces of Gods Spirit in them, then often conferences of Religion: then, when men and women beeing assembled and met together, doe passe some good part of the time in conferring together, concerning the mysteries of Gods Kingdome, in asking questions of the Minister, and of others that are able to informe them, in the found knowledge of the Truth, in calling that to remembrance which hath béen publikely
taught, in examining it by searching the Scriptures, as they of Berea did, Acts 17. Acts 17.11 and in making vse of it to their particular consciences, in helping, Heb. 3.13. exhorting, comforting, and admonishing one another. But lamentable experience proueth, that many there are, vnto whom nothing is more bitter, or vnpleasant, then questions, and conferences of Faith and Religion. They will not sticke to spend whole dayes in reasoning to and fro of worldly matters, concerning profit, or pleasure: but if any question be moued or propounded touching their estate before God; for want of sound and sauing knowledge, faith, repentance, patience, zeale of Gods glory, loue, and the like, or tending to their reformation in any thing that is amisse: where there is one that will take it patiently, and thankefully, and settle himselfe to be profited by it: it is the vse of the greatest part, if they withhold their tongues, from terming it precisenesse, Psal. 58.4, 5 yet like the deafe Adder, they will stop their eares, harden their hearts, and be sure to keepe themselues from reaping any good to themselues thereby at all.

Concerning the Sacraments, how
〈2 pages missing〉
as many as by faith haue the doore-posts of their hearts sprinkled with the bloud of Christ the true Lambe, that taketh away the sinnes of the world, shall be sure to be saued from the wrath of God, wherein the wicked shall bee vtterly ouerwhelmed. This, no doubt, the faithful Iewes in their Sacraments did see, before the comming of Christ; although not so cleerely as we doe now in this time of the Gospell; as this is manifest, 1. Cor. 10.1. Cor. 10.3, 4. where the Apostle saith, that they did all eate the same spirituall meat, and did all drinke the same spirituall drinke, for they dranke of the spirituall Rocke that followed them, and the Rocke was Christ. Which they could not possibly haue done, if in Manna, and in the Rock, they had not vnderstood Christ. For Christ was Manna, and Christ was the Rocke.
Now to the seuerall branches of the definition.

Wherein we are to obserue: first, touching a Sacrament it selfe, what it is. Secondly, who is the author of Sacraments. Thirdly, whereof euery Sacrament consisteth: and fourthly, to what end Sacraments were instituted.

A Sacrament, as you haue heard, is a publike worke of the Church, wherein arise two notes. First, that in the peace and liberty of the Gospell, Sacraments should bee celebrated publikely in the Church, and in the congregation of Gods people, being assembled together to that end. Secondly, not by priuate men, much lesse by women; but by the publike Minister lawfully authorized thereunto. In Luke 1. Luke 1.5 • . it is said, that the Neighbours and Kinsfolkes of Elizabeth came together the eight day to circumcise the Childe. So that they did it not secretly, but with a conuenient company and assembly both of men and women: forasmuch as Circumcision was then a publike Sacrament of the Church: into the place whereof, the Sacrament of Baptisme is now succeeded. And concerning the Lords Supper, it appeareth, 1. Cor. 11.2. Cor. 11.33, 34. how the Apostle Paul reprooueth the Corinthians very sharpely, because they stayed not one for another, and because they made no difference betwéene their priuate houses, and the Church of God.

Baptisme, the outward signe is Water, and the washing therewith visible, which is done by the Minister; so the thing signified, is regeneration; that is to say, the bloud of Christ, whereby wee are washed from our sinnes. Likewise in the Lords Supper, the outward signe is Bread and Wine, taken from things commonly vsed for meat and drinke; the thing signified, is the body of Christ crucified, and his bloud shed for our sinnes. Water, Bread, and Wine, considered in their owne nature, and out of this holy vse, and institution of the Lord, are onely that which they are called, and said to be; but let the Word of God be once added vnto them, together with calling vpon his holy Name, for their sanctification, according to Christs institution: and then become they holy signes, and representations of all these spirituall and heauenly graces: Neither thenceforth are they to be called bare water, or bare Bread and Wine: but in this holy vse, they beare ye names of the things signified, as sacramentally ioyned together: Ioyned, I say, or vnited by a mysticall signification, and by the purpose and will of him who first instituted them. And
Christ that instituted Water in Baptisme, did not institute it with that minde and purpose, that the faithfull should only be dipped in it, or washed with it: And so likewise in the Supper, when hee commanded the Bread to bee eaten, and the Wine to be drunke; he did not meane that they should onely receiue Bread & Wine, without any further mystery, as they eat and drinke in their houses: but that they should spiritually bee partakers of the things signified, and by Faith bee truely purged from their sinnes, and made partakers of Iesus Christ.

Thus you see, whereof Sacraments consist, and how rightly the promises of God, concerning the free forgiuenesse of our sinnes, and euerlasting life, are firmely confirmed by them, and sealed vp in our hearts. As Circumcision in the old time was profitable to all such as were circumcized, hauing faith before, and being comprehended within the Couenant, a seale of righteousnesse and iustification, as the Apostle Rom. 4. Rom 4.11. teacheth of Abraham; so is the very same to be said and concluded, as touching the Sacraments that are now in vse. Vnto all such as are within the couenant
of Gods grace, & mercy in Christ Iesus, & haue true faith in his righteousnesse and redemption, the Sacrament of Baptisme sealeth to their consciences, the washing away of the filthinesse of their sinnes, by the bloud of Christ; so as they are become pure, holy, and vndefiled before the face of God. And the Lords Supper sealeth vnto them the vertue and efficacie of Christs Death and Passion, to their effectuall preseruation to eternall life. But on the contrary, as Circumcision nothing profited those that were circumcised, if before they had not faith, and were not comprehended within the Couenant: euen so standeth the case with all those that are not at this day within the Couenant of Gods grace, and mercy in Christ Iesus, & are destitute of true faith in his righteousnesse, and bloud-shedding, though they haue been baptized; yet it is, as if they had neuer been baptized: though they neuer so often partake the Sacrament of the Lords Supper, yet doth it nothing profit thom, but they remaine neuerthelesse, in the state of condemnation.

div.head: To what ends Sacraments were ordained.
div.p: A maine cause and end of Sacraments, is to confirme and seale vp in our hearts, the promises of God, concerning the free forgiuenesse of our sinnes, and euerlasting life, as is expressed in the definition, and as wee haue already obserued in the former branch. But besides this, there are some others.

A second cause wherefore Christs pleasure was to ordaine Sacraments in his Church, is partly our owne infirmity and weakenesse, being dull and slow in the vnderstanding of heauenly things; and partly, the great goodnes and loue of God, that would vouchsafe to attemper himselfe to our rude capacity, and to seeke meanes by outward things, to ease & helpe the same. Our sences also, by the exercise of the Sacraments, are stirred vp to be instruments to helpe our minde and weake Faith. Our memory, in like manner, by the same means is much strengthned. And therefore a third cause and end of a Sacrament is, that it may be vnto vs a blessed exercise, whereby wee call to remembrance
the benefit of our Redemption by Christ, and yeeld vnto him most hearty praise and thankes for the same, according to the words of Christs institution: Luke 22.19 Doe this in remembrance of mee. And as Saint Paul, 1. Cor. 11.1. Cor. 11.16. As often as ye eat this bread, and drinke this cup of the Lord, ye shall shew forth his death vnto his comming. Another cause and end of a Sacrament is, that by the practics and vse of them, wee might openly before God and the world, protest and acknowledge that we are his people, and of the number of them that looke to be saued, preserued, and defended by the benefit of Christ onely. So that the open vse of the Sacraments, is a part of that confession, whereunto the Apostle doth attribute saluation, when he saith, Rom. 10. Rom. 10 9. If thou shalt confesse with thy mouth the Lord Iesus, and beleeue in thy heart, that God raised him from the dead, thou shalt be saued: For by the heart we beleeue to righteousnesse, and with the mouth confession is made to saluation.

A fourth cause and end of the Sacraments, is, that they might bee as bands and linkes of loue, vnity, and concord among our selues. All Christians weare
one cognizance or Liuery; for the Sacraments are the markes of Christs sheepe. Therefore not to loue, and agree together, is a reproch wrought to our Lord and Master: whereby, in a manner, wee protest to the world that wee bee not seruants of his Family. For in this (saith he, Ioh. 13. Ioh. 13.35.) shall all men know you to bee my Disciples, if you loue one another. Hereof, I say, doth the right vse and vnderstanding of the Sacraments, very notably put vs in remembrance; wee being taught in Baptisme, that wee are all new borne, Children of God, and grafted into one body: And in the Lords Supper, that wee are fed and nourished with one heauenly food of the body and bloud of Christ: and that therefore we should with faithfull loue, heartily imbrace one another, as the children of one Father, the members of one body, and as the seruants of one Master, fed at one table, and nourished with one food to eternall life. And the last cause and end of a Sacrament that I meane now to speak of, is, that by them, as by blessed instruments of the Holy Ghosts working, hee might impart vnto vs, and bestow vpon vs all the fruits and
benefits of our Redemption in Christ Iesus. For as his Word is, so are his Sacraments instruments, and meanes by the working of his holy Spirit, to bring vnto vs the whole benefit of our saluation.
Now for some vses:

Vse 1 Seeing Christ is the Author of the Sacraments, it cleerely then followeth, that the institution and ordinance of Christ, is the onely true rule and platforme for the right administration and vse of them. According whereunto when they are celebrated, they become most notable Seales and pledges of Gods wonderfull loue and fauour towards vs in Christ Iesus, and most excellent familiar meanes, to increase and confirme our Faith. Whereas on the contrary, if the institution of Christ be not inuiolably retained, and preserued, but corrupted, and violated, it is vnpossible, in the vse of the Sacraments, to haue any of these comfortable effects ensuing, to the glory of God, and to the true peace and ioy of our owne soules. This is manifestly taught by the Apostle. 1. Cor. 11. where labouring to induce the Corinthians to the right vse os ye Lords Supper, he
propoundeth vnto them the institution of Christ, as the only true rule to direct them aright.1. Cor. 11.23. I haue receiued of the Lord (saith hee) that which I haue deliuered vnto you. And surely this course did hee there take, not without great wisedome: for if he had barely deliuered his owne opinion, or censured them according to his owne iudgement, they might haue excepted against it, and haue beene at choise, whether they would haue submitted themselues thereunto or no: but now seeing he exhorted them vnto nothing, but what Christ himselfe had instituted, and commanded to be obserued, this tooke from them all excuse, and so as without manifest wickednes, they could not deny obedience accordingly. After this manner also, Mat. 19. Math. 19.8 haue we the example of our Lord Iesus Christ himselfe, who when the Iewes obiected vnto him their custome, and the permission of Moses, in giuing them liberty to put away their wiues for euery cause: hee maketh thereunto this answere, From the beginning (saith he) it was not so. Thus calling them backe to the first institution, and plainely shewing, that whatsoeuer was either practised, or
attempted contrary thereunto, it was vnlawfully done, and had neede to be reformed. The institution of Christ therefore, as I said, is the onely true rule, and as for the right celebration of the Sacraments, so also, for whatsoeuer else belongeth to the worship & seruice of God: and wherevnto euery Church, euery particular congregation, yea and euery particular man, ought willingly and religiously to submit themselues, without either adding any thing thereunto, or diminishing any thing from the same: the curse of God being as ready in this, as in any other respect, where it is said, If any man shall adde vnto these things, God shall adde vnto him the plagues that are written in this booke, Reuel. 22. Reu. 22.18.

Vse 2 Secondly, as the wicked presumption of the Papists is hereby euidently discouered, in corrupting, and abusing the institution of Christ, yea, and that as concerning both the Sacraments: insomuch, that whereas hee instituted the Sacrament of his Supper to bee a publike Feast, they make it a priuate repast: whereas hee ordayned it a Sacrament of thanksgiuing, saying, Doe this in remembrance of mee;
they make it a sacrifice propitiatory for the sinnes of the quicke and the dead, a common marchandize to buy soules out of Purgatory, a perpetuall matter of idolatry, by leading the people in their eleuations, to worship the creature, in stead of the Creator, no one of all which they haue receiued from Christ: In prophaning also, and abusing the other Sacrament of Baptisme, with their salt, breathing, spettle, crossing, anointing; attributing to euery of these the selfe-same operation, that in truth belongeth onely to the holy Ghost. Euen so, it teacheth vs, that seeing Christ is the Author of Sacraments, that therefore in the feare of God, we doe not lightly esteeme of them, neither think them to be idle ceremonies, vaine trifles, or mens deuices, so as we may vse them, or not vse them, frequent them, or not frequent them at our pleasure, and as wee thinke good, but esteeme them as Gods holy ordinances, and alwayes receiue them as at Christes owne hand. For euen as when we heare the Word preached by a mortall man, wee must not receiue it as mans word, but as it is indeed the Word of God, as the Apostle speaketh, 1. Thes. 2.1. Thes. 2.13.
so in the administration & vse of the Sacraments, wee must not so much regard the Minister, as with the eye of Faith behold the hand of God, communicating vnto vs the notable effects represented by them: Contrary to the errour of the Anabaptists, who affirme the Sacraments to be of the lesse value, if they be administred by an euill and wicked man. Indeede, the hand of the receiuer being without Faith, makes the Sacraments (which of themselues be good) to be vnto him of no effect, because of his vnbeliefe: but an euill Minister cannot make voyde the faith of a godly receiuer. Iudas was a wicked and false hypocrite all the time that hee followed Christ; and yet I doubt not, but the baptisme which he administred, was as auaileable to the faithfull receiuer, as the baptisme of Peter, or of any other the Apostles. And this must needes be a notable comfort to all Gods Children, that if they come to the partaking of the Sacraments, furnished with faith and true repentance; whether the Minister be good or bad, yet they shall not be disappointed of the notable fruits and effects, signified by the same. And as the goodnesse of the Sacraments
dependeth not vpon the worthines or vnworthines of the Ministers, so also must they not be weighed by the condition of the receiuers, their goodnes depending onely vpon the faithfulnes, truth, & meere goodnes of GOD; and they continuing true and perfect Sacraments, wherein God offereth the things signified, howsoeuer the vnbeleeuers be nothing bettered by them.

Thirdly, although the Sacraments be Vse 3 ordayned of God, for notable seales and pledges of his loue and fauour towards vs in Christ Iesus, & as excellent meanes and instruments to confirme, and strengthen our faith in his righteousnes, and redemption, of which wee haue continuall need: yet is not saluation tyed vnto them, but onely to faith: So that if a man doe truly beleeue, though he can neuer receiue the Sacraments, yet he shall be saued: but if he doe not truly beleeue, though hee receiue the Sacraments neuer so often, yet is he vtterly excluded from all hope of saluation. And this doth the Apostle Paul manifestly teach, Rom. 3. Rom. 3.30. in ascribing iustification, (whether a man be circumcised or vncircumcised) onely to faith. If a
man be circumcised, or (to speake according to the condition of our time) if a man be baptized, and receiue the Lords Supper, it is well; he shall be saued, if withall he truly beléeue in Christ Iesus: but if he truly beléeue not in Christ Iesus, though he haue béene baptized, and doe receiue the other Sacrament as often as it is administred: yet is hée neuerthelesse in the state of condemnation. So excellent a gift and grace is faith, and so notable a priuiledge and prerogatiue to be endued therewith: And so fearefull a sinne on the other side is vnbeliefe, thus making an annullity, after a sort, of Gods wholsome and holy ordinance, which he hath instituted and sanctified, for the good and saluation of his people. Not that hereupon it followeth, that it is a matter of no moment, whether we partake the Sacraments or no. God forbid. For, as I haue shewed, they are of Christs institution, and that for seales and pledges of his speciall loue and fauour. They are not superfluous therefore, neither is it a matter indifferent whether they be celebrated or no; but this is that which in this place I note, that saluation is not tyed vnto them, but onely to faith
in Christ Iesus, and that there is no condemnation for the want of them, but for the neglect and contempt of them: according also as neuer in times past were the sacrifices, Sacraments, and ceremonies of the Law, of any account before God, although they were of his owne ordinance, but onely so farre foorth, as Faith in the Messiah to come, was duly respected, and together ioyned in the obseruation of them: As this might be made appeare by plentifull testimonies and examples.

The Papists, cleane contrary to this, doe hold and affirme, that the grace of God, and the thing signified in the Sacraments, are so tyed, and included in the outward signes, that whosoeuer doth outwardly receiue the signes, must néedes inwardly participate of the grace of God, and of the thing signified, although the parties be neuer so wicked. But without Faith there is neither iustification nor saluation: Neither doe the Sacraments of themselues, helpe any whit herevnto. The Forefathers of those Iewes with whom Christ disputed, Ioh. 6. Ioh. 6.31. did eate Manna in the Wildernes, after their comming from Egypt, which Manna was
a type, and figure of Christ, and euen a very Sacrament of his flesh, but yet (as the Apostle teacheth, 1. Cor. 10.1. Cor. 10.5.) with many of them God was not pleased, for hee ouerthrew them in the Wildernesse. Although they had the Law, the ceremonies and sacrifices among them, daily heard the one, and were often conuersant in the other, yet were they neuerthelesse most wicked and vngodly: by their idolatry and other abominations, most fearefully prouoking the heauy wrath, and iudgements of God against them. Ananias and his wife (as Acts 5. Acts 5.3.) had béene baptized, and had also (no doubt) receiued the Lords Supper, and yet did they continue in their wickednes and lyes against the holy Ghost: the Sacraments did neither take away their sinnes, nor giue them any iustifying or sauing grace. This wee sée also in Iudas, and in Simon Magus.

But as by this which hath already béen spoken, this is a cleare and manifest truth, that the Sacraments cannot conuay grace, neither iustifie, nor make men righteous of themselues, as the Papists very grosly doe affirme; so is it withall as cleare and euident, that the Sacraments
haue no power to pardon or forgiue sinnes. Contrary also to their assertion, that by Baptisme is washed away that originall sinne, wherein wee are conceiued and borne, and that corruption which hath spred from Adam, vpon all mankinde, and that thereby wee are restored to that same righteousnes, and purenesse of nature, which Adam had before his fall. The which how contrary it is to the Scripture, wee may see at large, Iames 1. Iam. 1.13, 14, 15. and more especially, Rom. 7. R •• . 7.13.14, 15, 16. where the Apostle is nothing ashamed to acknowledge, what a wonderfull sway originall sinne bare in him; yea, after he was both baptized, and sanctified. In which respect, very much deceiued was the Apostle; if the Papists say true, that by Baptisme, originall sinne is washed away. Againe, if this were so, it is then vnpossible that any beeing baptized should sinne: For originall sinne is the ground of all sinne: take this away, and then can wee not commit any sinne: For if the well-spring be stopped, no streames can issue: or if the foundation be razed, it is not possible that the building should stand.

It is no small errour of theirs also, to hold, as they doe, that the Sacraments can purge from actuall sinnes, and earthly punishments, as sicknes, and the like. As in the time of Popery, it was an vsual thing, when any man was sicke, to haue the Sacrament (as they called it) carried vnto him, thus making it a charme for all diseases. In which blinde and grosse conceit, many remaine at this day so mis-led, that when God punisheth them for their sinne, either by sicknes, or otherwise, although they be neuer so void of faith and repentance; yet if they may haue the Sacrament, they perswade themselues that all is well.

Now in this discouery of popish errours, as touching the Sacraments, wee diminish nothing of the worthinesse, and excellency of them (as they falsely lay to our charge,) but restore them, and labour to preserue them, according to the end and purpose of the Lord in their institution: which was, that they should be, not fountaines of grace, or causes of righteousnes, but seales of righteousnes, and of the righteousnes of Faith, as the Apostle speaketh, Rom. 4. Rom. 4.11. yea, not of any other, but of
that righteousnesse of Faith which is had and obtained before the receiuing of them.

Furthermore, seeing the Sacraments Vse 4 are not bare signes, but such signes and figures, as most assuredly bring vnto the faithfull heart, verily, and in truth, the selfe-same things that they signifie: so that the faithful Christian receiuer may assure himselfe, that as truely, as God is God, so truely hee receiueth those things, which the outward Sacrament doth signifie. That therefore with humble hearts, wee bee religiously carefull to yéeld immortall thankes to the Eternall God in our Sauiour Iesus Christ, for that he hath vouchsafed so graciously, and mercifully to haue consideration of our infirmity, to help our frailty; and, as it were, to lead vs like children by the hand, and appoint vs w • ither to goe, and what to doe, and to giue vs those exercises, to trade vs to the obedience of his will, and confession of his name, to marke vs with his badges, and cognizances, that we may bee knowne to bee his; to fasten vs together with these linkes of vnity, and Christian concord, and finally to prepare for vs, such and so blessed
instruments, to bring vnto vs his heauenly blessings.

Herein we may also behold his great wisedome, that he would not lay forth vnto vs his spirituall mysteries and promises in words onely, lest they might slip away, and be forgotten: but confirmeth, and establisheth the same by his Deed and Seale also, that wee might the more assuredly imbrace them. Experience tels vs, that when men make any couenant, or bargaine, they either shake hands, or vse some other like ceremonie, or solemnitie to confirme it: Euen so dealeth Christ with vs in his Sacraments, hee hauing ordained them as his Deeds, and instruments to assure vs of his promises. And so much are his Déeds more sure, and his promises more certaine and infallible, then any mans can be, as his will is more iust, to stand to that he hath said, and his abilitie to performe it greater.

div.head: Quest. 17. How many Sacraments are there?
div.p: Answ. There are onely two Sacraments instituted by our Lord Iesus Christ: the Sacrament of Baptisme, and the Sacrament of the Lords Supper, Deut. 12.32.

div.head: EXPOSITION.
div.p:
THis I néed not stand much vpon, it being plaine by that which hath already beene shewed; that there can be but two Sacraments of the New Testament ordained by Christ to confirm our hearts in the assurance of Gods promises to eternall life; namely, Baptisme, and the Lords Supper. No other outward signes, obseruations, or ceremonies tending to this confirmation, but onely these two. And whereas the Papists say, that besides these there are fiue other; Confirmation, Penance, extreme Vnction, Order and Wedlocke; in which (as they say) vnder the couer of visible things, the power of God worketh mans
health: It is false, and blasphemous. For vnto euery Sacrament (as you haue heard) and (speaking properly of Sacraments) there must bee a sensible outward signe, and the word of institution. Now these fiue which they call Sacraments, do want either the Word, or the outward signe, or else both of them together. As for example: Matrimonie, Order, and Penance, as they terme them, haue in some sence, the Word of God to approoue them; but they haue no outward element, or creature ioyned therewith. Extreme Vnction, and Confirmation, haue neither outward creature, nor any Word of God to warrant them. And therefore if these fiue be to bee accounted Sacraments, it will be a very easie matter to proue many more.

div.head: Quest. 18. What is the Sacrament of Baptisme?
div.p: Answ. Baptisme is a Sacrament of the New Testament; wherein is signified, and sealed vnto vs, that wee are as assuredly washed from our sinnes by the bloud of Christ, as our flesh is washed with water, in the name of the Father, of the Sonne, and of the Holy Ghost, Mar. 16.16. Ephes. 5.25, 26, 27. Tit. 3.5. 1. Pet. 3.21.

div.head: EXPOSITION.
div.p: FOr the better vnderstanding of this most excellent principle of our Christian Religion: it shall be requisite to consider, according to this definition, these especiall notes: What it is: By whom it is to be administred; and in what place; after what manner; at what time; vnto whom; and what is the comfortable and and effect thereof.

div.head: As touching the first: What it is?
div.p: That Baptisme is a Sacrament of the New Test • ment, we haue séene already in the generall consideration of the Sacraments. Reason 1, 2, 3. And it is rightly called ye first Sacrament of ye new Couenant, not only because it was iustituted by our Lord Iesus Christ before the other Sacrament of his Supper, and is succeeded into the place of Circumcision, which was the first Sacrament among the Iewes: but also because it is sanctified, and set apart, to bee (as it were) the wombe of the Church, whereby the Elect of God, through the ioynt-work of the Holy Ghost, are new borne, and become, of the children of wrath, the children of God, and prepared by this their second birth, to enter into the Kingdome of Heauen. According to that of the Apostle, Tit. 3. Tit. 3.5. Not by the workes of righteousnesse which we had done; but according to his mercy he saued vs, by the washing of the new birth, and the renuing of the Holy Ghost. And Ephes. 5. E •••• . 5.25.26. he saith, Christ loued the Church, and gaue himselfe for it, that he might sanctifie, and cleanse it, by the washing of water through the Word.

div.head: By whom it is to be administred?
div.p: Wee haue learned in that which goeth before, that forasmuch as a Sacrament is a publike worke of the Church; therefore Baptisme being a Sacrament, ought not to be administred by any other, but onely by the publike Minister lawfully called thereunto: Our Lord Iesus Christ giuing Authoritie and Commission for the same, onely vnto them, and vnto no other.

And whereas it hath been held & maintained, as a lawfull action, that Midwiues (in the time of necessity (as they call it) and when the Child is likely to dye, and cannot conueniently bee brought to the publike ministery) may baptize. • his we say, that forasmuch as women are flatly forbidden in the Scripture to teach: It thereupon also plainely followeth, that they are at no time to baptize: the administration of this Sacrament of right belonging vnto none, but vnto such as bee called to teach: Teaching, and baptizing, by the ordinance and commandement of the Lord, being so necessarily ioyned together; that although it be lawfull to preach
the Word without baptisme, yet not lawfull to baptize without preaching, and declaration of the couenant of Gods grace and mercy, sealed to our soules in the bloud of Christ. And now, that no woman hath this commission of teaching or preaching the Word, the Apostle, 1. Tim. 21. Tim. 2 12. doth plainely declare, saying, I permit not a woman to teach. And whereas the example of Zipporah, the wife of Moses, is commonly obiected, who circumcised her Sonne, as Exod. 4. Exod. 4.25. This wee are to obserue for answere: that her action (with what affection soeuer it were done) establisheth no common rule, or law, no more then the particular example of Deborah, maketh all women Iudges. Iudges 4.4. There bee many peculiar things recorded in the Scriptures, out of which if any man shall goe about to draw generall things, and common rules, he shall bring in absurdities innumerable. And whereas, to colour baptisme by women, there is a necessity pretended, as though if the Child dye vnbaptized, it doth incurre the danger of damnation: the answere is easie, that the saluation of Infants in this time of the Gospell, is no more tyed vnto the outward
receiuing of the Sacrament of baptisme, then it was vnto circumcision in times past. And in the Law we read, Gen. 17.12. Leuit. 12.3. that it was not lawfull to circumcise a Child vntill the eight day. And many no doubt departed out of this life before the eight day, and yet was there neuer any condemnation imputed vnto them.

div.head: In what place.
div.p:
It being manifest, that the Sacrament ought not to be administred by any, but onely by the lawfull Minister authorized thereunto: It followeth thereupon as plainely, and euidently, concerning the place, that in no other place, but onely in the Church, and before the congregation ought it to be administred, vnlesse in the time of persecution. Not that Baptisme is tyed to one place more then to another, in regard of the thing it selfe. For wee read, Acts 8. Acts 8.36, &c. that Philip baptized the Eunuch in a certaine water as they trauailed vpon the way: but onely in regard of circumstances, because Baptisme is a publike worke of the Church publikely to be administred, and the Church is the ordinary place for the assembly of the faithfull,
to the vse and obseruation of all Gods ordinances belonging to the publike worship, and seruice of his name.

div.head: After what manner.
div.p:
As touching the manner of the administration of this Sacrament, it must be administred with water, Mat. 28.19. and in the name of the Father, the Son, and the holy Ghost. If it be administred with any other element or creature, but onely water, it is vnlawfully done, neither is it any Sacrament: the Lord instituting no other outward thing, but onely water, for the true Reason 1 and full administration of the same. Water holding this proportion with the bloud of Christ, and after this manner representing the same, that as water washeth away the filthinesse of the flesh, so doth the grace of God through Christes bloud, taken hold vpon by a true and liuely faith, wash the soule, and clense the fame from the gilt and pollution of sinne, so making vs the sonnes and daughters of GOD, which were before the children of wrath. Againe, if Baptisme be administred in any other name, but onely in the name of the blessed Trinity, the Father, the Sonne,
and the holy Ghost, it is no true baptisme, but a flat prophaning and mocking of Christs ordinance. For the force and effect Reason 2 of baptisme, can no otherwise be truly perceiued or vnderstood, th • n by beginning at the frée mercy of the Father, who reconcileth vs vnto himselfe by his onely begotten Sonne: Then secondly doth Christ appeare before vs, with the sacrifice of his death: And thirdly, the holy Ghost, by whom we are washed, and regenerated, and in the end made partakers of all good gifts. For we doe not rightly know God, except our Faith doe distinctly conceiue thrée persons in one Essence, and that the efficacie and fruit of baptisme doth come from hence, that God the Father adopteth vs in his Sonne, and that wee being purged from the filthinesse of our flesh, he reformeth vs by his Spirit to holinesse and righteousnes all the dayes of our life.

div.head: At what time.
div.p:
As touching the time of Administration, it is in it selfe frée▪ and not tyed to one time more then to another: but the time of resorting thereunto is not frée. They that beléeued the preaching of Peter at Ierusalem
in the day of Pentecost, Acts 2. Acts 2.41. The Eunuch whom Philip baptized, chap. 8. Chap. 8.36. Cornelius chap. 10. Cha. 10.47. Paul the Apostle at Damascus, chap. 9. Chap. 9.18. Lydia, and the kéeper of the prison, chap. 16. Cha. 16.15, 33. they of Philippos, and other faithfull men and women, assoone as they had tasted of the gifts and graces of Christ, and beléeued his Word, forthwith they desired to be baptized, and did not deferre, nor put it off till another time. Whereupon I conclude, that they doe very well, who neither in themselues, nor in their families, doe linger in receiuing this holy Sacrament.

div.head: Vnto whom.
div.p:
This Sacrament belongs to all such as are comprehended within the couenant of Gods grace, and mercy in Christ Iesus, whether they be old or young. Such as are of full age, are not to be receiued vnto baptisme, before such time as they be instructed, and haue yéelded a confession of a true faith, together with a protestation, that they will glorifie God in newnesse of Reason 1 life. But as touching Infants: Séeing our Adoption doth not depend vpon our selues, or vpon any outward thing, but
onely vpon the election of God; therefore although Infants be not indued with actuall faith, which is by hearing, yet are they iustly baptized (as in times past they were circumcised) because they are comprehended within the couenant of eternall life, by meanes of the faith of their Parents, who, according to the condition of the couenant, apprehend the promise of GOD, both to themselues, and to their children. To whomsoeuer God promiseth himselfe Reason 2 to be their God, and whom hee acknowledgeth for his, those, no man, without great impiety, may exclude from the number of the faithfull: but hee promiseth not onely that hee will be the God of such as doe professe him, but also of their séede, as appeareth in these words of the couenant made to Abraham, Gen. 17. Gen. 17.7. I will establish my couenant (saith the Lord) betweene thee and me, and thy seede after thee for an euerlasting couenant, to be God vnto thee, and thy seede after thee. Now to this couenant was circumcision added, as a seale and pledge thereof, as well in children, as in men, the substance whereof remaineth • o this day, and not abolished by Christ. For hee came to fulfill the promises, and
not to dissolue them. And therefore said he, Math. 19. Mat. 19.14 Suffer little children, and forbid them not to come to me: for of such is the Kingdome of God. And Marke 10. Marke 10.14, 15, 16. Verily I say vnto you, whoso • uer shall not receiue the Kingdom of God, as a little child, hee shall not enter therein. And hee tooke them vp in his armes, and put his hands vpon them, and blessed them. By this it is euident, that séeing the promise of saluation appertaineth as well to children as to men, there is no reason why the signe and seale of the promise, namely, Baptisme, should be with-holden from them, but that they should be baptized in their infancy at this day, as the children of the Iewes were circumcised the eight day after their birth, baptisme being succéeded into the place of circumcision, as hath béene shewed, and as the Apostle witnesseth, Col. 2. Col. 2.11, 12

div.head: What is the comfortable end, and effect thereof?
div.p:
Know ye not (saith the Apostle, Ro. 6. Rom. 6.3, 4, &c. ) that so many of vs as were baptized into Iesus Christ, were baptized into his death? Therefore we are buried with him by baptisme
into death, that like as Christ was raised vp from the dead by the glory of the Father, euen so, wee also should walke in newnesse of life. In which words the Apostle doth not onely exhort vs to the following of Christ; but his meaning is, that by Baptisme Christ hath made vs partakers of his death, that wee may be grafted into it. For as the graffe receiueth substance, and nourishment from the root into which it is graffed, so they that receiue Baptisme with a true and liuely faith, they doe truly féele the effect of the death of Christ, in the mortifying of their flesh, and therewithall also the effect of his resurrection in the quickning of the Spirit. Whereupon afterward, doth hee gather matter of exhortation, that if we be Christians indéede, wee ought to be dead vnto sinne, and to liue vnto righteousnes.

If the Sacraments of the old Testament did vrge, and require regeneration, and sanctification, and witnessed our communion with the death of Christ: the Sacraments of the new Testament must also do the like, as touching the substance, and graces signified, there being no difference at all betwéene them. In this sence,
Tit. 3. is Baptisme called, The washing of the new birth. And for this cause most notably, Col. 2. Col. 2.11, 12. doth the Apostle Paul (speaking of circumcision, and baptisme, make the one no more spirituall then the other: for he saith, that we are circumcised with a circumcision made without hands, by putting off the sinfull body of the flesh, through the circumcision of Christ. Afterward, for declaration of that saying, he addeth, that wee are buried with Christ through Baptisme, whereby hee meaneth nothing else, but that the fulfilling, and truth of Baptisme is also the truth, and fulfilling of circumcision, because they figure both one thing: Baptisme being the same to vs Christians at this day, that circumcision in times past was vnto the Iewes.

The Ministers outward washing with water in Baptisme, is a most certaine signe, seale and pledge, of the inward washing, whereby wee are clensed from our sinnes by the bloud of Christ. For euen as water purgeth the flesh, so are our sinnes purged by Christs bloud, as 1. Pet. 3. and 1. Ioh. 1.1. Pet. 3.21. 1. Io • . 1.7. Now to be washed with Christs bloud, is to be made partakers of the couenant of grace, that is to say, to be
reconciled, iustified, regenerate, and adopted into the liberty of the Sonnes of God. The outward man féeleth the force of the water, but the inward man féeleth the efficacie of Christs bloud. All they that are baptized with water, are not regenerated, nor washed with the bloud of Christ, but onely such as are elected: it being most sure and certaine, that the Ministers of Gods Word haue no preeminence in the Sacraments, but onely the administration of the outward signes, all the force, and efficacie of the graces signified, resting and remayning onely in the power and dispensation of Christ. I baptize with water (saith Iohn the Baptist, Ioh. 1. Ioh. 1.26, 38. but hee baptizeth with the holy Ghost. The Baptisme with water washeth the flesh, but it cannot make the soule cleane, nor regenerate the inward affections of the heart. To doe this, is the onely office of Christ, through the gracious worke of his holy Spirit, yea, and so properly and peculiarly hath he reserued it to himselfe, that hee will not communicate it with any other. So that, looke what difference there is betwixt water and the holy Ghost, betwixt a ceremoniall signification, and the thing it
selfe, so great difference there is betwixt the Baptisme of Christ, and the worke of all faithfull Ministers of his Word, and Sacraments, in the ministery and dispensation of the same.

Vse 1 First then in way of vse, here is offered vnto vs very fit occasion to examine our selues in what estate we stand before God. It is no sufficient argument to approue our selues to be in the state of grace and saluation, because we haue béene baptized with the outward Baptisme of water, and because wee are receiued into the Church, and accounted members of the same: but if by the worke, and witnesse of Gods Spirit in our hearts, we féele our selues to be regenerate, and sanctified to holinesse and righteousnes, then haue we a comfortable testimony, that we are baptized with the holy Ghost, and shal be sure of the remission of all our sinnes, and of eternall life; the outward washing with water, being a seale, a signe, and an assurance of the same. Whereas on the other side, if we féele not these effects of Gods grace and blessed Spirit, then, although we haue béene baptized, yet can wee haue no true peace of conscience, nor any hope or
assurance of Gods loue, and fauour in Christ Iesus, to the forgiuenesse of our sinnes, and to the saluation of our soules. This I haue made manifest in the example of Ananias, and Simon Magus, who although they were baptized, yet remayned neuertheles most horrible hypocrites, and blasphemers. And it doth appeare from time to time in experience; many that haue béene baptized with water, haue giuen apparant testimony by their lewd and vngodly conuersation, that they were neuer baptized with the Spirit of Christ, as directly treading the steppes of reprobation.

Secondly, we must remember to make Vse 2 this profit of Baptisme throughout our life, that wee are thereby baptized for dead, (according to the Apostles phrase, 1. Cor. 15.1. Cor. 15.29.) that is, that the death of sinne might be abolished in vs. This, I say, wee ought religiously to remember at all times, and especially when wee féele the motions, and flattering enticements of the world, the flesh, and the deuill, that by the consideration thereof, wee may be strengthened, and stirred vp to fight, and striue against them, knowing, that wee
grieuously sinne, and transgresse euen against the nature of our Baptisme, if after our calling, and conuersion, wee giue our selues to the delights of sinne, and suffer it to raigne, Rom. 6.12. and exercise a dominion in our mortall bodies, so as we obey it in the lusts thereof.

Vse 3 Thirdly, we must remember, that by Baptisme is made a solemne stipulation, or obligation, betwixt God and vs: God witnessing that hee doth receiue vs into the couenant of being his people; and wee giuing faith vnto God, to renounce sinne and Satan, and to serue him in holinesse and righteousnesse, all the dayes of our life. For to bee baptized in the name of Christ, is to be enrolled (as it were) entred, and receiued into the couenant, and family, and so into the inheritance of the Sonnes of God, to be purged also from the filth of sinne, and to be endued with the manifold graces of God, for the glorifying of his Maiesty in an innocent life. As they then who delight in sinne, and follow the lusts and motions of the flesh, doe sinne against the nature of Baptisme, so do they also violate, and breake the couenant made betwixt God and them: Yea, hereby are
vnsealed (as it were) the seales of Gods loue, the Sacrament doth become vnprofitable, and more worse and wicked are such men before God, then they that neuer had the Sacrament at all: As Rom. 2. Rom. 2.25. where the Apostle saith, that by transgressing the Law, the Iewes circumcision was made vncircumcision, that is, it stood them in as little stead, as if they had neuer receiued it. So fearefull and dangerous a thing it is, for men wilfully and licenciously to giue themselues to the affections, and wayes of vngodlinesse, after they haue béene admitted to the partaking of the Sacraments, they by this meanes being guilty of making voyde the grace of God, and his wholesome and holy ordinances which he hath instituted, and sanctified for the good, and saluation of his people. The which vndoubtedly is a most great and haynous offence.

div.head: Quest. 19. What is the Sacrament of the Lords Supper?
div.p: Answ. The Supper of the Lord, is a Sacrament instituted by our Lord Iesus Christ: whereby it is signified, and sealed vnto vs, that we are as assuredly sustained to eternall life, by the body of Christ crucified, and by his bloudshed, as we certainely eate the broken bread, at the Lords Table, and drinke the wine out of the Cup, Math. 26, 26, 27. 1. Cor. 11.23, &c.

div.head: EXPOSITION.
div.p:
THat you may the better vnderstand this Doctrine of the Lords Supper, and come prepared therevnto, with the more reuerence and Religion: (after I haue spoken a few words of the time, when it was instituted,) I wil enter into a briefe, and particular examination, and explication of the words of Christs institution, together with the seuerall circumstances, or sacramental actions, as they are recorded by the Euangelists,
and the Apostle Paul, 1. Cor. 11.1. Cor. 11.23

As touching the time of the institution, The Lord Iesus (saith the Apostle) in the night that hee was betrayed, tooke bread. From this circumstance of time, wee are to obserue two points. First, that the Sacrament of the Lords Supper, is succéeded in the place of the Sacrament of the Iewes Passeouer, which was instituted by God, a little before the deliuerance of the Israelites frō the captiuity of Egypt: euen as this was instituted by our Lord Iesus Christ, a little before our actuall deliuerance from the thraldome and captiuity of sinne, Satan, death, and condemnation. Of which our spirituall deliuerance, from these deadly enemies of our saluation, the Sacrament of the Passeouer was a type, and figure, and therefore not yet abolished, as touching the substance, but that remayning whole, and entire in the Lords Supper: the difference of time only excepted, as I haue shewed before. Now the reason, Reason. wherefore he instituted this Sacrament in the night, was this, forasmuch as he was thereunto compelled by the necessity of the Law of God, wherin it was expresly cōmanded, as Exod. 12.
that the Passeouer should be celebrated at euen. Exod. 12.6. The which ordinance of God was first by him to be fulfilled, before he might proceed to the abolishing thereof, by the institution of any other. So that hereupon it followeth not, that the Sacrament of the Lords Supper must still be administred in the night, because Christ in making himselfe subiect to the Law, instituted the same at that season: but this hereupon we may warrantably conclude, that it may be administred in the night, and after Supper too, if vrgent occasion and necessitie require the same, as in the time of persecution.

And whereas the Papists contend, that it standeth with no reason, to call this Sacrament by the name of the Lords Supper, because it was instituted after Supper: they cauell herein, not onely against vs, but euen against the Apostle Paul himselfe, who in plaine expresse words so termeth it in the twentieth Verse of the same Chapter.

For a second note, heere is offered vnto vs a most notable consideration of Christs wonderfull loue and goodnesse towards vs: For euen as when a man thinking
on death, and preparing himselfe to leaue this world, doth in his last Will and Testament bequeath some gift or Legacy vnto his friends, to such as haue beene néere and deare vnto him, whereby they might haue occasion to remember him, and to praise GOD for him when hee is gone: So our Lord Iesus Christ, knowing now the houre to be at hand, wherein he should by death leaue this world, and ascend vnto his heauenly Father, hath in the institution of this Sacrament, left vnto vs a most excellent pledge and token of his tender loue and kindnes towards vs, not onely in abasing himselfe to take our flesh; but also in suffering death for our Redemption. This was no small loue, but a loue most wonderful surpassing and excellent; of which himselfe speaketh, saying, Greater loue then this hath no man,
Ioh. 15.13. when any man bestoweth his life for his friends. And now, as all the parts and circumstances of this loue, our Lord Iesus Christ performed in his life, and at his death: euen so, hath hee left vnto vs this Sacrament, for a memoriall thereof, and perpetually to that end to bee obserued, euen vntill his comming againe. And surely,
in regard hereof, there could not be any fitter time for the celebration of the same, then in the same night wherein hee was betrayed, and when hee certainely knew, that he should shortly dye, that so it might the more freshly bee imprinted and retained in our mindes.
Now to the words themselues of the institution.

div.head: Math. 26.26, 27, 28. Luke 22.19, 20.Iesus took the Bread, and when he had giuen thankes, he brake it, & gaue it to the Disciples, and said, Take, eate, this is my body. Doe this in remembrance of me. Also hee tooke the Cup, and when he had giuen thankes, hee gaue it to them, saying; Drinke ye all of it. For this is my bloud of the New Testament, that is shed for many, for the remission of sins; This doe, as oft as yee drinke it, in remembrance of me.
div.p:
Exposition.In these words is contained the whole institution of the Lords Supper: wherein are two especiall things to be considered. The Ceremoniall, or sacramentall circumstances, which are these; He tooke
bread, hee gaue thankes, he brake the bread, hee gaue the bread, and they did take and eate it. Also hee tooke the Cup, hee gaue • hankes, he gaue it to them; he said, Drinke ye all of it.

The other thing to be considered, is the matter of the Sacrament, in these words; This is my body which is broken for you. 1. Cor. 11.23, 24, 25. This is my bloud of the New Testament, that is shed for many, for the remission of sinnes.

div.head: He tooke bread:
div.p:
The bread which Christ tooke, was vnleauened bread: the same being the vsuall and ordinary bread at that time. And whereas the Papists say, that because Christ tooke vnleauened bread, the first part of this Sacrament must alwayes therefore be administred with bread that is not leauened, and that it is an abuse of of Christs ordinance, if it bee administred with that which is leauened: The answer is plaine, that the necessitie of the time constrained Christ to take vnleauened bread, it being an ordinance and Law of God, as Exod. 12. Exo. 12.15. that for the space of seuen dayes there should be no leuen found
in the houses of the children of Israel, and that whosoeuer should eat leauened bread from the first day, vntill the seuenth, that person should be cut off from Israel. And now when Christ instituted this Sacrament, and tooke Bread, it was the first of these seuen, as we may see, Math. 26. Math. 26.17. So then, hereupon it followeth not, as they imagine, that this part of the Sacrament must of necessity be administred with vnleauened bread: but this may well be gathered, and concluded, that it must euermore be administred with bread, and that whosoeuer shall presume to celebrate it with any thing else, hee retaineth not the institution of Christ; but is manifestly guilty of prophaning & abusing the same: the Euangelist saying in plaine termes, that he tooke bread: and they name no other thing that he tooke; neither also doth the Apostle say, that he instituted it with any thing else. And surely, herein is a more manifest argument of Christs loue, then is of euery one well considered; in that, by such familiar creatures, as Bread and Wine, he would vouchsafe to attemper himselfe to our rude capacity, and to bring vs to the perfect vnderstanding of
his heauenly mysteries: wee being hereby plainely taught, and led (as it were) by the hand, to this comfortable assurance; that as Bread and Wine by naturall effects, nourish our bodies, strengthen and comfort our spirits: so doth the body and bloud of Christ broken, and shed for vs vpon the Crosse, nourish our soules, and quicken our spirits to eternall life with God. As the bread is made of many graines kneaded into one loafe; and the Wine pressed out of many Grapes into one Cup: so the multitude of Christians, communicating at the Lords Table, though many in number, are ingrafted into Christ, and made members of his mysticall body, and ioyned with mutuall loue one with the other, so that now they liue by the Spirit of Christ, as members of a naturall body liue, and haue sence by that Spirit, that commeth from the heart, and from the head.

div.head: He gaue thankes.
div.p:
The forme & matter of Christs thanksgiuing, is expressed neither by the Apostle Paul, nor by any of the Euangelists, they all concealing it, and (no doubt) vpon very
great consideration. But whatsoeuer it was, this is manifest, that thereby he sanctified, and separated the Bread, to bee an holy and blessed Sacrament of his body, broken for vs vpon the Crosse; as also afterward the Wine, to be an holy Sacrament of his bloud shed for our sinnes. Whereby we learne two points. First, somewhat generally by conference with other places: That we ought to giue God thankes in the vse of his good creatures, and to pray him to blesse and sanctify them to our comfort: remembring this notable saying of the Apostle,1. Tim. 4.4, 5. 1. Tim. 4. Euery creature of God is good, and nothing to be refused, if it be receiued with thanksgiuing, &c. The second, and more particular, is, that by praise & thanksgiuing vnto God, for the death of Christ, and by prayer vnto him, that we may bee made partakers of the fruit and benefit of his Death, ought the Sacrament of the Lords Supper to be administred, and the Bread and Wine sanctified, and set apart to that end.

The Papists terme this thanksgiuing, consecration: which phrase, and terme of speech, we would not stand vpon, if withall
they did not teach, that by consecration, the very substance of the Bread & Wine, should be turned into the body & bloud of Christ: which is nothing so. For consecration is, when that thing which before was impure, and that creature which was common, or vncleane, is made pure, and set apart, for the vse of man. And this is two wayes. First, they are sanctified of the Lord; and secondly, they are sanctified of vs. The creatures are said to be consecrated of the Lord, when they are instituted, ordained, and set apart from all other creatures, to serue for the vse of man, by his holy Word, according to that of S. Paul to Timothy, which I noted before; and where he addeth, that it is sanctified by the Word and Prayer. The second manner of consecration which appertaineth to vs, is by giuing of thankes. And thus, and no otherwise, is the Bread and Wine at the Lords Table, to bee consecrated at this day, and from time to time. It is consecrated and set apart, by the Word and institution of Christ; and by the prayer, praise, and thanksgiuing of the Minister, and faithfull Christians, in the celebration, and participation thereof,
comming (as they ought to come) prepared thereunto, with a religious consideration of the wonderfull and vnspeakeable mercy and louing kindnesse of the Lord, who spared not his owne Sonne,
Rom. 8.32. but gaue him to death for vs all, as Rom. 8.

div.head: He brake the Bread.
div.p: From hence we learne, that the Bread at the Lords Table, in the administration of the Sacrament, must be broken. First, because it is according to Christs institution, as we sée héere in expresse termes. Secondly, that euery one of the communicants feeding thereon equally, may see themselues to be equally partakers of the body of Christ crucified; yea, this breaking of the bread seemeth so necessary, that the Holy Ghost doth call the Sacrament by that very terme, Acts 2.42. Cha. 20.7. Acts 2. and chap. 20.

And a third reason is, because this breaking of the Bread, doth most liuely set forth vnto vs, the breaking of Christs body for our sinnes. Not that his body was materially broken, Ioh. 19.36. Exo. 12.46. as wee reade Ioh. 19. and Exod. 12. (for the outward breaking of it could haue made no satisfaction,) but
the breaking was inward, in Spirit, with bearing the burthen of our sinnes, with which inward griefe of the Spirit, the body, in some sort, may also be said to bee broken, or tormented, when therein, for the bitternesse of the paine, he cryed vnto his Father, as it is recorded, Mat. 26. and 27. Mat. 26.36 chap. 27.46 So then, when wee see the bread broken before vs in the Sacrament, we must verily beleeue, that the body of Christ crucified, is offered vnto vs of our heauenly Father, to be receiued by Faith.

div.head: He gaue the Bread.
div.p:
As the bread at the Lords Table must be broken; so also giuen and distributed. If it bee taken into the hand of the Minister, sanctified by prayer and thanksgiuing and broken; yet if withall it be not distributed, it is no Sacrament, nor sacramentall bread, that bread onely, being so to bée termed, and accounted, which is after prayer and thanksgiuing broken, and distributed to the communicants. Which quite ouerthroweth the opinion and custome of the Papists, in keeping the bread in their boxes, which remaineth vndistributed, as most holy, & consecrated bread,
thinking, and making the simple people beleeue, that that bread hath maruellous great vertue in it, to driue away Diuels, &c. which is not worth the standing vpon.

That which the distributing of the bread doth signifie vnto vs, is, that it is not the body of Christ, as it was borne of the Virgin Mary, that is offered vnto vs, or represented by the bread; but his body as it is was broken, by which wee are saued. And secondly, that this Sacrament must be administred in the face of the congregation, and publikely to all the people, being assembled together for the partaking of it: Contrary also to another custome of the Papists; the Priest oftentimes receiuing it alone, as wee shall sée further hereafter.

And whereas hee gaue the bread vnto his Disciples; we may learne & obserue, that such onely are meet partakers of the Lords Supper, who are the Schollers and Disciples of Christ. And of Christs Disciples doth hee himselfe make a description, Ioh. 8.31. Ioh. 8. by their continuance in his Word.1. Cor. 11.28. And these are also such, who (as the Apostle teacheth 1. Cor. 11.) before
they presume to come to the Table of the Lord, are religiously carefull, to proue and examine themselues.

div.head: And they did take, and eate it.
div.p: The Bread at the Lords Table, being blessed, broken, and distributed, must also be receiued, and eaten. If it be sanctified, broken, and distributed, and therewithall not receiued, and eaten, it is no Sacrament, nor sacramentall bread. The bread being set apart by prayer, and thanksgiuing, broken, giuen, receiued, and eaten, is an holy Sacrament of the body of Christ; and they who reuerently, and religiously, according to Christs institution, are partakers thereof; doe together, with the bodily eating of the bread, spiritually and by faith, eate, and receiue the very body of Christ, to the spirituall nourishment and preseruation of their soules.

div.head: This is my body.
div.p:
This expresseth the matter of the first part of the Sacrament, as I shewed before: The word (this:) which sentence is to be applyed vnto the bread, which the Minister doth take blesse, breake, and giue
to the communicants, exhorting, and requiring them to receiue, and eate it. And whereas hauing thus relation vnto the bread, he saith, This is my body: Wee must not thinke, that the pronouncing of these words doth make the Sacrament, or is any part of the consecration, as the Papists imagine: but herein did our Lord Iesus Christ teach his Disciples, what hee had done, and how hee had sanctified and set apart the bread, to be an holy representation of his body, which should shortly bee broken and crucified for them.

That which wee obserue heere for our instruction and comfort, is this: That the bread at the Lords Table, taken, blessed, broken, giuen, receiued and eaten, is a most holy Sacrament, and representation of the body of Christ crucified, and broken for vs in the Garden, and vpon the crosse. And whereas our Lord Iesus Christ calleth it his body; I will shew some reasons wherefore he doth so, and then come to a further proofe of this point, by the Testimonies & authorities of the Scripture.

A first reason why hee called this bread his Body, was, to teach his Disciples to make a difference betwixt this sanctified
Bread, and common bread.
Secondly, to distinguish it from the other part of the Sacrament, which concernes the Cup.
Thirdly, to distinguish it from the Sacraments of the Old Testament.

Fourthly, to teach his Disciples the thing signified by that outward Sacrament; and therewithall the inseparable coniunction betweene the outward element, and the thing thereby signified in the right receiuing of it.

Furthermore, that his Disciples should know, that hee had instituted another Sacrament of the New Testament, besides Baptisme: and which they might well discerne, not onely in that hee tooke common bread, blessed it, brake it, and gaue it to them, commanding them to receiue, and eate it: but in that also he gaue it the name of the thing thereby signified, according to the vsual phrase of the Scripture when it speaketh of Sacraments, as Gen. 17. Gen. 17.10, 11. Circumcision being but the signe of the Couenant, is called the Couenant. And Exodus 12. Exod. 12.27. The Lambe is called the Passeouer, which was not the Passeouer, but the signe of it, and which it did represent.
And so the Rocke in the Wildernesse, whereof the children of Israel did drinke, is by the Apostle 1. Cor. 10.1. Cor. 10 4. called Christ, of whom it was a signe.

But heere a question may bee asked; that seeing as the Apostle teacheth, Rom. 6. Rom. 6.3, 4. we be grafted into Christs Death and Resurrection by Baptisme: what neede haue wee then of this Sacrament? or how doth it differ from that? Whereunto I answere, that this Sacrament doth not differ from Baptisme, but in the manner and institution of it. For as Baptisme was instituted to ingraft vs into Christs body, that wee might become his members: So the Lords Supper was instituted, and ordained to nourish vs, to retaine and to feed vs, being ingrasted into his body, and that so we might grow and flourish in him.

Another question may be asked, whether the same that is offered vnto vs in the Sacraments, be not in like manner offered vnto vs in the Ministery and preaching of the word of God? To this I answere, that Christ by the Word, is offered to our eares outwardly, but in the Sacraments he is receiued of vs inwardly
by faith into our soules: So that wee become one with him, and he one with vs, and dwelleth in vs, euen vntill the end of the world, and that without any separation.

div.head: Doe this in remembrance of me.
div.p: The Papists would haue these words to be applyed to their Priests, who (as they say) are to offer vp the body and bloud of Christ, a sacrifice for sinne. But marke it well, and you shall see into what absurdities they run. For if these words, Doe this in remembrance of mee, be to be applyed onely to the Priests, then must none but onely the Priests remember Christs death: the which I say is most absurd; all the faithfull Communicants being religiously and faithfully to remember Christ, as well as they.

And as for that which they say of the Priests offering of Christs body for a sacrifice: it is most cleare, that the elect and faithfull, being made perfect by the onely oblation of Christ offered by himselfe once for all, as the Apostle teacheth, Heb. 10. Heb. 10 14.18. neede no other sacrifice, but a memoriall, and Sacrament thereof, to confirme their
faith in the remission of sinnes purchased by his sacrifice, according as hereof again, Heb. 9. Heb. 9.25, 26. that if Christ should be often offered for sinne, then he should often haue suffered: but it is manifest that hee did but once suffer, when he offered himselfe for a sacrifice: therefore is hee not now any more to be offered: as also againe, cha. 10. Where remission of these things is, there is no more offering for sinne. So then, when Christ said, Doe this in remembrance of me: It is as much in effect, as if he should say, Eate this broken bread, and performe all other parts and circumstances of my institution from time to time, in remembrance of me, and especially of my death, and of the excellent fruites and benefits thereof, to the redemption and saluation of the world, & so consequently with euerlasting praise, and thankes, vnto my heauenly Father, for his vnspeakeable loue and goodnesse in the same respect. This is the true sence and meaning of these words, and the true end and purpose that Christ aymed at, in the institution of this Sacrament: That his death and passion, and the notable fruits and benefits thereof, should not onely be had in perpetuall
remembrance of his Church, but also that his exceeding bounty and goodnesse towards the redemption and saluation of mankinde, should be published with due praise, and aduanced with hearty thanksgiuing.

div.head: Also he tooke the Cup.
div.p:
In these words the Euangelist comes to the second part of the institution of this Sacrament: wherein, before I come to the particular handling of them, we may obserue two speciall outward differences betweene this Sacrament, and the Sacrament of Baptisme. First, Baptisme is administred in one onely element or visible creature, namely, water: and this Sacrament of the Lords Supper in two, Bread, and Wine. The other difference is in the vse, the one being taken without the body, and the other within. Now the reason why Baptisme is instituted in one element, and this other Sacrament in two, was, because Christ is signified, and represented in both Sacraments after diuers sorts. In Baptisme, as hee is the washer away of our sinnes, and giueth vs entrance into his Church, that wee may
be partakers of his benefits. And in the Lords supper, as our natural bodies cannot liue with bread alone, nor with drinke only; but we must haue both bread & drink: euen so, our soules cannot be nourished with the body of Christ alone, nor with his bloud onely, but we must of necessity haue both his body & bloud. And therfore, Ioh. 6. he saith, That his flesh is meate indeede, and his bloud is drinke indeede. Which is as much as if hee said, That as our bodies are nourished with meate and drinke, so are our soules nourished, and strengthened in the vndoubted hope of eternall life, no otherwise, then onely by faith in his body crucified, and in his bloud shed. For this is a note, very necessary to be obserued, that the Bread & Wine are not Sacraments of the body and bloud of Christ, as he is now glorified, but as he was broken, and crucified for vs vpon the Crosse.

That which we call the Cup, the Papists translate a Chalice: but the Word doth signifie any common and ordinary vessell to drinke in. And it is no great matter in what manner of Cup it be administred, so as it be comely, the Lord being not delighted with outward shewes.
And whereas S. Luke and S. Paul,
Luke 22.20 1. Cor. 11.25 make mention of the circumstance of the time when he tooke the Cup, as namely, after Supper, we may thereby know, that there was a distance of time betwixt the receiuing of the Bread, and of the Wine: For the Bread was giuen when they were at Supper, but not the Wine, vntil they had supped. Whereupon it may be gathered, that it is not of necessity, that the Minister, in the administration of the Lords Supper, should giue the Wine presently after the imparting of the Bread: but that there may be some space of time, wherein may be singing of Psalmes, &c. Another thing to be obserued in the taking of the Cup, is, that in the vse of the Lords Supper, the Wine is as necessary to be receiued of euery Communicant, as is the Bread: for euen as Christ gaue the one, and commanded it to be perpetually obserued in remembrance of him, euen so also, and after the same manner, hee tooke the Cup, gaue it, and instituted the perpetuall obseruation of the same.

div.head: He gaue thankes.
div.p:
