We see heere, that there ought to be a double thanksgiuing, in the celebration of
the Lords Supper: for as Christ gaue thankes when he gaue the Bread, so did he in like manner giue thankes when hee gaue the Cup. The forme and matter being here concealed as in the former.

div.head: He gaue it to them.
div.p:
The parties to whom hee gaue the Wine, were his Disciples: vnder the name and title of whom are vnderstood all faithfull Christians generally, vnto whose faith, euen as vnto his Disciples, doth the Lord giue his bloud, as often as they celebrate the Lords Supper, and haue the Wine giuen them in the same. From which Sacramentall action of the Lords giuing the Cup vnto his Disciples, wee may here againe obserue: First, that it is not the bloud of Christ, as it naturally procéeded from the virgin Mary, but his bloud, as it was shed vpō the Crosse, that is giuen vnto vs for our spirituall nourishment, and whereby we are saued, And secondly, that this Sacrament of the Lords Supper, ought not, without respect of persons, to be administred to euery one, but only vnto such as approue themselues to be Christs Disciples: And who they
are, I haue shewed already.

div.head: He said, Drinke ye all of it.
div.p: From hence wee learne two points. First, that the drinking of the Wine is so necessary to the being of the second part of this Sacrament, as that although it be blessed, giuen, and receiued, yet withall, vnlesse it be drunke, it is no Sacrament. For euen as not the water in Baptisme, nor the pronouncing of these words after the blessing of it, I baptize thee in the name of the Father, &c. doth make the same Sacrament, vnlesse there be one that is baptized, so neither the blessing, giuing, or receiuing of the Wine, doth make the Sacrament of Christs bloud, vnlesse there be some that do drinke the same. And therefore, how truly the Papists affirme that to be the Sacrament, which they reserue after the administration, or rather what horrible idolatry they commit in calling, and worshipping it for a God, there is none so ignorant but he may discerne.

The second point is, that all they who are partakers of the Bread, which is the Sacrament of Christs body, ought in like
manner to be partakers of the Wine, which is the Sacrament of Christs bloud. For, euen as he said concerning the one, Take, eate, this is my body: euen so in like manner, concerning the other, Drinke ye all of it. Whereupon the Euangelist Marke, chap. 14. Mark. 14.23. addeth, that they all dranke of it.

This alwayes heerewithall being duly obserued, that although there bee two kindes of outward substances, namely, Bread, and Wine, yet doe they both make but one Sacrament, and therefore consequently may not be separated. Whereby againe, the grosnesse, or rather the intolerable presumption of the Papists, is euidently discouered, in that, of their owne priuate authority, they dare corrupt the holy institution of Christ, offering to the Lay people (as they call them) one onely kinde, namely, the Bread, when they communicate; and vtterly denying them to drinke of the Cup. Whereas, the Lord Christ (as it were, by the Spirit of Prophecie) fore-seeing what should come to passe in the Church, speaketh nothing so generally of the Bread, as of the Cup. Hee saith not of the Bread, Eate ye all of
this: but, Take, eate, this is my body: but of the Cup, without any maner of restraint, Drinke ye all of this. Whereupon the Apostle Paul, 1. Cor. 11.1. Cor. 11.26, 27, 28. hauing an especiall regard to this holy ordinance, and institution of Christ, doth many times ioyne the Bread and the Cup together, as may be seene at large in that Chapter.

Moreouer, if the Sacrament of the bloud of Christ were giuen to the Apostles onely, (as the Papists imagine) then the thing it selfe, namely, remission of sinnes, which is obtained through Christs bloud, belongeth onely vnto them: whereas the Lord plainely saith in the very next words, that not onely for them, but for the remission of the sinnes of many, is his bloud shed: and in many other places it is euident, that his bloud was shed for the redemption of all the faithfull. Wherfore if the thing it selfe, namely, remission of sinnes, belong generally to all that truly beleeue, much more then vndoubtedly ought the signe of the same. But they obiect, that if the Cup be giuen to all, without exception, there may bee a great offence committed, in letting it fall. As if the eternall prouidence of God could not
foresee the danger of committing that offence: And as if the Papists were become more carefull, and more prouident to preuent offences, then the Sonne of GOD. Againe, they say, that onely the Apostles sate with the Lord at his last Supper, and that the vse of the Cup was granted to them onely, and so consequently, that all the Priests whom the Apostles did represent, and not any other at this day, should drinke of the Cup: but by as good reason they may say, that the Bread is in like manner to be debarred from the common people, as also from all women generally, seeing it cannot be proued, that any women sate at table with him when he instituted this Sacrament.

They also cry out, that one kinde is enough for the Lay people, forasmuch as by a necessary concomitance it followeth, that where the body of Christ is, there is his bloud also: which exclamation of theirs if it be sufficient, then it must needes follow, that one part of this Sacrament was instituted in vaine: But the Lord distinctly first gaue the Bread, and afterward the Wine, and instituted nothing in vaine: therefore both kindes, séeing the
Lord so commanded, ought to be parted among all the faithfull. If he had meant to signifie both his body and bloud when he gaue the Bread, he would not haue seuered the one from the other, both in words and signes: but being willing to helpe our weakenesse, did set the Cup seuerally from the Bread, to teach, that hee sufficeth no lesse for drinke, then for meat. Therefore, although it be true which they pretend, that the bloud is in the Bread, and the body in the Cup, yet they defraud the faithfull of the strength and confirmation of faith, which the Lord in this distinction hath so carefully and tenderly prouided for them.

div.head: For this is my bloud of the new Testament, which is shed for many for the remission of sinnes.
div.p:
The Apostle Paul in rehearsing these words of Christ, doth somewhat differ from the Euangelists Mathew and Mark, but in sence and meaning they be all one, and there is no diuersity at all betwéene them. For séeing they all spake by one Spirit, which is the Spirit of truth, it is vtterly vnpossible, that one should be any
thing contrary to the other, or that the one should in any measure at all dissent from the other. Mathew and Marke reade it after this manner, This is my bloud of the new Testament, &c. meaning thereby, that the Wine in the Cup, was a Sacrament of his bloud, by which his bloud, the new Testament, or couenant of frée remission of sinnes, was fully established: for it was neuer fully confirmed, and ratified, before it was confirmed by Christs reall bloud. For the bloud of Calues and Lambs, in the old Testament, were but signes and figures of Christs bloud. And therefore, although this couenant was made at the beginning of the world, when the Lord said, The seed of the woman shall breake the Serpents head:
Gen. 3.15. yet was it not fully confirmed and established, before Christs death. But the Apostle Paul, agréeing with the Euangelist Luke, repeateth Christs words in this sort: This Cup is the new Testament in my bloud, that is, this is a new Sacrament of the new Testament, confirmed in my bloud. So that (as I said) there is no repugnancy: but in sence and meaning they agrée all in one. For as the holy Ghost can shew his minde in all languages, euen
so also infinite wayes in one tongue. The Cup is taken for the Wine in the Cup, by a figuratiue kinde of spéech. By a figure also is it said to be the new Testament, according to the ordinary phrase of ye Scripture, vsually attributing (when it speaketh of Sacraments) the name of the thing signified, to the outward signe, as I haue shewed before. The outward signe (I say) is here honoured by the thing signified: so that this herein we are to obserue, that the Wine in the Cup at the Lords Table, being consecrated, and put apart by prayer and thanksgiuing, is not to be considered as common, and ordinary Wine, but is an holy Sacrament of the new couenant, made between God and vs through Iesus Christ, concerning the free deliuerance from the guiltines of all our sins, and our eternall life, through faith in his bloud. And now for these two respects, is it figuratiuely after this manner called the new Testament, not in regard of the matter and substance thereof, forasmuch as Christ being the substance thereof, was promised at the beginning of the world, but in respect of the dispensation, and administration of the same,
forasmuch, as whereas the ancient Fathers before Christs comming, had this couenant ministred vnto them in types and figures, so as they saw Christ, but as as it were, a farre off: wee now sée him much more liuely and familiarly, being administred vnto vs after another manner, with all his glory and righteousnesse. And secondly, it is called the new Testament, or couenant, because it is confirmed vnto vs after a new sort: for it was confirmed to them of the old Testament, in the bloud of Calues, Lambs, Goates, &c. so farre as it pleased the Lord: but it is confirmed to vs in Christs owne bloud, which for our sakes, for our redemption and saluation, hee shed vpon the Crosse: According as hee said in plaine termes when hee gaue the Wine, that his bloud was shed for many, for the remission of sinnes.

div.head: For many, for the remission of sinnes.
div.p:
Vnder the name of many, hee vnderstandeth all such as are elected, and doe truly beléeue in him, of what Nation, or Countrey, and of what estate and condition soeuer they be throughout the world.
Whence we may obserue for our further instruction and comfort. First, Christs innocency: That in no measure at all, in regard of himselfe he deserued death, but for this cause submitted himselfe therevnto, that as the Apostle saith, Heb. 2. Heb. 2.14, 15. That he might destroy, through death, him that had the power of death, that is, the deuil: and that he might deliuer all them, which for feare of death were all their life time subiect vnto bondage. In him had the Prince of this world nothing, as himselfe speaketh, Ioh. 14. Ioh. 14.30. because hee was clearely exempted, and free from all sinne, as Heb. 4. H • b. 4. • 5. Secondly, that many, but not all, without exception, haue remission of sinnes by Christs death and bloud-shedding. That hee hath not giuen his life a ransome, and shed his bloud, nor by bearing their iniquities, hath iustified all, but many, that is, part of all: which many, are all such as are elected, and truly beleeue in him, as I said before. So saith Simeon, Luke 2. Luke 2.34. that he was appointed for the fall, and rising againe of many, that is, for the fall of many reprobates, and for the rising of many who are elected, and therefore not for the redemption of euery one. The death
of Christ, in respect of the fulnesse and sufficiency of redemption, is sufficient for all men, but it is effectuall onely to those that were fore-ordayned to life in him. As of this, wee shall consider further (through Gods assistance) when we come to the 21. question.

A third note obserueable here is this, that all our sinnes are pardoned and forgiuen, not for the acknowledgement or confession of them, but for the m • rit and bloud of the Sonne of God. Not for our owne workes or merits, but of the sr • e grace and mercy of God, for which cause are we taught to professe, as an article of our faith, that wee beleeue the remission of our sinnes. And lastly, that the meanes, and meritorious cause of remission of sinnes, is not the body and bloud of Christ it selfe, taken, and considered apart from his Passion, but his body broken, and his bloud shed, his painefull sufferings, his bearing in body and soule, the extremity of Gods wrath: According to that of the Apostle, Col. 1. Col 1.14, 20, 2 • . In who • we haue redemption through his bloud, euen the forgiuenesse of our sinnes. And againe, It pleased the Father (saith he) that in him all fulnesse
should dwell, and by him to reconcile all things vnto himselfe, and to set at peace, through the bloud of his Crosse, all things in Heauen, and in earth. And verse 22. In the body of his flesh through death. And Heb. 9. Heb. 9.22. we haue it in expresse words, that without shedding of bloud, there is no remission of sinnes. He saith not without bloud, but, without shedding of bloud.

div.head: This doe, as often as ye drinke it, in remembrance of me.
div.p: This is as much in effect, as if hee had said; This is the end which I respect, in the institution of this Sacrament: and this is my will and commandement, that as often as yee celebrate the same, you should not only call to your remembrance my Death and Passion, with the inestimable benefits thereby purchased: but also extoll and magnifie my wonderfull loue in this behalfe; and that altogether with one month, and with one heart, confessing that all your confidence of life and saluation, is reposed therein.

div.head: Of Transubstantiation.
div.p:
The Papists say, that the whole substance of the Bread at the Lords Table,
is turned into the reall body of Christ, and the Wine into his bloud, by the power and efficacy of these words pronounced by a Priest, This is my body, and this is my bloud. Thus, like very Witches & Coniurers, ascribing power and efficacie to bare words and sillables. But herein how grosse and absurd they are, may easily appeare by these few reasons.

Reason 1 First, if the substance of the bread bee turned into the substance of Christs body, then the body of Christ consisteth of these fiue elements: of Bread, Water, Wine, Flesh, and Bloud. But this cannot be, and it is horrible blasphemy, so to think of the body of our Sauiour Christ: but we must beleeue, & acknowledge, that he consisteth only of a diuine & humane nature.

Reason 2 Secondly, if it bee as they say; then Christ did not onely offer his owne flesh to be eaten with the bodily mouthes of others; but he himselfe also with his bodily mouth did eate his owne flesh, (for that which he gaue, of that did he eat.) But this is monstrous, & against nature, either that a man should eat his own flesh; or that one man should eate the flesh of another.

Reason 3 Thirdly, they hereby take away one
part of the Sacrament, and so make it no Sacrament at all (For euery Sacrament consisteth of two parts; the outward element, and the inuisible grace thereby represented.) Now they cannot deny, but Bread is the outward element instituted by our Sauiour: therefore if the bread be transubstantiated, there remaineth no outward element of bread; and thus is one part of the Sacrament abrogated by them. That which taketh away the nature of a Sacrament, is not to be admitted in the Sacrament: but transubstantiation doth so; therefore not to be admitted. For if it bee transubstantiated, it is no signe, but the thing it selfe.

Fourthly, it taketh away one of the Articles Reason 4 of our Christian Faith, where wee professe, that Christ sitteth at the right hand of his Father in Heauen: and wee doe not reade, that hee shall come from thence vntill the Day of Iudgement: (howsoeuer concerning his Spirit, he is, and will bee with vs vnto the end of the world, as Ioh. 12. and chap. 14 and 16. Ioh. 12.8. chap. 14, 16, 17, 18. chap. 16.7.) but they that wil haue his bodily presence in the Sacrament, must proue another comming of Christ besides that: nay, many
commings, which is contrary to the expresse Word of God. Or else they must imagine, (as indeed they do) that Christs body may be in many places at one time: which is also against the Word of God, and asmuch in effect, as if in plaine termes they should deny him, to be (as yet) come in the flesh.

Reason 5 Furthermore, the Apostle, 1. Cor. 11.1. Cor. 11.26, 27, 28. speaking of the Sacrament, as it is after consecration or thanksgiuing, calleth it Bread and Wine, (for by the Cup, hee meaneth the Wine in the Cup.) Now if it be Bread and Wine after consecration, then is it not the body and bloud of Christ: but the Apostle in expresse words calleth it Bread and Wine; therefore it is not the body and bloud of Christ.

And whereas they obiect, that the Apostle therefore so calleth it, because it was so before, Ex • . 4.2, 3. euen as Aarons Rod which was turned into a Serpent, was called a Rod, because it had beene so. First, the very words of the Apostle doth manifestly confute them, euidently signifying Bread and Wine, and not the accidence or shew only of the same. And as for that which they bring of Aarons Rod, when it was called
a Rod, it appeared so to bee: and when it was called a Serpent, it appeared to the sight, and might bee discerned to bee a Serpent.

Againe, that which we eate and drinke Reason 6 at the Lords Table, doth nourish our bodies: and can our bodies bee nourished with that which hath no substance? Can the shew or likenesse onely of Bread and Wine, nourish the substance of our bodies? and if our bodies be not nourished with ye outward thing in the Sacrament; how then can it haue this comfortable representation; that as the Bread & Wine doth nourish our bodie, so doth the body and bloud of Christ nourish our soules? So we see, that if the Popish doctrine bee true; then can wee not possibly haue any comfort in the receiuing of the Sacrament: but after this manner must néedes be discouraged, and discomforted: that as the shew, signe or likenesse of bread and wine, cannot nourish our bodies; no more can the body and bloud of Christ nourish our soules. This (I say) must needs follow vpon their doctrine. For not the substance of Bread and Wine, but onely the outward shew of the same it is, which
most grossely, and wickedly, they would make to hold proportion with the body and bloud of Christ.

Reason 7 Last of all, if wee should grant (which they are neuer able to proue) that the bread and wine in the Sacrament, are turned into the substance of Christs body and bloud; yet what profit should come by that bodily presence, seeing the flesh (as himselfe speaketh, Ioh. 6. Ioh. 6.63.) profiteth nothing? The body of Christ crucified, (I say) and his bloud shed, is not profitable, without the merit of his Death and Passion, apprehended and applyed by the mouth of the soule, which is Faith in him. And if they say that the body of Christ crucified, and the merit of his Death, euer goe together in the receiuers of the Sacrament; and that they who receiue the one really present, receiue also the other: then doe they fall into a foule absurdity, and make the distinction of the Apostle idle, 1. Cor. 11.1. Cor. 11.27, 29. that some are worthy, and some are vnworthy receiuers. And by this doctrine of theirs, all without exception, good, and bad; beleeuing, and vnbeléeuing; (yea euen such as by the Apostles doctrine eate and drinke their owne damnation) doe receiue
the body and bloud of Christ really present, and withall, the merit of his death, and so are fed and nourished to eternall life: which, as yet, is not so much as begunne in them, and whereunto (it may be) they shall neuer come. Such, and so grosse absurdities, follow vpon this popish conceit of Transubstantiation. For though we grant a reall presence, euen of the crucified body of Christ; yet (beeing separate from the merit and vertue of his Death) there is no vse, nor profit, that comes by that bodily presence.

Now, the Papists being not able to answere these, and such like arguments, they say, that herein is a miracle: but we doe not reade of any miracle in the Scripture, but it did alwayes appeare to the outward sences to be a miracle, as I shewed before in Aarons Rod, & is further manifest in the water which Christ turned into Wine, Ioh. 2. Io • . 2.6 &c Now, that which we receiue at the Lords Table, appeares to our sight, hands, taste, téeth, and stomake to bee no other then Bread and Wine. And shall we contrary to all these sences, imagine or thinke they are not so? This were childish, and ridiculous.

But doth not Christ (say they) in plaine termes call the bread his body? And shall we not beleeue him? And doth he not also in as plain termes call himselfe a Doore, a Vine, Ioh. 10.9. chap. 15.1. 1. Cor. 10.4. Ioh. 1.36. Ioh. 10. and 15. And elsewhere also, is he not called a Rocke, a Lambe, &c? Yea, but it appeares by the circumstances (say they) that these are figuratiue speeches. And doth it not appeare also as plainely by the circumstances, that this is figuratiuely spoken, when he saith; Doe this in remembrance of me? And doe this, as oft as yee shall drinke it in the remembrance of me? Especially withall considering, as I haue formerly noted, that it is vsuall in the Scripture, when it speaketh of Sacraments, to attribute the name of the thing signified, to the outward signe, and representation thereof? But

But they cry out, that herein we speake against Gods Omnipotency, and almighty power, when we deny the naturall body and bloud of Christ to bee (as they would haue it) in the Sacrament, and in many places at one time. Whereas wee onely say, that although Christ be omnipotent, yet can hee doe nothing against his owne will, against his Word or glory: As to dishonour his glorious body, and to bring it within the compasse of a piece of bread, where it may be deuoured of Cats and Dogs, Rats and Mice, or which is worse, be eaten of wicked men, who are
the members of the Diuell. This we say, Christ cannot doe, not for want of power; but because he will not doe it As Heb. 6. H • b. 6.18. It is vnpossible that God should lye. And this thing, not to lye, is not a want of power, but a signe of greater power in God.

div.head: Quest. 20. Can we not be sustained to eternall life, vnlesse wee eate the flesh of Christ, and drinke his bloud?
div.p:
Answ. Christ himselfe answereth this question, Ioh. 6.
Ioh. 6.53.54. saying, Verily, verily, I say vnto you. Except yee eate the flesh of the Sonne of Man, and drinke his bloud, yee haue no life in you. Whosoeuer eateth my flesh, and drinketh my bloud, hath euerlasting life, and I will raise him vp at the last day, &c.

div.head: EXPOSITION.
div.p:
HOw, and in what sence, the flesh of Christ is said to be eaten, and his bloud to be drunke, wee shall take special consideration (God willing) when
we come to the one and twentieth question.

In this place it may suffice, to consider somewhat generally: That our Lord Iesus Christ, is the fountaine and well-spring of life, and all good things: from whose fulnesse, aboundantly floweth sufficient grace and vertue, for the perpetuall satisfying, and refreshing of all such as hunger and thirst after the same; as this is notably confirmed in that description which he maketh of himselfe, Io. 7. Ioh. 7.37, 38, • 9. where hee not onely most louingly inuiteth all such as thirst after grace, mercy, and saluation, to come vnto him to drinke, and to refresh themselues: but absolutely also pronounceth, that he that beleeueth in him, out of his belly shall flowe Riuers of water of Life. And presently after, This (saith the Euangelist) spake he of the Spirit, which they that beleeued in him, should receiue. Hereunto appertaineth that also, Ioh. 4. where he saith in plaine termes, that if the woman of Samaria had had knowledge and faith to haue desired the same at his hands, hee would haue freely sufficed her with the water of life. Ioh. 4.1 c. If thou knewest (saith he) the gift of God, and who it is that
saith to thee, Giue me drinke, thou wouldest haue asked him, and hee would haue giuen thee the water of Life. This is further apparant, Ioh. 6. Ioh. 6.35.48. where he calleth himselfe the Bread of Life; nourishing (as it were) vpholding, and preseruing to eternall life, all such as truely and faithfully beleeue in his name; euen as earthly meat & drinke nourisheth, vpholdeth, and preserueth in this life, all such as eate it, receiue, and digest it: Ieu. 26.26. Ezek. 4.16. C • ap. 5.16. that euen as materiall bread is the staffe, and stay of our nourishment, (as the Scripture termeth it, and as we sée by experience, that without the same, we cannot possibly continue in life, and health;) euen so is our Lord Iesus Christ, the only meanes of our preseruation to eternall life: without the enioying and partaking of whom, and of whose righteousnesse and redemption, there is no remedy, but fearefully to perish both soule and body for euermore: That he, I say, and no other, either thing, or person, is the onely spirituall food, and nourishment of our soules, by whom alone we are reconciled vnto God, and kept in vnity with him to eternall life; and without whom, wee by sinne remaine separated from God, & so in death
eternall. And therefore notably, 1. Ioh: 5.1. Ioh. 5.12. He that hath the Sonne, hath life; and hee that hath not the Sonne of God, hath not life. Vnto this excellent fulnesse, and fountaine of life, Christ Iesus (long time before his comming in the flesh) had the Prophet Esay relation, chapter 55. where we may see, how earnestly he exhorteth all such as hunger and thirst after saluation, that they should come, and seeke the same plentifully in Christ, & sharply blameth all those, who forsaking or neglecting Christ, doe seeke the satisfying of their hungry & thirsty soules by other meanes Ho,
Esa. 55.1.2, 3. euery one that thirsteth (saith hee) come ye to the waters, and ye that haue no siluer, come buy, and eate; come, I say, buy Wine and Milke, without siluer, and without money. Wherefore doe yee lay out siluer, and not for bread, and your labour without beeing satisfied? Hearken diligently vnto me, and eate that which is good. And a little after: Encline your eares, and come vnto mee: Heare, and your soule shall liue. Whereunto agreeth the complaint of the Lord by the Prophet, Ier chap. 2. Ier. 2.13. My people haue forsaken mee the fountaine of liuing waters, to digge them pits, euen broken pits that
can hold no water. The which prophesies, that they were foretold, and spoken of Christ, and of that excellent fulnesse that should be in him, it is so cleere in the places already alledged, that wee cannot desire any thing more apparant.

But now, if we shall yet a little further consider, how our Lord Iesus Christ is made after this manner, the spirituall food and nourishment of our soules: wee must ascend higher in this consideration, then to the humanity of Christ, or to his naturall body and bloud, and conceiue that hee is the bread of life, and our spirituall nourishment, as he is in one person both God and Man. Reason. For euen as all kinde of nourishment hath some proportion of likenesse, with that body which it nourisheth: euen so Christ, the naturall Son of God, became Man, that by that likenesse and proportion with vs, he might bee apt and fit nourishment to sustaine vs to eternall life: He being to this end humbled and abased to the death of the Crosse, where his body was broken, and his bloud-shed: where he offered himselfe to God the Father, a full and perfect sacrifice for our sinnes: And so consequently being afterward
raised from death, to life, became a very true, yea, the onely true sustenance to eternall life, aptly, and truely in all respects, prepared for our soules: and not onely for our soules, but euen for our bodies also; hee dying for the preseruation as well of the one, as of the other.

Acknowledging then the Lord Iesus to bee the onely Fountaine, Vse. and well-spring of life: wee must be religiously carefull, (according to that which hath bin taught) to seeke the refreshing, and satisfying of our hungry and thirsty soules, onely, and altogether of his fulnesse, and that euermore with an vndoubted assurance of obtaining our desire: Not according to the doctrine of the Papists, standing in doubt whether he will be so gracious or no: but remembring what S. Iames saith, chap. 1. He that wauereth, is like a waue of the Sea,
Iam. 1.6. driuen with the winde, and tossed. Wee therefore he cleerely resolued, and out of all doubt:

Alwayes yet, taking heed withall, that herein wee presume not too farre, but knowing that this foode of life appertaineth onely to such, as feeling the want thereof, doe desire refreshing: that therefore
in the feare of God, we pray and beseech the Lord to open our eyes, that wee may see and féele our wants, the wretched and miserable estate that we are in by reason of our sinnes: it being most sure and certaine, that as the case stood with the Iewes in times past, so it stands with many of vs at this day. We are in a miserable case, through want of this sweet and heauenly food, and yet wretched men and women (as we are for the most part) we doe not see nor perceiue it. The hunger and thirst of the body, we can quickly see and complaine of; but as for the want and necessity of the soule, many of vs haue no sence or feeling at all. A rare matter to heare one (so much as once in all his life) to complaine of the want of sauing knowledge, faith, repentance, patience, zeale of Gods glory, peace of conscience, ioy in the Holy Ghost, or any other sanctifying grace of Gods Spirit. To asswage the hunger and thirst of the body, no cost or paines is thought too much: but to prouide for the good estate of the soule, to furnish the same, and to satisfie the hungry and thirsty desires thereof, (by the ordinary meanes which God hath appointed,)
the least cost & the least paines, is thought to be enough, if not too much: Nay, though it be freely offered, we regard it not. Thus are wee at this day (for the most part) as ignorant of our miseries, and as sencelesse in our sinnes, as euer were the Iewes, or any other in times past. And therefore no maruell, though there be no more true zeale of Gods glory, no more true loue of religion and godlinesse, no more care or conscience to walke vprightly in the wayes of Gods cōmandements, to be found among men: these, and such like graces (indeed) being not common to euery one, but proper onely to Gods children, which feele the want of them (as I said before) and hunger and thirst after them. According, as none but such, doth our Lord Iesus Christ call vnto him, Math. 11. Mat. 11.28. And vnto none but such doth he promise a comfortable refreshing, saying, Come vnto mee, all ye that labour, and are heauy laden, and I will giue you rest.

div.head: Quest. 21. Doe all such as receiue the Sacrament, feede vpon Christ, to eternall life?
div.p: Answ. Not euery one without exception, but such only as are Gods elect, Ioh. 10.15, 28. Phil. 1.29.

div.head: EXPOSITION.
div.p:
THE Bread and Wine at the Lords Table (as I haue shewed before) being set apart by prayer and thanksgiuing, broken, giuen, receiued, eaten, and drunke, is a most holy Sacrament, and representation of Christs body and bloud, broken and shed for vs vpon the Crosse. An holy Sacrament and representation (I say) of Christs body and bloud, but not the body and bloud of Christ it selfe. For wee must not confound the outward signe, and the thing signified, but their seuerall natures must be distinguished. Reason 1 For if the nature of the parts were vnited, or naturally knit together, either by changing the substance of the Bread, (as the Papists most grosly imagine:) or
by an inseparable concomitance (as the Lutherans professe) then must it needes follow indeede, (as here it is demanded,) that all such as receiue the Sacrament, do in like manner feede vpon Christ to eternall life: that all they which partake of the signes, must of necessity be partakers also of the things signified. Which to hold and beleeue, is most absurd, and statly repugnant to the examples and testimonies of the Scripture: For Simon Magus receiued the outward signe in Baptisme, but of the thing signified, hee was very farre. And as the Apostle teacheth, 1. Cor. 10. the ancient Fathers before Christs comming, did eate of the same spirituall meate, and dranke of the same spirituall drinke, &c. but yet with many of them God was not pleased, for he ouerthrew them in the wildernes. Shall wee say now that either Simon Magus, or these Fathers, receiued together with the outward elements, Christ Iesus, and his sauing graces, thereby represented? Surely if they had God would not haue beene displeased with them, nor depriued them of the sweet and comfortable fruits, and effects therof. The Sacrament is one thing, and the
thing signified is another thing. The Sacrament is receiued with the hand, it entreth into the mouth, nourisheth the body, & hath a passage out of the body againe, as other meate and drinke. But the thing signified, which is Christs body & bloud, is not receiued by the hand, but in the heart by faith in Christs death and redemption, as we shal see more fully in the next point. A wicked man, yea a very reprobate, may receiue the Sacrament, and be damned when he hath done, but onely such as are Gods elect, in receiuing the Sacrament, Reason 2 doe feede vpon Christ to eternall life. And the reasons are cleare, because our Lord Iesus Christ gaue his flesh to be crucified, Iob. 10.15, 28. Tit. 2.14. and his bloud to be shed, onely for their sakes, and for the spirituall nourishment Reason 3 of their soules onely: And because withall, onely they haue true faith to apprehend, Phil. 1.29. and apply it accordingly. But now, whereas the Papists are not ashamed to confirme, that wicked and vnfaithfull persons doe, in the partaking of the Sacrament, eate the flesh of Christ, and drinke his bloud, and yet neuer attaine eternall life: How grosse their errour is herein, or rather how blasphemous, let
vs consider by the repugnancy which it hath with Christs words, Ioh. 6. Ioh. 6.54. hee saith there, Whosoeuer eateth my flesh, and drinketh my bloud, hath eternall life. The Papists say: Some men, and namely, wicked men, & vnbeleeuers, may eate Christs flesh, and drinke his bloud, and yet be damned. Are not these assertions directly contrary the one to the other? They that eate the flesh of Christ, and drinke his bloud, haue eternall life, and shall be raysed vp at the latter day. But the wicked haue not Reason 1 eternall life by Christ, nor shall be raysed vp to life, but to damnation: therefore it is a false and wicked doctrine, that wicked men and vnbeleeuers doe eate the flesh of Christ, and drinke his bloud. For if they did, then should they be partakers of those benefits which Christ (truth it selfe) promiseth to them that eate him. And a little after, He that eateth my flesh,
Ioh. 6.56, 57. and drinketh my bloud, dwelleth in me, and I in him. As the liuing Father hath sent me, so liue I by the Father, and he that eateth mee, euen hee shall liue by mee. But the wicked ones Reason 2 dwell not in Christ, nor liue by him, therefore doe they not eate his flesh, nor drinke his bloud. But it is manifest (say the Papists)
1. Cor. 11.1. Cor. 11.27. that the body and bloud of Christ is eaten, and receiued of the wicked, the Apostle there affirming, that the vnworthy receiuers are guilty of the body and bloud of Christ. But the Apostle doth not there say (as they would haue him) Whosoeuer eateth the flesh of Christ, and drinketh his bloud vnworthily: but whosoeuer eateth of this bread, and drinketh of this cup of the Lord vnworthily, is guilty of the body and bloud of the Lord. Thus speaking of the Sacrament of Christs body and bloud, and not of Christs body and bloud it selfe: for that is alwayes worthily. & can neuer vnworthily be receiued. This difference (I say) is there alwayes between the Sacrament of Christs flesh and bloud, and the flesh and bloud of Christ it selfe. The Sacrament may be eaten well, and religiously of godly men, and not well, but prophanely, of wicked and vngodly men: But as for the flesh and bloud of Christ it selfe, that cannot be eaten and receiued at any time but well, and of the godly alone, & to their life and saluation, according to the expresse words of Christ, which I haue remembred. Sacramentally, the flesh and bloud
of Christ is said to be eaten, and drunke, in the vse of the Sacrament of both godly and vngodly: but truly spiritually and indéede, of the godly alone, and not onely sacramentally, as it is of the wicked: The Reason 3 godly bringing to the partaking of the Sacrament, not onely the mouth of the body, but also faith, the mouth of the soule: and the other not faith the mouth of the soule, but onely the mouth of the body. And therefore as vnto the godly, it is the seale of eternall life: so the other (not discerning the Lords body) in eating the bread, and drinking the wine, doe eate and drinke their owne damnation.

Wee must take héede therefore, Vse. that as often as we come to the Lords Table, we prepare not our téeth, and bodily mouth, but be duly mindfull to pray for grace before-hand, that not only sacramentally, but spiritually, truly, and indéed, we may eate the flesh of Christ, and drinke his bloud, and so according to his promise (dwelling in him, and he in vs) wee may in due and conuenient time, be raysed vp by him to eternall life.

div.head: Quest. 22. How doe Gods elect eate Christs flesh, and drinke his bloud?
div.p: Answ. By a true and liuely faith, in his death and redemption, Ioh. 6.35.

div.head: EXPOSITION.
div.p:
IT is not sufficient to our saluation, that we know, and beleeue, that the Sonne of God gaue his flesh to be crucified, and his bloud to be shed vpon the Crosse, for the life of the world, vnlesse therewithall wee also eate his flesh, and drinke his bloud. The words of our Sauiour being so expresse for the proofe of this, in the places which I haue alledged, Ioh. 6. that wee cannot desire any thing more apparant. Now to eate the flesh of the Sonne of man Christ Iesus, and to drinke his bloud, is (as you haue heard,) by a true and liuely faith to be made partakers of that righteousnes and redemption, which our Lord Iesus Christ, by the offering of his body, and powring out of his bloud, hath purchased and obtayned for vs: whereof most notably speaketh the Apostle, Rom. 3. Rom 3 24. And are iustified freely
by his grace, through the redemption that is in Christ Iesus. So then, hee doth eate Christs body, and drinke his blood, who doth truly and faithfully beleeue in Christ Iesus, as in the true Sonne of God, the onely Sauiour & Redeemer of the world, who beleeueth that he offered his flesh and bloud, which he tooke of vs, and like to vs in all things except sinne, a sacrifice vnto God his Father. A sacrifice (I meane for vs) vpon the Crosse, of reconciliation, and redemption; by which oblation and offering, he hath fully recouered eternall life, for all those that truly beleeue in him. And thus you see, how faith in the flesh, and bloud of Christ, is rightly set foorth in the Scripture, by the figuratiue terme of eating and drinking him. Forasmuch, as it Reason 1 hath not only the promise of life, but euen also that eternall life it selfe which is gotten, and obtayned by Christs flesh and bloud. For euen as no man can either haue this life, or enioy this life (according to the common order, and course of nature) vnlesse hee be first nourished in the wombe, and afterward with ordinary food of meate and drinke: so can no man possibly haue true and eternall life, vnlesse hee
be fed with the vertue and efficacie of this heauenly nourishment, namely, of the body and bloud of Christ, the which cannot be, except with a faithfull minde he apprehend Christ, and his redemption, beleeue in him, and trust in him. For this (I say stil) is to eate Christs flesh, & to drinke his bloud: First, to lay hold vpon the whole Passion of Christ with vndoubted confidence and assurance, and thereby to obtaine forgiuenesse of sinnes, and life euerlasting.

And now, that faith is the mouth and meanes whereby onely wee receiue, and eate Christ to saluation: I will make it appeare by Christs owne words, Ioh. 6. where he vseth these words indifferently, as being all of one force and signification: To beleeue in him, to come vnto him, to eate him, and to drinke him. To beleeue in Christ, is the proper word: to eate Christ, or to come vnto him, are metaphoricall, and figuratiue speeches, but all of one sence. Ioh. 6 35. I am the bread of life (saith he) he that commeth to me, shall not hunger, and hee that beleeueth in me, shall neuer thirst.
Reason 2 Marke well these words. Hee that commeth to me (saith Christ) shall not hunger:
therefore to come vnto Christ, is to eate Christ. And againe, he saith, Hee that beleeueth in me, shal neuer thirst, therefore to beleeue in Christ, is to drinke Christ. To eate and to drink, are means to take away hunger and thirst: but to come vnto Christ, and to beléeue in him, doth (as himselfe saith) take away hunger and thirst: therefore to come vnto Christ, and to beleeue in Christ, is to eate him, and to drink him. Hee attributeth also in that Chapter, Reason 3 the very same effects & fruits to them which beleeue in him, that he doth to them that eate his body, and drinke his blood; therefore by eating and drinking, he meaneth nothing but beleeuing. Ioh. 6.54. He that eateth my flesh, and drinketh my bloud (saith he) hath eternall life, and I will raise him vp at the last day. Note the effects that he giueth to the eating of his flesh, and drinking of his bloud, which is, to haue eternall life, and be raysed vp at the last day.
Ioh. 6.40. In verse 40. of the same Chapter, he saith, This is the will of my Father that sent mee, that euery one that seeth the Sonne, and beleeueth in him, should haue eternall life, and I will raise him vp at the last day. Who seeth not heere, that Christ attributeth the same force to
beleeuing, that in the other verse hee did to eating and drinking, and therfore vseth the words indifferently, as being of one meaning. I might produce many other places, wherein the holy Ghost witnesseth, that we haue eternall life by beleeuing in Christ: but the point is plaine enough by Christs owne words, that to beleeue in Christ, is to feede vpon him. Now if any thinke, that this spirituall eating by faith, is but a slight matter, and of no great weight, such men doe not consider the great vertue, power, and strength of faith. For by faith we doe not only know Christ, and the true meanes of our saluation by him: but thereby we also receiue Christ, and assure our selues in our hearts, that we are partakers of that redemption, which by his death hee hath procured for vs, and with that firme perswasion lay him vp in the bowels of our hearts, that in all our temptations and troubles, wee may feede vpon him, and gather strength and comfort in the assurance of Gods fauour purchased by him: so that so often as our hearts are shaken with mistrust and feare; this faith doth comfort and relieue vs againe. By faith wee are graffed into
Christ, as branches into the root and stock, so that wee now liue by him, and by his Spirit, as the branches doe by the iuice that commeth from the roote of the tree. By faith we be so vnited vnto Christ, that we may iustly say, whatsoeuer is his, is ours also. Of this speciall gift and grace of God, I haue spoken more at large in Question 13: vpon all which conferred, and compared together, I may clearely conclude, that this excellent vertue, and strength of faith, they neither feele nor vnderstand, who thinke it a slight and simple matter, to eate Christ by faith.
And now to make some vse of that Vse 1 which hath beene spoken:

Euen, as when wee are desirous of bodily nourishment, wee must come to the partaking of it, where it is to be had: so, for the partaking of Christ Iesus to our spirituall nourishment and saluation, wee must likewise repaire & resort vnto him. For as their bodies cannot be nourished, who come not to the eating of that corporall foode that is prepared for them, no more can their soules be satisfied, and preserued by Christ Iesus crucified, which come not accordingly to the partaking of
him. Ioh. 6.35. For, he that commeth to mee (saith Christ) shall not hunger, that is, hee shall be throughly satisfied, and sustayned to eternall life. Whereupon it clearely followeth on the contrary, that hee which commeth not to Christ, he cannot be satisfied, but must still endure both hunger and thirst, euen vntill he finally perish through the same. Now as concerning the right manner of comming vnto Christ: euen as bodily meate, be it neuer so dainty and delicate, is nothing profitable to him that feeleth no want of it, and hath no strength to receiue and digest it: Ioh. 7.37. so, nothing at all profitable is Iesus Christ vnto all such as feele no want of him, through the sence and consideration of their wretched and miserable estate, and therewithall also, are voyde of faith to apprehend and apply his righteousnesse and redemption to the forgiuenesse of their sinnes, to their iustification, and eternall life. Much might be adde • to the amplification of this point: but this in few words is the summe of all, that whosoeuer will be partakers of the bread of life, Christ Iesus, to eternall life, they must come vnto him with a due consideration, Math. 11.28. and with an humble and penitent
confession, and acknowledgement of their manifold sinnes, and grieuous transgressions, as how in regard thereof, they are worthy of nothing but of Gods fearefull wrath and heauy indignation, hauing no meanes of their owne to escape the same, and bring with them withall, a true and liuely faith in his name, as in the onely Sonne of God, the alone true promised Messiah, and Redeemer, through faith in whose name, they are sure of saluation; and without whom, there is no hope, Acts 4.12. or possibility of attayning it.

This must be the manner of our comming vnto Christ at this day, not with such affections, as the Iewes resorted vnto him in times past, some in hypocrisie, some for their bellies, some with a regard onely of his bodily presence, but our comming vnto him must be in truth and sincerity, for the good of our soules, and for the partaking of his righteousnesse and redemption, according as hee is made vnto vs of God, wisedome, righteousnes, 1. Cor. 1.30. sanctification, and redemption. And not at this, or that particular place, but wheresoeuer the Doctrine of his Gospell is purely preached: it being most sure, and certain,
that in the Ministery and preaching of the Gospell, is the Lord Iesus especially to be found at this day, and therein most familiarly doth hee reueale and discouer himselfe. And therefore in hearing the same, and in resorting thereunto, must all such as desire to finde Christ, take most paines, and with greatest diligence imploy themselues. Ioh. 5.39. Searching the Scriptures also to this end, for a right discerning of the truth, and praying vnto God for the assistance of his grace in this respect.

Heere we may consider the end of his comming, the manner of his birth, the afflictions of his life, the miracles which he wrought, the doctrine which hee taught, all the circumstances of his humiliation, and sufferings, to the reprochful death vpon the Crosse, together with his glorious Resurrection and ascension; the manner of his sitting at the right hand of God; the office of his mediation; the gouernment of his Kingdome, with the order of his glorious appearing vnto Iudgement. All these particulars of the sound knowledge of Christ, are so cleerely laid open in the doctrine of his Word, that wee need not
now say, (as it is Rom. 10. Rom. 10.6, 7, 8.) Who shall ascend into Heauen; or who shall descend into the deep? The word is neere, &c. Now as this is the way that we must go, to come vnto Christ for the partaking of him to our spirituall nourishment, and saluation: and as this is the place where he is to be found: so must we not content our selues to come vnto him after this manner, once, or some fewer times, and when we are at leisure, and haue nothing else to doe, (as is the vse of many) but we must learne dayly to goe after him, and the more wee come vnto him, the more must our loue bee inflamed towards him, as Psal. 105. Psal. 105.4. Seeke the Lord and his strength, seeke his face continually. And that too, without dallying, and deferring the time, as Esay 55. Esa. 55.6. Seek the Lord while he may be found, call vpon him while he is neere, &c.

Secondly, we may heere obserue (to our vnspeakeable comfort) the very great Vse 2 difference, betwixt this spirituall feode of our soules, and the ordinary meat & drinke of the body. Our earthly meat and drinke, though it be neuer so dainty or delicate, receiued sparingly, or to the full, yet can it nourish but for a time: Though wee eate
and drinke neuer so plentifully to day, yet shall we bee hungry and thirsty againe to morrow, and haue as much need to refresh our selues as before. Men are notwithstanding subiect to sicknesses, and diseases, to lamenesse, blindnesse, crookednes, old age, and at length are all swallowed vp of death, not one can escape. Yea, and which is more, though men keepe neuer so good a dyet, make neuer so good choise, yet where there is one that liueth vntill he come to old age, many slip away in their flourishing youth, and in the time of their greatest strength. But as for the vertue and efficacy of this spirituall meat of the flesh and bloud Christ Iesus, (eaten and receiued by faith the mouth of the soule) the same is farre otherwise, and hath a farre other manner of operation: insomuch, that whosoeuer hath once truely tasted the sweetnesse thereof, receiued, and digested it in his soule, the soule of such a one, euen in this life, shal haue true peace of conscience, sound ioy in the holy Ghost; it shall not not decay in strength, but grow & increase in faith, repentance, patience, loue and al other like sauing and sanctifying graces: and when the time
of their dissolution is come, and the Lord seeth it good to take them out of this life, they shall then first in soule, and then both in body and soule, be made partakers of eternall life. Thus you see, how rightly our Lord Iesus Christ saith, Ioh. 6. Ioh. 6.55. that his flesh is meat indeed, and his bloud is drinke indeed. As hauing in truth and indeed, the onely vertue and efficacy of all sound nourishment, and preseruation; all earthly meat and drinke, in comparison thereof, being not worthy the name of meat and drinke, as not able to continue and preserue for any long time; no, not so much as this earthly and transitory life.

The last vse then hereupon is this, that Vse 3 seeing there is so great difference betwixt the food of the body, and the food of the soule: that therefore, as our Sauiour exhorteth, Ioh. 6. Ioh. 6.27. wee labour not for the meat which perisheth, but for the meat which endureth to eternall life: Considering, that neither in the abundance, nor in the want of these earthly things, there is any truth or soundnes; but onely in spirituall and heauenly things, purchased and obtained by Iesus Christ. Are we affected with any worldly ioy, vpon any
outward occasion whatsoeuer? Let vs know, that it is not the true ioy, the ioy of the soule is better; the ioy of Gods kingdome much more surpassing. Are we afflicted with any bodily paine or griefe? Let vs know, that this is not the true affliction, the griefe of the soule for sinne, is much more grieuous, the paines of hell much farre exceeding. Are wee delighted with the sweetnesse of any delicious or dainty delicats? Let vs remember, that the flesh of Christ is meat indeed, and the bloud of Christ is drinke indeede: and therefore, consequently, whatsoeuer become of this life, we euermore especially hunger and thirst, after that so swéet and heauenly a feeding. These are the vses that wee are to make of this point: and the Lord grant, that thus wee may apply this doctrine, and take comfort by it in our seuerall soules, and not (as the most part doe) preferre earthly vanities, before heauenly pleasures and euerlasting blessednesse; the food of our bodies, before the foode of our soules, and the saluation of them; the effecting of our owne will and pleasure in the matters of this life, before the aduancement of Gods glory, & the sincere
obedience of his will: but as our Sauiour himselfe exhorteth, Math. 6. Math. 6.33 Let vs first seeke the Kingdome of God, and his righteousnesse, and all other things shall bee added vnto vs.

div.head: Quest. 23. How shall a man know himselfe to be of the number of them that are elected?
div.p: Answ. By the witnesse of Gods Spirit, working in him true repentance, and framing his heart to beleeue, and to yeeld obedience, according to the Word and will of God, Rom. 8.16. Ephes. 1.13, 14.

div.head: EXPOSITION.
div.p:
FOr the better vnderstanding of this point: I will consider it in these three branches. First, I will make it appeare, that the Lord God, before the foundation of the world, hath freely in Christ Iesus, elected some to life and saluation. Secondly, that such as are elected, haue the Spirit of Christ, bearing witnesse with their spirits, that they are of
this number. And thirdly, that the Spirit doth thus beare witnesse, by working in them true repentance, and by framing their hearts to beleeue, and obey according to the will and Word of God.

As touching the first, that the Lord God hath elected a certaine number: it is euident, where our Sauiour Christ saith, Ioh. 13. Ioh. 13.18. I speake not of you all, I know whom I haue chosen. And that this was before the foundation of the world, it is plaine, Ephes. 1. Ephes. 1.4. where the Apostle saith in expresse termes; He hath chosen vs in him, (that is in Christ) before the foundation of the world. To this effect also, 2. Tim. 1.2. Tim. 1.9. And for this cause doth our Lord Iesus Christ affirme, Math. 25. Mat. 25.34 that after this manner, shall the sentence of euerlasting life bee pronounced at the last Day: Come ye blessed of my Father, inherit ye the Kingdome prepared for you from the foundation of the world. So manifestly teaching, that they were ordained thereunto from euerlasting.

It is euident also, that this election is onely and altogether of the Lords free goodnes, and meere mercy. For Iacob (as the Apostle teacheth, Rom. 9. Rom. 9.11.) nothing
at all deserued to bee preferred before his brother Esau: but as our Lord Iesus Christ speaketh, Math. 11. Mat. 11.26 this is euen because such was the goodwill and pleasure of God. And according to that of the Apostle, where he teacheth, Luke 10.21 that of his méere mercy and grace, through Faith in Christ his Sonne, hee hath chosen and preferred to life, whom he will haue to be saued, and accounted among the iust.

And to make it yet more plaine, that Reason 1 onely some are thus chosen in Christ before the foundation of the world: it may appeare by this; For if God had decreed, to communicate his glory and mercy to all and euery one, then there could be no election. For he that taketh all, cannot bee said to chuse: And therefore saith the Lord, Math. 20. Mat. 20.16 Many are called, but few are choten. And Ioh. 10. Our Lord Iesus Christ speaking of such is in the eternall counsell of God, are ordained to life and saluation, and whom he there termeth his sheepe; I giue vnto them (saith he) eternall life; not to all, but to them. And Ioh. 17. Ioh. 10.28. Ioh. 17.9. I pray for them, I pray not for the world, but for them which thou hast giuen mee, for they are thine.

Now, if it hee demanded, whether the least, or the greatest number of the sonnes and children of men are thus chosen, and ordained to eternall life: The Text is plaine, Math. 7. Mat. 7.14. and they are the words of our Lord Iesus Christ himselfe, that it is a straight gate, and a narrow way that leadeth vnto life, and few there bee that finde it. The best number is commonly the smallest number. And the Scripture giues great light for the proofe of it in many places. But of this, there can bee no doubt, continuall experience making it apparant.

As concerning the second branch, that such as are elected, haue the Spirit of Christ, &c. This is cleerely taught by the Apostle, Rom. 8. Rom. 8.9. where he saith expressely If any man haue not the Spirit of Christ, hee is none of his. From whence wee learne, that this is a most certaine, and infallible token, whereby the Children of God are knowne, and discerned from the wicked; because onely Gods Children haue the Spirit of Christ, whereby they are mooued, regenerate, and directed to true innocency, and holinesse of life. They onely (I say) haue the Spirit, that is, the gifts and
graces of the Spirit: the which Spirit doth not onely make their consciences void of care, quiet, and at peace before God, in the matter of their election and iustification, and in all the temptations and troubles of the world: but guideth and leadeth them also into all truth, both as concerning the knowledge, and the practice of it: assuring them withall of the free forgiuenesse of all their sins, and of the euerlasting saluatiō of their soules▪ It is God (saith the Apostle, 2. Cor. 1.2. Cor. 1.21, 22. who hath anointed vs, who hath also sealed vs, and hath giuen vs the earnest of his Spirit in our hearts. And Ephes. 1. Ephes. 1.13, 14. Yee were sealed with the holy Spirit of promise, which is the earnest of our inheritance, vntill the Redemption of the possession purchased, vnto the praise of his glory. Also Rom. 8. Rom. 8.16. The Spirit it selfe beareth witnesse with our Spirits, that we are the Children of God. And 1. Ioh. 4.1. Ioh. 4.13. Hereby wee know that wee dwell in him, and he in vs; because he hath giuen vs of his Spirit. And againe,1. Ioh. 5.10. He that beleeueth in the Sonne of God, hath the witnesse in himselfe. All these places plainly proue, that all Gods elect haue the Spirit of Christ bearing witnes with their spirits,
that they are of that number. Lastly, proue your selues (saith the Apostle 2. Cor. 13.2. Cor. 13.5.) whether yee are in the Faith. And to what purpose is this spoken, if by the euidence of Gods Spirit wee cannot know our selues to be in the state of grace and saluation? And presently after, Know you not your selues, how that Iesus Christ is in you, except yee be Reprobates? Whereby hee sheweth, that to proue a mans selfe, whether hee be in the Faith, is to proue whether Christ bee in him, because the faith which he speaketh of, is that liuely Faith, whereby Christ dwelleth in our hearts. And if Christ be in you;
Ephes. 3.17. the body (as he saith Rom. 8 Rom. 8.10. is dead as touching sinne, but the Spirit is life for righteousnesse sake. So that whosoeuer feeleth himselfe dead to sinne, and aliue to righteousnesse, and to haue such other vertues, as wherewith the Spirit of Christ, endueth them in whom he doth dwell: such a one may vndoubtedly be assured, that he is in the number of Gods elect, and without all danger of condemnation. Rom. 8.1.

This alwayes withall, being duely obserued that in this certainety & assurance of election, (whereof we speake) wee exclude
not that kinde of doubting, which oftentimes ariseth in Gods Children, through the infirmity of their nature, and through the sight & consideration of their sinnes: but that wilfull doctrine, and resolution of doubting, for which the Papists contend and striue;

It being most sure and certaine, that Reason 2 there can bee no greater torment to a tender conscience, then to stand in doubt of Gods fauour and loue. For he that doubteth of Gods loue towards him, cannot loue God againe. And when a man hath not the loue of God in him, hee hath no grace, and his conscience must needs bee defiled; yea, he must needs bee a wicked man. And this saying of Salomon, Prou. 28. Prou. 28.1. belongs vnto him: The wicked flyeth, when no man pursueth him (meaning through the guiltinesse of his conscience) but the godly is bold as a Lyon. Indeed, when we looke vpon our selues, and examine our manifold infirmities, and goings astray, we shall see sufficient cause to stand in doubt: but looking withall vpon Gods promises of grace and mercy in Christ Iesus, and vpon the fruits and effects of his Spirit of sanctification in our
hearts: in, and by them, wee shall haue sufficient cause to bee cleerely resolued, and out of all doubt. Whosoeuer (I say) thus feeles this gracious worke of the holy Spirit of God in him. Such a one need not be discouraged in regard of his infirmities, and manifold transgressions: as hauing sufficient matter in himselfe, to answere all obiections of the World, the Flesh, and the Diuell; as also for true peace of conscience, ioy in the Holy Ghost, assurance of Gods loue, and of eternall life.

Ob.But now by the way, if it be demanded whether this assurance and certainty of saluation doe not make the Elect children of God, idle, carelesse, and vnprofitable in the matters of Gods glory, and of their owne saluation?

Sol.The Papists indeed doe thus alledge, calling this doctrine of Gods frée grace, in election, and iustification, (but most wickedly) a doctrine of liberty, and which openeth a wide gappe and window to all Reason 3 manner of sinne and licentiousnesse: But that it is a blasphemous slander, hauing no countenance or likelihood of truth in it, but altogether false and erroneous;
it is hereby manifest, because the same spirit, which is the Spirit of Faith, and perswadeth our consciences to beléeue the great goodnes and mercy of God in our election and free iustification, is also the spirit of loue, and doth inflame our hearts, to loue so gracious, and so mercifull a God, as vouchsafed without all respect of any worthinesse or deserts, as either was, or could bee in vs, to deale so graciously and louingly with vs. Now then, if by the motion of one and the same Spirit, we doe by faith assuredly know Gods goodnesse towards vs in Christ Iesus, and by the knowledge, and true sence thereof, do loue him vnfainedly for the same: needs must there follow obedience to his commandements, and a perpetuall study to serue and please him. The assurance of election, and saluation then, (as wee see) makes not Gods Children secure & carelesse, but breeds in them a loue of God; and loue bringeth forth obedience to his will. For if any man loue mee (saith Christ Ioh. 14. Ioh. 14.23.) he will keepe my Word.

Secondly, the selfesame doctrine of the Gospell, that teacheth vs, that by Gods free grace, and méere mercy in Christ Iesus
we are elected, and made heires of saluation. Tit. 2.11.12. Ephes. 2.10. Luke 1.74.75. The selfesame doctrine doth also teach vs, that the end of this speciall grace and fauour is, that we should glorifie God in our mortall bodies, so much the more, and not bee slaues and seruants vnto sin: the wages & recompence whereof, is eternall death and condemnation.

Now to proceede to the third Branch. The Spirit of Christ (as you haue heard) doth beare witnesse of election, by working in the Elect true repentance, Rom. 6.23. and by framing their hearts to beleeue, and obey according to the will and Word of God.

div.head: Of Repentance.
div.p: True repentance may thus be defined.
It is an vnfained turning of the whole man, from all sinne vnto God.
That repentance is a turning, the Scripture sheweth in many places.

Esay 9.13. Hosea 6 1. cha. 14.2.Now I call it an vnfained turning, because there is a kinde of repentance and turning vnto God, which is fained, hypocriticall, counterfet: Such as was the repentance of Cain, Esau, Pharao, Iudas: And (I say) it must bee of the whole man, Ier. 4 1. that is, both of soule and body,
in euery part and faculty thereof, Ioel 2.12. Acts 26.20 because to turne in one part, and not in another, will not serue the turne. There must bee a change of the heart, Mat. 12.35 Deut. 6.5. Mat. 16.24 and a reformation of the whole life, or else there is no true repentance. And as this turning must bee a turning of the whole man; so also from all sinne: not from some speciall sinne, or from some few, but from all. and euery one Knowing, that the least sin that is, deserueth death, and is most odious, and loathsome before the face of God. Psal 51.5, 9 The which turning of the whole man from all sinne, must bee with godly sorrow, arising from a serious sence and consideration of sinne, Psal. 130.3. (as it is sinne) and with a settled • esolution (through the grace of Gods Spirit, Rom. 7.24.) not to sinne any more, but to forsake, and detest all sinne for the time to come.

And lastly, as to be truly repentant, wee must thus vnfaynedly in the whole man turne from all sinne, so must our turning be vnto GOD, with a penitent acknowledging and confession of all transgressions, with an hearty desire after mercie and forgiuenes, & with ioy and chéerefulnes of spirit, arising from the assurance
of Gods loue and fauour in Christ: desiring inwardly in our hearts, Psal. 51.12. and endeuouring outwardly in the whole course of our conuersation, to frame our liues according to his holy Word.

Luke 19.6, 8.This I take to be a sound (if not a full) definition and description of repentance: of the particular parts & branches whereof, I cannot now stand to entreate, euery of them requiring a large discourse, and I haue often had occasion to remember them at other times.
In this place, it will be sufficient, if I make it appeare that true repentance is a speciall worke of Gods grace, and blessed Spirit, and that it is proper only to Gods elect.

That it is a speciall worke of Gods grace, it is expresly proued, Ier. 31. Ier. 31.18. where the Church of God, vnder the title of Ephraim, acknowledgeth God to be the Authour of her conuersion, saying, Conuert thou me, and I shall be conuerted, for thou art the Lord my God. And it is apparant also, Acts 5. Acts 5.31. where the Apostle Peter saith of our Lord Iesus Christ, that God hath lift him vp with his right hand to bee a Prince and a Sauiour, to giue repentance to
Israel, and forgiuenesse of sinnes. And in chap. 11. it is recorded, Acts 11.13. that when the Church, and people of GOD, had heard from Peter what great mercy GOD had shewed to the Gentiles, they glorified God, saying, Then hath God to the Gentiles granted repentance vnto life. And herevpon also it is, that the Apostle Paul thus speaketh to Timothy, 2. Tim. 2.2. Tim. 2.25, 26. Instructing them with meekenesse, that are contrary minded, prouing if God at any time will giue them repentance, &c. And not without Reason 4 good reason is repentance said to be the gift of God, and a speciall work and grace of his Spirit, because the conuersion of the heart, and inward man, is as great a worke as the creation of it: As an infinite power is required to create, so also to a true conuersion and changing of the corrupt and naturall affections.

Againe, as no man can raise vp a dead Reason 5 body, nor quicken himselfe, but it must be the voyce of Christ (as Ioh. 5. Ioh. 5.28.) so must it be onely God, that must conuert the heart, and worke repentance in it: All being by nature dead in trespasses and sinnes, as we haue already learned out of Eph. 2. Eph. 2.1. and Col. 2. Col. 2.13. And if it be demanded, why God
doth then in so many places exhort men to repentance, if they haue no power therevnto in themselues? The answere is cleare: that the Lord doth not exact repentance at our hands, as if it lay in our owne power: but that considering by such commandements and exhortations, the great necessity of repentance, and our own great weaknesse, and inability hereunto, wee should be stirred vp with so much the more zeale and feruencie, to craue this speciall grace at his hands.

To make it plain also in the next place, that only Gods elect can truly repent and turne to GOD: this is proued, Esay 59. Esay 59.20. where the Lord promiseth the Redeemer onely vnto them that turne from iniquity in Iacob: So, that they only, for whom Christ dyed, can repent. And not without good reasons is true repentance proper to Gods elect.

Reason 6 As first, because repentance and remission of sinnes are necessary consequents, Luke 24 47. the one of the other: for he that truly repenteth, shall haue remission of sinnes, and such as haue remission of sins, doe truly repent. Now, remission of sins belongs onely to Gods elect: therefore in
like manner doth also repentance. Reason 7

Secondly because true repentance, the grace of regeneration, and true faith, euer goe together, and are inseparable. Now if true faith, and the graces of regeneration and sanctification, be proper onely to the elect: it followeth, that none but they are likewise capable of this benefit of repentance. Reason 8

Againe, repentance in this life, and saluation in the life to come, are necessary consequents one of another (for whosoeuer repenteth, shall be saued, and whosoeuer shall be saued, doth repent:) but saluation is onely of the elect, theref • re is repentance also proper vnto them. And if hereupon it be demanded, why repentance is then preached to all, without exception, whether elect or reprobate? I answere, because, as the preaching of the Gospell is the meanes for the repentance and conuersion of the elect: so also to make the wicked altogether without excuse, all pretence of ignorance being by this meanes vtterly taken from them.

div.head: Of the Faith of Gods Elect.
div.p:
In the next place followeth the consideration of faith, which the Holy Ghost
settles in the hearts of Gods elect, and whereby also hee assureth them of their election. For (as you haue heard,) the Holy Ghost not onely worketh in the elect, true repentance (for the sealing of their assurance,) but also frameth their hearts to beleeue, &c.

That to beleeue aright, is a special gift and grace of God, proper onely to such as are elected, and settled in their hearts by the Spirit of God, we haue already seen • at large in Question 13. Now it remaineth onely to be obserued, that the holy Ghost frameth the hearts of Gods elect, to beleeue no otherwise, then according to the will and Word of God, as Rom. 10. Rom. 10.17 Faith commeth by hearing, hearing by the Word of God. The Word of God (I say) is so the foundation of that faith and beliefe, which the holy Ghost frameth, that if it be taken away, there will remaine no true faith, but a certaine lightnesse of beliefe, and a wandring error of the minds.

Reason 9 And the reason is cleare, because faith must be so grounded, as that it may abide inuincible, and certaine against all the engines of hell and death, and in the middest of all the temptations of the world, the
flesh, and the deuill; the which certainty, and sure ground-worke, is no where else to be found, but onely in Gods Word. So that to be assured of election, it is not enough to say, I beleeue in God, or I beleeue in Christ: but thou must beleeue in God, and in Christ, as the Word, and Gospell of Christ hath prescribed, and teacheth thee to beleeue. Hereby (I say) thou shalt know, whether the faith which thou hast, be a true faith, and whether the holy Ghost hath framed thy heart to beleeue, or no. For assure thy selfe, and be out of doubt, if the faith which is in thee, be not grounded vpon the Word & Gospell of Christ, if thou beleeue any otherwise then the Word, and Gospel of Christ doth prescribe and teach; thy beliefe is no witnesse of thy election, it is no true faith, it was neuer planted in thy heart by the holy Ghost. For there is euermore such a mutuall relation of faith to the Word of God, as that a true faith can be no more seuered from the Word, then the Sunne-beames from the Sunne: Yea, true faith hangeth vpon the Word of God alone, hath respect vnto, and wholly resteth thereupon. The Word and
doctrine of a mortall man, may fill and satisfie the eares, but it can neuer establish any true faith in the heart of him that heareth the same, nor confirme the minde in any quiet hope of eternall life. To doe this, is the proper office onely of Gods Word, accompanied with the ioynt assistance of Gods Spirit. For otherwise, Paul may plant, and Apollo may water, the Minister may preach, & apply the Word, and yet haue no good effect, either of faith, or of any other sauing or sanctifying grace ensuing vpon his labour.

div.head: Of the obedience of Gods elect.
div.p:
Obedience to the will and Word of Reason 10 God, being more acceptable then sacrifice, as also much more due, and of right belonging vnto him, then vnto any Parent, then vnto any Master, then vnto any Prince or Potentate whatsoeuer. Not without great cause therfore is the Scripture very plentifull, not onely in setting forth the commendation of the godly, in regard of their obedience, and in exhorting vs vnto the like,2. Pet. 1.10. for the making sure of our calling and election; but in describing also the examples of the disobedient, and the curse & wrath of God vpon them for their disobedience, whereby we might the more effectually be terrified from the same. As the example of Noah his obedience, Gen. 6. of Abraham, recorded to his high praise, Gen. 22.
Gen. 6.22. chap. 22.10. and Heb. 11.
Heb. 11.17. Of Moses and Aaron, Exod. 7.
Exod. 7 6. Of the Rechabites in obeying the commandement of their father Ionadab, recorded to their high commendation, Ier. 35.
Ier. 35.6. &c.
Of the Israelites, Numb 1.
Num 1.54. and Iosh. 1.
Iosh. 1.16. And especially of our Lord Iesus Christ himselfe, and of his
Apostles, as many particulars might be remembred. Heereunto appertaine also many notable exhortations and sentences in holy Scriptures, as that Heb. 10.
Heb. 10.5, 6, &c. out of Psal. 40.
Psa. 40.6, 7. that of Samuel to Saul, 1. Sam. 15. 1. Sam. 15.22. Also Rom. 6
Rom. 6.13. and cha. 1. and 4. of S. Iames. Examples of disobedience in wicked and vngodly reprobates, we haue in Saul, Cain, Pharao, and in many other.

Iam. 1.22. &c. chap. 4.7.But this being plaine, it remayneth to consider, that the obedience of Gods elect, to the will and commandements of the Lord, is a fruit of Christs Spirit in their hearts. For we of our selues are vtterly vnapt, and vnable to any good thing. Reason 11 And therefore thus prayeth Dauid vnto God, Psal. 143.
Psa. 143.10 Let thy good Spirit leade mee vnto the land of righteousnesse. And Gal. 5.
Gal. 5.16. Walke in the Spirit, and ye shall not fulfill the lusts of the flesh. That the Spirit of God (I say) is the principall, and efficient cause of this new obedience in Gods elect: yea, and so, as without the gracious worke, and assistance of the same Spirit, neither the preaching of the Gospell, nor any other meanes whatsoeuer, are any thing powerfull, or auaileable to worke and effect it: this is further confirmed
by the words of the Apostle, Rom. 15. where hee attributeth the comfortable effects of his office and ministery, in the obedience of the Gentiles, to the holy Spirit of God, Rom. 15 19 without the which all outward helpes would haue beene altogether vnprofitable, and so as they should neuerthelesse haue remayned so ouerwhelmed in their naturall corruption, as not to doe any thing holily and purely before the Lord. From the Spirit of God proceedeth that righteousnes, sanctification, and holinesse, without which no man shall see the Lord, as Heb. 12.
Heb. 12.14. true peace of conscience, and perfect ioy in the holy Ghost, all good counsels, all pure desires, and godly purposes. For although it be left in our power (inasmuch as wee are the Lords reasonable creatures) to will this, or that thing, to reason vpon this or that question, to thinke vpon this or that matter, and to doe this or that worke: yet to will, to reason, to thinke, speake, or doe any thing at all, in such sort as the Lord requireth of his chosen children, and so as the manner of performance may be acceptably receiued in Christ, as sincere obedience vnto God. This proceedeth not from flesh and
bloud, neither from the will of man, or of any other creature in heauen, or in earth, but onely from the most comfortable Spirit of our regeneration, whose peculiar office is to begin, continue, and finish in the children of God, these notable graces, and effects, to the glory of God, and to their eternall comfort and consolation. So teacheth the Apostle, Phil. 2. where after he hath charged the faithfull to work their saluation in feare and trembling: he presently addeth, Phil. 2.12.13. saying, For it is GOD that worketh in you both the will and the deed, euen of his •• d pleasure. Which is a most strong and forcible reason, to worke in vs a reuerend feare, and trembling, vnder the mighty h ••• of God, because, that although we had power to will, and to work in euery part and branch of that obedience which God requireth, yet the changing of our will to the acceptable performance of any thing in the sight of GOD, proceedeth onely from the holy Ghost. Yea, and so, that all such workes are carnall, earthly and deuillish, and but an hypocriticall shew of obedience, (in no measure at all pleasing God, what shew soeuer it make in the sight of men) which is either
settled in the heart, or appeareth in the life or conuersation of any, without the gracious working of the holy Ghost.

And now to make some vse of these particular Vse 1 branches: First, is it so, that God, before the foundation of the world, hath elected a certaine number to life and saluation? Let vs then examine our selues whether wee be of this number. If wee féele the Spirit of God preuailing in vs against the corrupt lusts, and motions of the flesh, and so as notwithstanding the manifold temptations of the world, the flesh and the deuill, wee first seeke Gods Kingdome, and the righteousnes thereof, and labour more for the meate that endureth to eternall life, then for that which perisheth: If we be religiously carefull to make the Word of God the Lanthorne for our féete, and a light for our pathes, and so as we grow in knowledge, faith, repentance, zeale of Gods glory, &c. according to such wholsome doctrines, and exhortations as are taught and deliuered: If we be separated from the wicked, and vngodly of the world, and so as wee runne not with them to the wayes of sinne: If we perceiue our selues to be sanctified in
all the parts and powers of our soules and bodies, to serue and obey the Lord with true zeale, and feruency of Spirit, according to the rule of his Word. These, and such like, are infallible testimonies of the grace of election, and that wee doe vndoubtedly belong to eternall life. Whereas on the contrary, if wee feele not these, nor any of them in any good measure, our estate is wretched and most miserable, what faire shew soeuer we may carry of a blessed condition in the view of the world. The deuill will suffer any man to say, that he is one of Gods elect, that his sinnes are forgiuen him, and that he hopeth to be saued: but wouldest thou come to the certainty of this indeede, and haue such a proofe of it, as may silence the deuill himselfe standing against it? Looke then to the holinesse of thy heart and life, according to these few particulars; and if thou be able from thence, to inferre, and conclude thy election; then surely thou art a happy man, and mayst minister such sound comfort to thy selfe at all times, as will neuer deceiue thee. By the workes of sanctification (I say) make thy election sure, as the Apostle Peter counselleth thée, 2. Epist.
chap. 1. and make an end of thy saluation in feare and trembling,2. Pet. 1.10. as the Apostle Paul doth aduise thee, Phil. 2.
Phil. 2.12. And nothing shall be able to separate thee from the loue of God.

Hereby also wee may make triall whether Vse 2 we haue the Spirit of Christ: For whosoeuer is elected, hee hath the Spirit of Christ, as I haue shewed before: And the Spirit of Christ is neuer idle in those in whom he abideth, but beares witnesse with their Spirits, of their vndoubted election by these, and such like effects.
