And for the further confirmation of this assurance, let this be noted, that wheresoeuer the holy Ghost dwelleth and abideth, there will he be Lord, gouerning both the heart, minde, will and affections, by repressing all bad motions vnto sinne, and by stirring vp good motions, and good affections, vpon euery occasion: whereupon saith the Apostle, Rom. 8.
Rom. 8. that as many as are led by the Spirit of God, they are the Sonnes of God. It makes a man to dislike of sinne, because it is sinne, and to haue a hungry desire, especially, and aboue all things, to be at peace and vnity with God through Christ Iesus, for the free forgiuenesse
of all their sinnes. And finally, it maketh all such as are endued with it, to grow & flou ish as a greene Garden, and as a tree planted by the riuers of waters, in all the graces of sanctification, not only for their owne peculiar good, and the sure sealing of their owne saluation, but also for the good, and saluation of others, according to euery mans place and calling, and the diuers occasions that are offered. He, that thus feeles the working of Gods Spirit, the same Spirit doth beare witnesse with his spirit, that hee is without all question, the elect child of God.

Vse 3 Hauing a cōfortable assurance, through the witnesse of Gods Spirit in our hearts (vpon this examination) that wee are in the number of Gods elect. Wee must take heede, as we tender the glory of God, and our owne saluation, that we be so far from taking occasion, or encouragement thereby, to sleepe in sinne and security, as if all should be well with vs, howsoeuer we behaue our selues; as cleane contrariwise to become inflamed, with so much the more feruent zeale, to glorifie GOD in the fruites of the Spirit, according to the vttermost of that measure of gifts and
grace, which we haue receiued.

Fourthly, seeing the holy Spirit of God workes true repentance in all Gods elect, let vs examine also how it is with vs in this particular. If we be vnfaynedty in euery part, and faculty of both soule and body, turned from all sinne, not from one sinne, or from some fewe, but from all and euery one, and that with godly sorrow, arising from a serious sence and consideration of sinne, and with a settled resolution (through the grace of Gods Spirit) not to sinne any more, but to forsake all sinne for the time to come: And if being thus vnfainedly in the whole man turned from all sinne, wee turne therein vnto God, with a penitent acknowledging of all transgressions, with an hearty desire of mercy, and forgiuenesse, with ioy and cheerefulnesse of Spirit, arising from the assurance of Gods loue and fauour in Christ; and with a desire and indeuour inwardly in our hearts, and outwardly in our bodies, to frame our liues according to the will and Word of God: These are infallible testimonies of true repentance, wrought in vs by the Spirit of God; yea, of that true & vnfained repentance, which
belongeth onely to Gods Elect. Whereas on the contrary, if wee cannot finde, and feele these things in any good measure begunne in vs, we cannot possibly haue this assurance.

Vse 5 Againe, séeing true repentance is a speciall worke of Gods grace, and only Gods elect can truely repent: then most wretchedly, and miserably do all such deceiue themselues, who perswade their owne hearts, that they can repent them of their sinnes, and be reconciled to God for them when they thinke good. As many such there are, who will not sticke to say of themselues, and of others, that it is yet too soone for them to repent, too soone for them to giue ouer their vaine pleasures, & carnall delights, that they may repent time inough hereafter, and when they are old, &c. Indéed, the Scripture saith in diuers places, that God will forgiue such as are truely humbled, and cast downe with remorse and sorrow, in regard of their sins, when, and at what time so euer they doe repent. And hereupon doe many take incouragement to liue as they list; nothing fearing, but to make al good by repentance at the last. And no doubt, if they do truely
repent at the last cast, all will be well with them indéed, how loosely soeuer they haue liued before. But it must be obserued, that God, who promiseth forgiuenes to euery one that repenteth, doth not promise repentance to euery one that sinneth. Repentance is the gift of God: and such as harden their hearts against it, when God in mercy doth call them vnto it, (as hee calleth dayly in the ministery, and preaching of the Gospell,) when such men would, they cannot repent, as the Apostle sheweth, Ro. 2.
Rom. 2.5. And if there be no repentance, then all lamentation, and teares that can procéede from such a one, are vtterly in vaine, as it is said of Esau, Heb. 12.
Heb. 12.17. that he found no place to repentance, though hee sought the blessing with teares. The Sacraments also, though they bee seales and pledges of Gods loue & fauour in Christ, are to such men vtterly vneffectuall. God will neither heare their own prayers, nor the prayers of any other, that pray and beseech him in their behalfe, as Ioh. 9. Psal. 66. and Ier. 7.
Ioh. 9.31. Psal. 66.18. Ier. 7.16.

Furthermore, if there be such a mutuall Vse 6 relation of Faith to the Word of God, then it followeth: First, that no other doctrine,
but onely the pure doctrine of Gods Word, must bee preached to the people of God, by all the faithfull Ministers of Iesus Christ; such as teach, and preach otherwise, being guilty euen of murthering and destroying such as heare and regard them, in causing them to build their faith and hope vpon errours, and lyes: for it is no better then very errors, & lies, whatsoeuer is repugnant, or in any measure swarueth from the pure simplicity of Gods Word, dangerous to the saluation of all such as rely and rest vpon it. And therefore 1. Pet. 4. 1. Pet. 4.11. If any man speake, let him speak as the words of God. And Esay 8.
Esay 8.20. To the Law, & to the Testimony, if they speak not according to this rule, it is because there is no light in them. For this cause also are the Ministers and preachers of the Gospell, termed the Messengers and Ambassadors of the Lord: as 2. Cor. 5. 2. Cor. 5.20. as not comming in their own names, nor hauing commission to deliuer any thing of their owne deuising; but simply and directly to doe the will of him that sent them: and to teach that alone, which he hath prescribed and commanded. And therfore also, 1. Thes. 2. 1. Thes. 2.13 When ye receiued of vs the Word of the
preaching of God, ye receiued it not as the word of men, but as it is indeed the Word of God.

Secondly, the people must also learne Vse 7 hereby, to try all things, and to keepe that which is good, that so their faith may bee grounded, not vpon the sand of mens deuices: but onely vpon the Rocke Christ Iesus, as Act. 17. and 1. Ioh. 4.
Acts 17.11. 1. Ioh. 4.1.

Last of all: seeing the Spirit of God Vse 8 seales the assurance of our election, by framing our hearts to an holy obedience: Nay, seeing this is the very end of our election, that we should be holy, and without blame before him in loue, as the Apostle teacheth, Ephes. 1.
Ephes. 1.4. Let vs therefore in the feare of God, (for the sound peace and ioy of our soules in this behalfe,) be exhorted and incouraged to obedience: and on the other side disswaded, and terrified from disobedience: exhorted, and encouraged (I say) to the one, by the examples of the godly, whose praise for their obedience, is so plentifully recorded in the Scripture, by the louing exhortations of the Apostles, and by the sweet promises, and experiences of the Lords liberall kindnes vnto such as either haue beene, or shall bee
faithfully obedient vnto his holy will; as also terrified from disobedience, by the fearefull examples and threatnings of Gods iudgements, vpon the children of disobedience. And to make our obedience the more acceptable vnto God, these thrée things are necessarily required: First, that it be exercised in the kéeping of euery commandement of God. For as Saint Iames saith, Iam. 2.10. chap. 2. He that breaketh one commandement, is guilty of all. Secondly, the whole man must endeuour to keepe the whole Law, in his minde, will, affections, and in all the faculties of both soule and body. As it is said of Iosias, 2. King. 13. 2. King. 13.25. that he turned to God, according to all the Law of Moses, with all his heart. And thirdly, we must be duely mindfull to pray, and beseech the Lord, to vouchsafe vs the sanctifying grace of his holy spirit, frō whose supernaturall working all our desire, and indeuour (to performe acceptable obedience vnto God) must proceed, and without whose gracious assistance, it is vnpossible to doe any thing pleasing him.

div.head: Quest. 24. When you receiue Bread and Wine at the Lords Table: what will you set your heart and minde vpon?
div.p: Answ. Vpon the Death and Passion of our Lord Iesus Christ, to glorifie and praise God, for the most excellent work of our Redemption by him: confessing that therein consisteth all our happinesse and saluation: And that it is no more possible to come to the Kingdome of Heauen without it: then it is possible to liue in this world, without meat and drink, 1. Cor 11.24, 25, 26.

div.head: EXPOSITION.
div.p:
THis doth our Lord Iesus Christ teach in that little clause of his institution, where he saith, Doe this in remembrance of me. Whereunto the Apostle Paul, 1. Cor. 11. hauing relation (in way of a declaration, or exposition) thus addeth, saying, As often as ye shall eate this Bread, and drinke this Cup, yee doe shew
the Lords death till he come. I haue spoken somewhat to this purpose, in that which goeth before. And I will now a little enlarge it, as the very same words doe minister fit matter for our further instruction.

div.head: As often as ye eate this Bread, and drinke this Cup.
div.p: Heere, and in this phrase of speech, we may first obserue, that our Lord Iesus Christ appointed no certaine or set times, for the celebration of the Sacrament of his Supper: but hath left the same to the godly wisedome of the Pastors and Ministers of his Word.

Whereupon it plainely followeth, not onely that it is an vnlawfull iniunction of the Papists to tye the administration and receiuing thereof vnto certain set dayes in the yeere, and especially vnto Easter: but also a very superstitious obseruation in all such as are more deuout, and ready to communicate at such times, then at others. According as of such superstitious affections, there is too much experience from time to time: so, as if the Sacrament
be administred at Easter, it is an easie matter to haue many communicants; all sorts and degrees will make full account of resorting thereunto: But as for all other times in the yeere, though they may come as conueniently; and though the necessity of often partaking bee neuer so plainely laid open vnto them; yet is it little or nothing accounted of. So superstitiously are the greatest part of people giuen to obserue dayes and times, moneths, and yeeres, which the Apostle reprooueth in the Galathians, chap. 4. Gal. 4.1 • .

div.head: Ye doe shew the Lords death.
div.p:
There is a double manner of shewing the Lords Death, in the vse and celebration of the Sacrament. The first appertaineth to the faithfull Ministers of Christ, they not administring the Lords Supper rightly, and as they ought to doe, except they make a declaration of the Lords Death vntill his comming: & that not only in the whole visible action of breaking, and distributing the Bread and Wine: but in preaching, and declaring out of the Word of God, the end & causes of Christs Death, for to stirre vp the remembrance
of his benefits, to confirme the Faith of the receiuers in the participation of the same: to exhort them to due praise and thanksgiuing, and to vnity and agréement with their fellow members. For, for these causes principally was this Sacrament ordained, as it is manifest in the words of Christs institution.

The preaching of the Word therefore, must not bee separated from the Sacrament (which is a seale of the doctrine.) For to make this separation, were as absurd. as if a man should deliuer a Seale without a writing. Reason. The Word may bee preached without the Sacraments: but ye Sacraments cannot rightly bee administred without the Word. And whereas it is obiected, that the Sacraments may aswell be administred without preaching at this day, as Habel his sacrifice was offred, and the Passeouer celebrated without preaching in former time: The answere is easie, that the cléere Sacraments of the New Testament in this point of the declaration of Christs Death, are vnfitly compared to the obscure figures of the Old Testament: And yet, had they according to their institution not onely a diuine action,
or silent ceremony: but also a preaching, and declaration of Christs Death, and of the benefits thereof. And although there be no expresse mention of the forme of Abels sacrifice; yet seeing the Scripture testifieth, Heb. 11. Heb. 11.4. that it was offered by faith, and graciously accepted, and Faith hath alwayes relation to the Word and promise of the Lord: there is no doubt but Abel presented his sacrifice with such words as declared his faith in the Seede which was promised to breake the Serpents head, Gen. 3.15. and to destroy the workes of the Diuell. And as for the Paschal Lamb, the institution carried with it an expresse commandement (as Exod. 12. Exod. 12.26, 27.) that the Israelites should declare to their children, the end and vse of the same Sacrament: whereby (though obscurely) yet according to the institution thereof, the Lords death was preached, before he came in the flesh. For this cause (as I said) according to Christs institution, and expresse commandement, ought euery Minister cleerely, and plainely, to preach and make declaration of the Death of Christ, to the instruction, edification, & comfort of all such as are partakers of the Lords Supper.

The other manner of shewing and declaring the Lords death, appertaineth to all true Christian communicants generally. And it is performed by them according to the meaning of the Holy Ghost, if they do not only cal to their remembrance the abasing of the Son of God in our flesh, and the most excellent worke of our Redemption, made by the price of his body and bloud: but doe also yeeld vnto him most hearty praise and thankes for the same: and therewithall also, not onely acknowledge themselues to bee his seruants, and of the number of them that looke to be saued, onely by the benefits of Christs death, & by no other meanes at all: but also, that if he had not yeelded his precious body to be crucified, & his precious bloud to be shed: the price of our Redemption, could not possibly haue bin satisfied; neither could the fierce wrath of GOD haue been appeased: but as wee are by nature the children of wrath; so should we for euer haue remained in the state of condemnation. They that haue this remembrance; they which with vpright hearts, and sound affections, doe make this profession, and acknowledgement, they are
true Christian communicants, and they doe rightly make declaration of the death of the Lord. And as at the Lords Table they receiue the Bread & Wine into their bodies; so are they spiritually made partakers of the fruits & benefits of Christs Death and Passion, to the vtter abolishing of the guiltinesse of all their sinnes and transgressions, to the true peace and ioy of their soules, and their vndoubted assurance of euerlasting blessednesse for euermore. According to that notable saying, Rom. 10. Rom. 10.9, 10. If thou shalt confesse with thy mouth the Lord Iesus, and beleeue in thine heart that God raised him vp from the dead, thou shalt be saued. For with the heart man beleeueth vnto righteousnesse, and with the mouth confession is made vnto saluation.

And as for all others which either come to the Lords Table for custome, or fashion sake; and being there, doe not reuerently call to their remembrance the most excellent worke of Redemption by Christs death, and bloud-shedding, to glorifie and praise GOD for it: All such are no true Christian communicants, they set not forth the Death of the Lord, they cannot
be assured of any benefit thereby, but doe euen eate and drinke their owne damnation.

The outward eating by the instruments of our body, causeth all our sences, our hearing, our seeing, our feeling, our tasting, to helpe our inward eating by Faith: and by the same quickneth, stirreth, strengtheneth and increaseth our Faith, that wee, may eate the body, and drinke the bloud of Christ the more effectually, and fruitfully. For when a faithfull Christian heareth these words of Christs institution sounding in his eares, This is my body which is giuen for you, and this is my bloud that is shed for remission of your sinnes: it stirreth vp his Faith to lay strong hold-fast vpon this promise: and in his heart doth assure himselfe that Christ dyed, and shed his bloud, not onely for the Redemption of the world in generall, but for his red • mption in particular: and that hee is vndoubtedly of the number of them that shall be saued.

When we heare these words, Do this in remembrance of mee: Our faith is assured that it is Christs commandement,
that we should vse this Sacrament to call to our remembrance the benefit of our saluation by the death of Christ, and in heart and minde at all times, but then especially to shew our selues thankefull to him for the same When our sight beholdeth vpon the Table the Bread and Wine, according to Christs ordinance broken, and powred out for vs to vse: the faith is moued thus to thinke: As surely, and truely, as my bodily eyes behold these creatures of Bread and Wine: so assuredly with the eye of Faith doe I behold the body and bloud of Christ broken, and shed for me vpon the Crosse, and the same my Sauiour now sitting at the right hand of God the Father, with the same body and bloud now glorified, wherewith vpon the Crosse, he paid the price of my Redemption. When we see the Minister offer vnto vs the Bread and the Cup, and wee receiue, and féele it: then inwardly in our hearts is our faith moued to haue this cogitation; that as surely as the Minister doth offer them vnto vs, and wee receiue them with our hands▪ so assuredly by faith doe we receiue Christ himselfe, and in our hearts feele and imbrace him, as the onely
price and meanes of our saluation.

When we eat of the Bread, and drinke of the Wine, and by our taste haue sence of the swéetnesse of them, and féele them passe down into our stomakes there to rest, that they may bee according to their nature, meanes to nourish and strengthen our bodies, and to continue them in life: Our Faith is stirred vp by these sences thus to thinke: Euen as certainly as our taste féeleth the sweetnesse of the Bread and Wine, and thereby perceiue indeed, that their operation is to nourish and strengthen our bodies, and to quicken our naturall spirits, which without such nourishment would perish: euen so, the taste of our faith, and sence of our hearts, doe féele the swéetnesse of Christs body and bloud, broken and shed for vs, and for all the rest of Gods Elect, and perceiue it thereby to be the onely food of our soules, without the which we should perish, both soule and body eternally.
Vse. Now for the vse, whether we take such sweet instruction and comfort in the vse of this blessed Sacrament, or no, wee will examine, God willing, when wee come to the last question.

div.head: Quest. 25. What is to bee thought of such as presume to receiue the Sacrament, without thus remembring the Death and Passion of our Lord Iesus Christ, to glorifie and praise God, for the worke of Redemption by him?
div.p: Answ. The Apostle, 1. Cor. 11. calleth them vnworthy eaters, and drinkers of it, and saith, that they are guilty of the body and bloud of the Lord, that is, of reproching the very body and bloud of Christ, and euen of treading the same vnder their feet: And that they eate and drinke their owne damnation, because they discerne not the Lords body, 1. Cor. 11.27, 29.

div.head: EXPOSITION.
div.p:
THere are both worthy, and vnworthy receiuers of the Lords Supper. Who they are that receiue it worthily, I haue shewed in the
two and twentieth question.

Now, a first sort of vnworthy receiuers are such, as are vtterly destitute of faith, being meere Atheists, and godlesse persons, cōming to the Lords Table only for custome, and fashions sake, without either knowledge or regard of the matter in hand. Another sort are such, who although they haue some knowledge and Faith of Christ, so as they are perswaded of his Death and Redemption, yet are notwithstanding dissolute, and licencious, hauing no care or conscience of true repentance, nor of expressing the fruits of their knowledge and faith in their life and conuersation.

Reason Now the manner how the wicked and vngodly doe become guilty of the body and bloud of the Lord, may plainly be shewed by this similitude: Euen, as hee that reprochfully receiueth the Princes Seale, is guilty of the maiesty of the Prince, not which he receiueth, but which hee despiseth. And wee know, that it is a very hainous offence to despise the Princes Seale (although in substance it bee but printed Wax:) Euen so, he that eateth and drinketh the Bread and Wine at the Lords
Table vnworthily (it being the Seale of Christs Passion) committeth on heinous offence, although in substance they be but earthly creatures. In the like sence doth the Apostle say, Heb. 6. Heb. 6.6. of wicked men that fall from Christian Religion, that they crucifie again to themselues the Sonne of God, and make a mocke of him. And Chapter 10. chap. 10.1 • . that they tread vnder foot the Son of God, &c. Not that Christs person suffereth any such thing of them indeed, (for he is now impassible) but that their malice is as great, and their wickednesse as horrible an offence against Christ, as was the malice of the Iewes & Gentiles in crucifying him.

Now such as are vnworthy receiuers of the • Sacrament of Christs Supper, as by reason of their infideli • y and wicked liues, they thus become guilty of the body and bloud of Christ: so are they far from reaping any profit by the Sacrament, as that they grieuously prouoke the wrath of God: some to their temporall punishment in this life, and correction by sicknesse, weakenesse, and bodily death, as the Apostle there saith of the Corinthians. 1. Cor. 1 • .30. For this cause (saith he) many are sicke and weake
among you, and many sleepe: and othersome to their euerlasting condemnation.

Vse. Let vs take good heed then (as wee tender the glory of God, and our owne saluation,) that wee be not willingly in the number of vnworthy receiuers: assuring our selues, that if it bee a great offence to tread ye Princes Seale vnder foot, it is then a much more wicked abusing of Christ, to receiue the Sacrament of his body and bloud vnreuerently, and without faith in his redemption. And if hee that defileth the Princes Letters, shal not escape vnpunished, but is worthy to bee reputed, and handled as a Traitor; Much more grieuous punishment then shall hee worthily sustaine, as a most wicked Traitor against the Sonne of God, which defileth the holy Sacrament of his body and bloud, with an vnhallowed hand, and vnfaithfull heart. Let euery man therefore in the feare of GOD, proue and examine himselfe, how hee stands affected in this behalfe; and feeling our faith weake; let vs with the Apostles, Luke 17. Luke 17.5. pray vnto the Lord to increase and strengthen the same, and that so effectually, in his righteousnesse, and Redemption, as that
no temptations of the world, the flesh or the Diuell, may be able to disanull, and make it void, vntill we enioy the end therof, which is the saluation of our soules, as 1. Pet. 1.1. Pet. 1.9.

div.head: Quest. 26. How must wee prepare our selues beforehand, for the worthy receiuing of the Lords Supper?
div.p: Answ. By examining our knowledge, our faith, our repentance, our purposes, and affections, how sound and vpright they are before God: According to that of the Apostlae, 1. Cor. 11. Let a man examine himselfe, and so let him eate of that Bread, and drinke of that Cup, 1. Cor. 11.28.

div.head: EXPOSITION.
div.p:
SVch onely are meet and worthy partakers of the Lords Supper, who before they presume to come vnto the same, doe diligently, and in the feare of God descend into themselues, and make a due tryall and examination, (according to the rule and touchstone of
Gods Word) as concerning their knowledge, their faith, their repentance, their purposes and affections both for the auoyding of sinne, and of liuing iustly and acceptably in the sight of God. For vnto all these (there is no doubt) but the Apostle hath relation, in admonishing euery man to examine himselfe.

Concerning the examination, and triall of knowledge in the first place, many necessary branches there are of true knowledge, which euery true Christian Communicant ought to be throughly furnished withall: But I will speake onely of such as are most speciall, and without the vnderstanding whereof, there can bee no worthy receiuing of this Sacrament. The first respecteth the vnderstanding of our naturall condition, whether we conceiue, and feele it to be such, as I haue formerly discouered it to bee in the sixt question.

A second speciall branch of this knowledge hath relation vnto God, and vnto our Lord Iesus Christ, as concerning the most excellent worke of our redemption in such sort, as I haue already shewed in the eight, and in the tenth and eleuenth
questions. The last speciall branch of true knowledge, that I meane now to remember, concerneth the institution and right vse of Christs Supper, according to that which is set downe before in the ninetéenth, twentieth, one and twentieth, and two and twentieth questions. This knowledge of our naturall estate, this vnderstanding of our Redemption, and reconciliation, and this knowledge of the end and purpose of Christ in instituting this Sacrament, and what belongs to the right vse, and celebration of it, ought to be in all those that will be worthy partakers therof; and to proue and examine their seuerall soules and consciences, whether they be furnished with such knowledge or no; ought euery true Christian to be religiously carefull of frō time to time, before he come to the receiuing of Christs Supper.

The second branch of a true Christian examination, concerneth faith, which being ioyned with the former knowledge of the loue of God, and of our Lord Iesus Christ, as touching the worke of our Redemption, consisteth in a sure and absolute resolution, that whatsoeuer Christ hath wrought for the saluation of mankinde, the
same in particular belonge •• vnto vs: and so as euery one may say of himselfe, and of his owne estate and condition (through the witnesse of Gods Spirit in his heart) with the Apostle Paul, Rom. 8. Rom. 8.38, 39. I am perswaded that neither death, nor life, nor any thing else, shal be able to separate me from the loue of God in Christ Iesus. And so consequently concerning the vse of the Sacrament, that as we see with our eyes the bread broken, and the wine powred out? so assuredly, and without all doubt, we doe beleeue, and rest resolued, that the body of Christ was broken, and his bloud shed vpon the Crosse for our sinnes. And againe, that as surely as the Minister doth giue vnto vs the bread and wine; euen so assuredly we be out of doubt, that the Lord giueth vnto vs the fruits, and benefits of his death and passion, to be applied to our soules by faith for our saluation. This faith ought to be in euery true Christian Communicant, or else hee cannot possibly be a worthy receiuer of the Lords Supper. And therefore for this triall and examination, ought euery one to enter into his owne heart, before he presume to present himselfe vnto the same.
According to that also of the Apostle, 2. Cor. 13.2. Cor. 13.5. Examine your selues whether ye be in the faith, proue your owne selues, &c.

Next of all followeth the examination of repentance, and namely, that forasmuch as we sinne daily and hourely against the Lord, in our thoughts, desires, words and actions, whether we finde, and feele in our selues such an vnfayned turning of the whole man from all sinne vnto God, as I haue already spoken of in the three and twentieth question.

And last of all, whether there be in vs a settled purpose, and resolution of heart, ioyned with an holy endeuour, to glorifie God, and to seale the assurance of our owne saluation, in all the workes of holinesse, and righteousnesse, according to euery mans place and calling, and the diuers occasions that are offered? This is that godly and Christian triall, and examination of our selues, which the Apostle commendeth, and whereunto hee exhorteth: The which whosoeuer vseth in the feare of God, before hee approach to the Table of the Lord, such a one (by his grace) is a true Christian Communicant. But this is a priuiledge proper onely to
Gods elect, none being thus religiously carefull to proue and examine themselues beforehand, for a right preparation, but onely they.

If any part of this examination be left vnperformed, there cannot possibly be any true prouing of our selues, according to the meaning of the holy Ghost; and so consequently no worthy receiuing of the Reason. 1 Lords Supper. For these particulars of knowledge, faith, repentance, and purpose of a godly conuersation, are so strongly linked, and tyed together, as that they cannot be separated: for without the knowledge of our naturall wretchednesse, and of the loue of God the Father, and of our Lord Iesus Christ in the most excellent worke of our Redemption, there can bee no true faith, as Rom. 10. Rom. 10.14 How shall they beleeue in him of whom they haue not Reason. 2 heard? And againe, though a man be endued with neuer so sound and absolute a knowledge of these things; yet, vnlesse through the testimony of Gods Spirit he be able to apply that which hee knoweth, vnto the peace, and saluation of his soule, what can hee profit by his knowledge? Surely nothing at all. And though a man
haue neuer so much knowledge, & boast Reason. 3 neuer so much of faith, yet vnlesse hee be truly penitent, and sorrowfull for his manifold sinnes and transgressions, together with a true desire, and endeuour to glorifie GOD in the doing of that which he commandeth, and in the eschewing of that which he doth forbid: his knowledge is vaine, his faith is no faith, he doth but deceiue himselfe, with a vaine shew & imagination of it.

Whereby as the miserable estate and Vse 1 condition of all such, is euidently discouered, who intrude themselues to the Table of the Lord, onely for custome and fashion sake: as many such there are, the Lord knoweth, at this day, who are so far from prouing, and examining their seuerall soules and consciences, (according to the Apostles counsell and admonition) whether they be furnished with ye true knowledge of their naturall estate, and of the Lords vnspeakable goodnes and mercy in the most excellent worke of our redemption, whether they know also and vnderstand the institution, and what belongs to the right vse of this Sacrament: so farre from examining their faith, their repentance,
their purposes and endeuours for a godly reformation; as that they carelesly and irreligiously passe ouer them all, euen like the Horse and Mule, Psal. 3 2 9. (as the Prophet Dauid speaketh) that haue no vnderstanding: making no conscience of continuing in ignorance, infidelity, prophanenesse, and hardnes of heart, in vaine-swearing, in breaking the Sabbath; some in malice, some in whoredome, some in drunkennesse, some in couetousnes, oppression, deceit, dissembling, lying, and the like; neither being allured by the sweet promises of Gods grace and mercy in Christ, nor terrified by any threatnings of his fearefull iudgements: But as they are filthy, so will they grow on to be more filthy, and wax worse and worse: and yet in great scorne and disdaine will such take it, either to be admonished, or to be suspended from the Lords Table, perswading themselues, that they haue as much right to the partaking of the Sacrament, and come as well prepared as the best. But howsoeuer they flatter themselues, it is apparant enough by that which hath béene spoken, that such are guilty euen of betraying the body of the Sonne of God, as
much as lyeth in them, and of reproachfully powring foorth his bloud vnder their féete. And therefore shal be so far from being partakers of any part of his redemption, as that they shall not faile to be fearefully ouerwhelmed with his fearefull iudgements, vnlesse they repent, & craue mercy and forgiuenes, before it be too late. Which should be sufficient (a man would thinke) to strike a terrour into the hearts of all ignorant, faithlesse, vnrepentant, and dissolute liuers, if they be not already giuen ouer to a reprobate sence.

But now, lest in denouncing this fearfull iudgement against the wicked; and lest withall in vrging so strictly this prouing, and examination of euery seuerall conscience, such among the godly as haue weake and tender consciences, should be rather terrified, and discouraged from the partaking of this Sacrament, then comforted and encouraged, forasmuch as very fewe among the multitude, doe in this manner examine themselues: and they that doe, cannot but feele so great want and imperfection, either in their knowledge, or in their faith, or in their repentance and sorrow for sinne, or in the study
of a new life, or in all, and euery of these, as that they must needes be wonderfully cast downe, if not vtterly discouraged.

Vse 2 Let vs therefore obserue for our singular comfort, that this triall and examination must bee made within the bounds of humane frailty; and the Lord in this, as in all other things, will not faile to be gracious and mercifull for Christs sake. For hee knoweth our corruptions and imperfections, and will haue regard of our infirmities. Onely let vs not be carelesse, slacke, and negligent, but feeling by this tryall great want in our selues, let vs penitently acknowledge, and make confession of it. Let vs be zealous and frequent in faithfull and feruent prayer, and say euery one to God, I am sorry O Lord for my sinnes, but not as the haynousnesse of them doth require. Open mine eyes, I beseech thee, that I may clearely see and discerne the wretched & miserable estate that I am in, without thy speciall grace and mercy in Christ Iesus. I beleeue and know that thy Sonne Christ Iesus hath shed his bloud for mee: but increase my faith (O God) and helpe my vnbeliefe. I desire to liue in the true feare of thy name,
and to walk in the wayes of thy commandements, but the world and the flesh doe much hinder mee in the course of obedience; doe thou therefore graciously assist and helpe me with thy blessed Spirit, &c.

The sence and knowledge of our owne weakenesse, must not discourage vs from the Lords Table: for this heauenly feast is a medicine for all them that be sicke in soule; a comfort to all penitent sinners, a free and liberal gift to all such as are poore in spirit, and haue no conceit of their own righteousnes. Christ in this feast is giuen as meats, without which we must of necessity perish: he is giuen as life, without whom there is nothing but death. The best worthinesse that we can bring, is an vnfayned confession of our owne vnworthines, that ye mercy of God may make vs worthy; to despaire in our selues, that his grace may cōfort vs; to humble our selues, that his goodnes may raise vs vp; and to accuse our selues; ye Christ Iesus by his merits may iustifie vs. For although of our selues we are able to doe nothing, yet by him we shall be able to doe all things.

These, and such like cogitations if wee haue, in preparing our selues to that blessed
nourishment of our soules, hee that breaketh not a bruised reede, Esay 42.3. nor putteth out smoking flax, will not cast vs off because of our infirmities, but mercifully receiue vs to the partaking of his euerlasting loue.

The Lord GOD respecteth nothing so much our actions, as our affections; nothing so much our workes, as our desires and endeuours: So that he who truly and vnfaynedly desires to be righteous, hee is righteous. He that so desireth to beleeue, he doth beleeue. He that so desireth to repent, he doth repent. Hee that so striueth to leaue, and forsake his sinnes, the Lord reputeth and accounteth of such a one, as if hee had left and forsaken them. They that truly and vnfaynedly desire not to fall, nor to be foyled of their spirituall enemies, the Lord esteemeth of such as his inuincible Souldiers, and valiant Worthies, who were neuer vanquished. For he accepteth the desire for the deede: and, if there be first a willing minde, it is accepted according to that a man hath, and not according to that a man hath not, as speaketh the Apostle, 2. Cor. 8.2. Cor. 8.12. So Math. 5. Math. 5.6. is he pronounced blessed, not which hath
attayned to perfect inherent righteousnes, but who hungreth and thirsteth after it. Blessed are they which hunger and thirst after righteousnes, for they shall be satisfied. Lord (saith Dauid, Psal. 10. Psal. 10.17.) thou hast heard the desire of the poore, thou preparest their heart, and bendest thine eare to them. And Psal. 145. Psa. 145.19 he will fulfill the desires of them that feare him. Faith maketh vs not acceptable in the sight of God, or worthy partakers of the Lords Supper, in respect of it selfe, because it is an action or vertue, or because it is strong, liuely and perfect: but in respect of Christ Iesus crucified, whom faith apprehendeth, as he is set foorth vnto vs in the Word and Sacraments. It is Christ that is the Author and matter of our righteousnesse, and it is he that applyeth the same vnto vs. And as for faith in vs, it is but an instrument, to apprehend, and receiue that which Christ for his part offereth and giueth. So then, if faith erre not in his proper obiect, but follow the promise of God, though it doe but weakely apprehend: nay, though it cause a man onely to desire and endeuour to apprehend, yet is it a true faith, and sufficient to saluation.

The sorrowfull Father, Mark 9.
Mark. 9 24. which with care for his Son, cryed vnto Christ, Lord I beleeue, helpe my vnbeliefe; though his faith was weake, yet obtayned his purpose at Christs hands. If our faith he but as a graine of Mustard-séede, yet will it much preuaile with Gods mercy. The Apostles of Christ, which were admitted to his last Supper, were notwithstanding weake, and touched with many infirmities, although they were not altogether wicked and faithlesse as Iudas was. They beleeued in Christ, they loued Christ, and they loued one another: And yet shewed they their weakenesse, when Peter, not without some reproach of the residue, preferred himselfe before them all: Mat. 26.33 Though all other be offended (saith hee) yet will not I be offended by thee. And when also they ambitiously contended among themselues who should bee the chiefe. Mar. 9.33. And did not their faith also appeare to be weake, when they all forsooke him, and fled away at the time of his apprehension, yea and after the knowledge of his doctrine, and experience of many and wonderfull miracles? yet it pleased our Sauiour neuerthelesse, in great mercie to accept them,
and to admit them as singular instruments of his grace.

div.head: Let a man examine himselfe.
div.p:
Whereas the Apostle saith not,Exposition. Let a man examine his brother, or neighbour: but, Let a man examine himselfe; there ariseth a note which I am not willing to passe ouer: Rom. 14.12. That euery man shall giue an account for himselfe to God; and not one man for anothers ignorance, infidelity, or hardnesse of heart: And that therefore ought euery one to looke vnto himselfe, that his owne knowledge bee sound, his owne faith true, his owne repentance vnfained, and his desire of holinesse without hypocrisie: without either looking curiously into other mens sinnes, and imperfections, (vnlesse it be onely in a Christian and charitable maner to admonish and reforme them) or without beeing discouraged from the Sacrament, through the presence of such, whom they esteeme not so meet partakers (in regard of some corruptions or infirmities) as themselues: Being Reason 1 fully assured, that as the faith of one man shall not iustifie another; so shall not the infidelity, ignorance, Hab. 2.4. or prophanenesse of any (though present at the Communion)
possibly hinder the effectuall communicating of Christs body and bloud to the faithfull receiuer. Ezek. 18.20 As Ezek. 18. The righteousnesse of the righteous shall bee vpon him, and the wickednesse of the wicked shal Reason 2 be vpon himselfe. The essenciall ioyning also in this communion being spirituall, wherein the wicked cannot possibly come néere ye faithful members of Iesus Christ.
Lastly, whereas some holding, that Iudas receiued the Sacrament; do thereupon inferre, that all, without exception, are now to be admitted to the partaking thereof:
I will briefely deliuer my opinion, in both respects.

Whereas the Apostle, 1. Cor. 11. and all the Euangelists with one consent, doe record & say, that our Lord Iesus Christ, hauing broken the Bread, did giue it vnto his Disciples: There ariseth a question, (and it is not a new, but an ancient question) whether Iudas were one of these Disciples, to whom Christ thus gaue the broken bread; or whether he were gone from the Table before, and busily imployed at that very instant about his Treason?

I will not take vpon mee absolutely to
determine it: but onely set downe in as few words as I can, what I conceiue, and the reasons of it.

They that thinke that Iudas was present, & receiued the Sacrament of Christs body and bloud, doe ground their perswasion vpon the words of the Euangelist: where they all agree, that Iesus sate down with the twelue. Now Iudas (say they) was one of the twelue; and beeing at the Table, as well as the other, there is no doubt, but as well as the other he did partake of ye Sacrament. That Iudas was one of the twelue, no man can deny, neither do I, that he also sate at the Table: but that he did partake of the Sacrament, I cannot resolue, but incline to the contrary for diuers reasons.

A first reason is out of Luke 22. and Reason 1 1. Cor. 11. where it is recorded, that when Christ gaue the Bread vnto his Disciples he said, This is my body which is giuen for you. But the body of Christ was not giuen for Iudas: therfore was not the sacramental bread giuen vnto him, as vnto the rest,

Againe, Christ then promised (as Mat. Reason 2 26.) that all they which there dranke with him of the fruit of the Vine, should drinke
with him afterward in his Fathers Kingdome: But Iudas shall neuer drinke with him in his Fathers Kingdome: therefore did he not drinke with him of the fruit of the Vine.

Reason 3 Another reason I gather out of Ioh. 13. where, after our Lord Iesus Christ had pointed out the Traitor, Ioh. 13.26, 27, 30. saying, Hee it is to whom I shall giue a sop when I haue dipped it: and he wet a Sop, and gaue it to Iudas Iscariot, Simons sonne. It followeth also in the same Chapter, not onely that after the Soppe, Satan entred into him: but also, that as soone as he had receiued the Sop, he went immediately out. Now, if he went immediatly out, after the receiuing of the Sop, about his Treason: then was hee gone before the institution, & administration of the Sacrament. Whereas then hee sate downe at the Table, it was for the eating of the Passeouer. In the eating of the Passeouer, he dipped his hand with Christ in the Dish; and in the eating of the Passeouer did Christ giue him the Soppe. Now séeing the Passeouer was celebrated before the Sacrament of the Lords Supper was instituted, and Iudas went out immediately after the same: it is a cleere
case (as I verily take it) that hee did not receiue that Sacrament at all.

The Euangelist Luke, as I noted before, goeth on with a narration of ye Passeouer, and of the Lords Supper together, and afterward by way of recapitulation, or rehearsall, returneth againe to the words, which the other Euangelists iointly witnesse, to bee spoken before the institution of the Supper.
But admit, Iudas was present at the institution of it, & did partake of the same as well as the other: what will follow?

Why, this, will some say: That as Christ admitted Iudas (whom hee knew to be an Hypocrite, a Reprobate, and a very Diuel:) so ought the Minister without difference, & respect, without tryall, and examination, to admit to the Lords Table at this day, such as are notoriously euill, and manifestly lewd, & wicked. For none of such (say they) are worse then Iudas.

But though I be not peremptory in the former, because I know that some learned men are of a contrary minde: yet this consequence I absolutely deny and contradict, as most absurd, and as most iniurious to Christs body and bloud. It is true, that Iudas was an Hypocrite, a Reprobate, and a very Diuell; in that sence Christ so calleth him, Ioh. 6.70. Ioh. 6. But if hee were at the Sacrament; to whom was his hypocrisie, his reprobation, and diuelish practise knowne? And to whom could these things be an offence? It is manifest by the Text, that none of his fellow-Disciples knew him to be such a one: and therefore vnto none of them could he be an offence. Yea, but Christ (will they say) knew him to bee such a vile wretch, and yet admitted him. Well, he thus knew him as he was God,
and not as he was Man: and therfore this maketh nothing to the matter. It only concludeth; that although a man be neuer so very an hypocrite, of neuer so lewd & wicked disposition: yet so long as he makes profession of the truth, and is not discouered to be an hypocrite, but keeps his lewdnesse and wickednes secret: so long the Minister ought not to debarre, or repel him from the Communion. This is all that can rightly follow frō Christs example, in admitting Iudas to his last Supper, if he did admit him. And after this maner (I make no doubt) but that many hypocrites, and wicked liuers, are oftentimes admitted to the partaking of these holy mysteries at this day: yea, euen where the Ministers are most curious, and most religiously carefull to separate the vnworthy; It being the proper office onely of God to search the heart, and hidden affections, and not the Ministers, who can labour no further then to the outward behauiour & conuersation. But for any man to affirme, that the Minister is too precise, transgresseth Christs example, and offereth wrong in excluding, and shutting out such from the Lords Table, as are ignorant of the
worke of our Redemption, by Christs humiliation, and sufferings; or such whose offences are open, and they knowne to continue in them without repentance, according to the nature and quality of their transgressions: Besides their impugning herein the Law of the Land, which hath giuen power & authority to the Minister in this behalfe; they become most iniurious (as I noted before) to the holy Sacrament of the body and bloud of the Lord, Math. 7.6. in thus opening gaps for Dogs and Swine to eate and deuoure it. They flatly contradict the precepts and rules of the Holy Ghost, in diuers places of the Scripture, and oppose their owne partiall and selfe-conceits, against the godly iudgement, and graue authority of all the godly learned that euer were.
